description.narrative: At the EU Facility level, according to mid-term progress report January-June 2020, key highlight of delivery results are, for example: - One formal Voluntary Partnership Agreement (VPA) negotiation took place between the EU and Côte d'Ivoire while the planned negotiation with Laos and Thailand were postponed. In spite of the challenges by the corona crisis, in many countries, the commitment to the VPA process remained strong. - Progress was made at the technical level, for example: the revision at the thematic group on Timber Legality Assurance Systems (TLAS) and the legality definition in Cameroon and Thailand; the setting up a new thematic group on TLAS and the legality definition in Côte d'Ivoire; and regulatory revisions in Indonesia. - A lot of desk-based work have been done, e.g. the Facility updated all its FLEGT country webpages on its website, captured evidence in areas of governance applicable to FLEGT or VPA processes in partner countries, documented the impact of trainings of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in the Mekong region and published impact stories related the VPA processes in Ghana and Thailand. For Sida Special Work on Regional Asia and MSMEs, EFI made progress in the documentation and dissemination of lessons learned of the MSMEs work. EFI published the paper Small and Micro-sized entities in the Mekong region’s forest sector and raised awareness about the MSME work in regional fora such as the Asia Pacific Forestry Week, the 7th TLAS Workshop in late 2019 in Indonesia and in APEC Experts Group on Illegal Logging and Associated Trade meeting in Malaysia in early 2020. Gender equality was strengthened through a gender workshop organized by WOCAN under the Regional Asia gender helpdesk framework. EFI informed that the workshop was successful and received positive feedback from their participants. The training took a hands-on approach and was a good balance of theoretical introductions to key concepts in gender, tools for gender analysis, and group work to practice the tools. One good lesson learned is that prior to the training, EFI had three meetings with the WOCAN to underline the objectives of the training, share information about participants, introduce the SmE work and FLEGT. EFI informed that the regional work supported by Sida until the end of 2020 will become part of the new FLEGT Asia program and contribute to the dialogue between the EU and ASEAN+3. This means that financial resource for Sida special work can be more focused on the MSME activities and linking to regional level while the Regional Asia work will still be implementing from the EU resources.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 DKT International (US-based non-for-profit) have submitted an application for a regional programme to contribute to improved sexual and reproductive health and rights in six countries in the region (Tanzania, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, DRC, Mozambique). Focus is on decreasing the number of unwanted pregnancies and the availability to safe abortion. By increasing peoples access to a wide range of contraceptives, like IUD and implants, one contributes to their opportunities to decide over their own bodies and fertility. The programme is also specifically focused on young people through efforts to reduce teenage pregnancies and this is intended to help reduce the maternal mortality rates. The programme will also complement the programmes implemented through existing health systems and the public sector which often suffers from lack of resources. This complementing programme with the private sector is intended to contribute to reduced poverty and in the end support economic development.
The six countries have demographical similarities when it comes to the large number of Young people, high maternal mortality rates and a huge unmet need for information and health services related to sexual and reproductive health and rights. Access to and the use of modern contraceptives (Contraceptive Prevalence Rates - CPR) is for example in Uganda only 8%. In Ethiopia, which is the second most populated country in Africa with approximately 100 million people, more than 66% are young below 25 years. In Tanzania more than 50% are below the age of 18 and the trend is similar in the remaining countries. There is therefore a great potential to increase the market in the region on access to contraceptives and especially among young people given the demographic similarities. There is also a big potential to build on already ongoing initiatives and existing programmes which DKT is implementing in these six countries.
This regional programme is planned to complement programmes at bilateral in those countries where Sida is working on SRHR. Initial discussions have been held with the Embassies in Kinshasa, Maputo and Dar es Salam. Continuous consultations will be held with these as well as with the Embassies in Kampala and Addis Ababa. There are also clear Connections to Sidas global programme support to strategic partners such as IPAS and IPPF who are also working on SRHR, contraceptives and abortion. Synergies will be explored throughout the programme and there is also a firm interest from DKT International to look at potential connections and collaborations at bilateral level as well as with Sidas partners at global level,of which many are already established collaborating partners with DKT International.
DKT International are well established as one of the worlds' main organisations with expertise in Contraceptive Social Marketing (CSM). In Ethiopia DKT is running the largest programme in the country on contraceptives and safe abortion since 1990 and it also represents the third largest CSM programme in the World. The proposed programme is over 4 years (2016-2020) and has a budget of a total 80 million SEK and Sida is the first and so far only donor to this regional programme. This is based on the fact that there are very few regional SRHR-focused donors in the region and ever fewer that are focusing on access to safe and legal abortions. There is a possibility that other donors who has expressed an interest for this programme will contribute with funding later on. A potential support from Sida is expected to generate 28 million Couple Years Protection (CYP), which is a method used to estimate the protection against a pregnancy during one year by different contraceptive methods. Sidas support will be used for procurement of contraceptives, marketing and targeted youth activities. It will also be used to increase collaboration with the private health sector (clinics and pharmacies) to increase access to safe abortions wherever legal.
The country offices are responsible for implementation and the head office in Washington DC bears the financial responsibility. The programme will mainly focus on large volumes of procured contraceptives and abortion-related medicines and Equipment as well as distribution of these through strategic marketing. It also finances training and competence-building for health staff, both within the public and the private sector with focus on SRHR and counseling. Special youth activities will also be implemented with the purpose to reduce the number of unwanted pregnancies and increase the knowledge about SRHR generally.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 DKT International (US-baserad non-profit organisation) har inkommit med en ansökan för ett regionalt program för att långsiktigt bidra till förbättrad sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter i sex länder i regionen (Tanzania, Etiopien, Kenya, Uganda, Demokratiska Republiken Kongo, Mozambique). Fokus ligger på att minska antalet oönskade graviditeter och osäkra aborter genom ökad tillgång till preventivmedel och erbjudandet av säker abort. Genom att öka människors tillgång till ett utbud av preventivmedel inkl. fokus på långtidsverkande preventivmedel, såsom tex. spiral och p-stav, bidrar man till deras möjlighet att själva bestämma över sin fertilitet. Insatsen avser också att särskilt fokusera på ungdomar genom att bidra till ett minskat antal tonårsgraviditeter och detta avses bidra till minskade mödradödlighetssiffror. Insatsen bidrar även till att komplettera de insatser som genomförs genom befintliga hälsosystem och den offentliga sektorn som ofta lider av bristande resurser. Denna komplementerande insats inom privata sektorn avses bidra till minskad fattigdom och i slutändan gynna ekonomisk utveckling.
De sex länderna har demografiskt stora likheter i vad det gäller ett stort antal unga människor, höga mödradödlighetssiffror och kraftigt undersatta behov av information och vård när det gäller sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter. Tillgången till och användingen av moderna preventivmedel (Contraceptive Prevalence Rates - CPR) är tex. i Uganda endast 8%. I Etiopien, som är det andra mest befolkningstäta landet i Afrika med ca 100 miljoner människor, utgör mer än 66% unga under 25 år. I Tanzania är över 50% under 18 år och trenden ser liknande ut i de övriga länderna. Det finns därmed ett stort utrymme för att bredda marknaden i regionen vad gäller tillgången till preventivmedel och speciellt bland unga, givet de demografiska likheterna. Det finns även stor potential att bygga på redan tagna initiativ och pågående program som DKT implementerar i dessa sex länder.
Detta regionala program avser komplettera bilaterala insatser inom SRHR-området i de länder där Sida arbetar inom hälsa. Inledande dialog har först med ambassaderna i Kinshasa, Maputo och Dar es Salaam. Vidare konsultationer kommer att genomföras med dessa samt med ambassaderna i Kampala och Addis Abeba. Det finns också tydliga kopplingar till Sidas globala stöd till strategiskt viktiga organisationer som tex. International Pregnancy Advisory Services (IPAS) och International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) som också arbetar med SRHR, preventivmedel och abort. Synergier kommer att utvecklas vidare under programmets gång och det finns också ett stort intresse från DKT International att närmare utforska kopplingar och samarbeten på bilateral nivå, såväl som med Sidas partners på global nivå, varav flertalet redan är etablerade samarbetspartners med DKT International.
DKT International är väl etablerade som en av världens främsta organisationer med expertis inom Contraceptive Social Marketing (CSM). I Etiopien bedriver DKT International det största programmet i landet inom preventivmedel och säker abort sedan 1990 och det utgör även det tredje största programmet inom CSM i världen. Den föreslagna insatsen löper över 4 år (2016-2020) och omfattar totalt 80 miljoner kronor och Sida är den första och än så länge enda finansiären till detta regionala program. Detta grundar sig i att det för närvarande finns mycket få regionala SRHR-inriktade givare i regionen och ännu färre som fokuserar på tillgång till säker abort. Det finns dock en möjlighet att andra givare som uttryckt intresse för programmet kommer att bidra med stöd framöver. Ett potentiellt stöd från Sida beräknas genererera 28 miljoner Couple Years Protection (CYP), vilket är en mätmetod för att uppskatta skyddet mot graviditet under ett år av olika typer av preventivmedel. Sidas stöd kommer att gå till upphandling av preventivmedel, marknadsföring och särskilda ungdomssatsningar. Det kommer också att gå till att utöka samarbeten med privata hälsosektorn (bl.a. kliniker och apotek) för att öka tillgången till säkra aborter där detta är lagligt.
Landkontoren har ansvar för implementering av verksamheten och huvudkontoret i Washington DC bär det finansiella ansvaret. Programmet finansierar i huvudsak inköp av stora volymer preventivmedel och abort-relaterade mediciner och utrustning samt distribuering av dessa genom strategisk marknadsföring. Det finansierar även utbildning och kompetenshöjande insatser för sjukvårdspersonal, både inom offentlig och privat sektor med fokus på SRHR och rådgivning. Särskilda ungdomssatsningar kommer också att genomföras med syftet att få ner antalet oönskade graviditeter samt öka kunskapen om SRHR generellt.

The programme by DKT International aims to reverse the high number of unwanted pregnancies and unsafe abortions by ensuring that a wide range of contraceptive methods are available, affordable and of high quality. The programme also intends to increase access to safe abortion services (where legal) including post-abortion care (PAC) counselling and SRHR information. By expanding the scale and scope of the procurement of contraceptives, to prevent regular stock-outs of commodities, more women and men will have a broader access to a wide range of contraceptive methods. In addition to focusing on supply of contraceptives and medical abortion products, strategic marketing and brand-building that caters to different segments of the population, creates demand. By reducing the barriers to accessing contraceptives and informing the general public of the value of using contraceptives, DKT operates from the assumption that many people will ultimately use their own funds to pay for the products and services they want as long as they are affordable and accessible. This has proven to be the fact in many countries around the world, where DKT is operating and even in low-income countries. The poorest of the poor and those who do not have the money to pay for contraceptives or health services are often targeted by other NGOs, UN, donors (for example with free condoms) and governments themselves. DKT does not claim to target this segment of the population as the prime objective of the programme. They do however also focus on the poor, underserved communities and high-risk groups and they engage with young people through different marketing strategies to reach those who are not able to pay and they also procure commodities which are distributed for free by other organisations. The intended outcome of this programme is to increase the contraceptive prevalence rates through increased number of Couple Years Protection (CYP) and reduced costs per CYP as well as ensuring safe abortion services are available wherever legal. Sida funds will result in increased sales and services and contribute to the drive for health impact with focus on reduced number of unwanted pregnancies and unsafe abortions with a general impact on peoples' SRHR.

tag.narrative: 3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: In 2019, DKT generated over 6.4 million CYPs (109% of target) through the sale to the private and public sectors (including NGOs) of more than 98.3 million condoms, 6.2 million cycles of oral contraceptives, 4.6 million emergency contraceptives, 4.1 million injectables, 488,000 implants, 254,000 IUDs, 1.7 million tablets of misoprostol, 544,000 medical abortion (MA) combipacks, and 7,600 MVA kits in East and Southern Africa (see table 1 below). These sales helped to avert 1.1 million unintended pregnancies, 7,473 maternal deaths, 24,158 child deaths, and 1.2 million unsafe abortions (see table 2 below for health impact). Table 2: Health impact 2019 in East and Southern Africa DKT developed an e-learning module for provider training on comprehensive safe abortion care and over 3,201 health providers (target for 2019 was 175) completed it in 2019 (source appendix 3). DKT also trained 65 "community mobilizers" (target was 24) and 87 Youth Ambassadors (target was 45). DKT also met or exceeded in all countries targets for affordability (where products fall within the .25% of GNP PPP per capita). In DRC, DKT launched an MA combi-pack which was a first for DRC after the government ratified the Maputo Protocol. DKT also expanded reach to 206 government health zones (over 142 from 2018) as a result of the support from Sweden, and DKT’s growth outpaced current contraceptive use estimates. DKT is one of the most important providers of SRH products and services in the country. In Ethiopia, where a large anonymous donor cut DKT’s funding significantly (and eliminated funding for non-governmental organization partners entirely), DKT was unable to continue supplying commodities to partners and the Government. The country’s political and economic fragility also contributed to a challenging work environment, restricting sales and user growth, but DKT still managed to grow private sector social marketing sales by 5% between 2018 and 2019. By year’s end, modern contraceptive prevalence (mCPR) was recorded at 37.8%, towards which DKT’s contributed 25.7 percentage points. Other results of interest could be seen in DKT's leverage of its online platforms, Women First Digital, which in addition to providing vital information on SRHR also provided a space to challenge abortion stigma, reinforce women's rights and spread news about reproductive health and rights successes globally. Examples provided by DKT for Eastern and Southern Africa in 2019 include: - Ending Abortion Stigma: Role of Media - Talking about abortions: how safe2choose shaped the online and offline conversations in 2019 (including at the 2019 Women Deliver conference) - The role of schools in bridging the abortion information gap - To Be Or Not To Be: Abortion in Zambia (note that DKT does not operate in Zambia) - New Landmark Abortion Ruling In Kenya In addition, following close dialogue with Sida and the recommendations from an MTR in 2018, DKT has seen a strengthened regional approach which it acknowledges has improved the programme's ability to deliver results through internal knowledge sharing, partnerships, case-studies on barriers to safe abortion promotion in different country contexts, sustainability and economies of scale. DKT held a pan-Africa meeting for all senior managers in 2019 (inspired by the MTR) which led to a five-year plan for the region as a whole. The sharing of information focused on sustainability, common branding and collaboration and led to increased efficiencies and regional partnerships.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 EAC-sekretariatet has ansökt om stöd för ett integrerat regionalt hälsoprogram under 2016-2020.
Programmets syfte är att, på policynivå, hantera svagheter inom medlemländernas hälsosystem. Om EACs medlemsländer gemensamt och effektivt harmoniserar standarder för SRHR-, mödra-, barn-och HIV/AIDS-hälsotjänster kommer detta att stärka det regional samarbetet inom hälsa. Vidare syftar interventionen till att stärka relevant forskning, innovationer, kunskapsspridning, ledarskap, styrning och ansvarsutkrävande inom regionen. EAC förväntar sig att det långsiktiga resultatet av ett fördjupat samarbete inom ovan nämnda områden kommer att vara att snabbare nå målen om att eliminera den mödra- och barnadödlighet som går att förhindra och att på sikt stoppa AIDS-epidemin.
Projektet har en budget på 45 miljoner kronor över 4,25 år och Sida är den enda givaren. Projektet är en del av EAC-sekretariatets mer övergripande hälsostrategi som omfattar även andra givare. Huvuddelen av projektets kostnader omfattas av löner för anställda vid EAC-sekretariatet samt kostnader för de processer som framtagande av EAC-gemensamma policydokument innebär (möteskostnader, resor m.m).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The EAC secretariat has applied for support to the EAC-Sida integrated health program 2016-2020.
The purpose of the program is to, at a policy level, address weaknesses of member states' health systems. If the member states collectively and effectively harmonize standards for SRHR- maternal-, child and HIV/AIDS health services this will in turn strengthen regional cooperation in health. Furthermore, the program seeks to strengthen relevant research, innovation, knowledge management, leadership, governance and accountability within the region. The EAC expects that the long-term outcome of a deeper collaboration in the abovementioned areas will be that the goals of eliminating preventable maternal- and child mortality and eventually ending the AIDS-epidemic can be reached faster.
The project has a budget of 45 million SEK over 4.25 years and Sida is the sole donor. The project part of the EAC-secretariats more overarching health strategy which includes also other donors. The majority of costs are represented by salaries of project staff at the EAC-secretariat and costs related to development of EAC policies (e.g. workshops, travels, consultancy fees)

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

title.narrative: COVID-19 AECF 2017-22 Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT)
COVID-19 AECF 2017-22 Renewable Energy and Adaptation to Climate Technologies (REACT)

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution consists of support to a Challenge Fund; REACT (Renewable Energy, Adaptation and Climate Change Technology). REACT - sub-Saharan Africa, is administered by Afica Enterprise Challenge Fund Ltd (AECF), a non-profit company with AGRA (African Green Revolution) as the sole owner/member. AGRA is a "“non profit organization registered in Washington State as a public charity”. The contribution includes components in seven of Sweden's cooperation countries and the regional strategy for sub-Saharan Africa.
The objective of REACT is to stimulate small and medium-sized companies, to develop business models, services and products in renewable energy and energy efficiency that improve the lives of the poor. The idea is that companies supported by REACT are prepared to take risks, which they otherwise would not take. The ideas put forward by the companies, are identified through competitions in the respective countries. Applications are assessed on the basis of clear and transparent criteria and in three separate steps - this, to assure an independent and transparent process. REACT also supports capacity development of enterprises in a variety of areas, brokering service for successful companies to access capital for scaling up, learning and advocacy on national and regional issues (laws, rules, licensing, trade barriers etc.).
The decision on the intervention covers five years and amounts to 400 000 000 SEK.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen består av ett stöd till en Challenge Fund; REACT (Renewable Energy, Adaptation and Climate Technology). REACT administreras av Africa Enterprise Challenge Fund Ldt (AECF), med Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa (AGRA) som enda ägare/medlem. AECF är ett icke-vinstdrivande företag och AGRA är en "non profit organization registered in Washington State as a public charity”. AECF är registrerat på Mauritus som bedömts som det afrikanska land som har den mest lämpliga företagslagstiftningen för att kunna bedriva AECF's verksamhet. För att få bedriva verksamhet utanför Mauritius finns bara alternativet "Global Business Licence" enligt gällande lagstiftning.
Insatsen omfattar sju av Sveriges samarbetsländer samt den regionala strategin för Afrika söder om Sahara.
Syftet med REACT är att stimulera små och medelstora företag, att utveckla affärsmodeller, service och produkter inom förnybar energi som förbättrar livet för fattiga. REACT bygger på att företagen med stöd från REACT är beredda att ta risker de annars inte skulle göra. Företagen identifieras via tävlingar i de respektive länderna, där ansökningar bedöms utifrån tydliga och transparenta kriterier. Urvalet görs i tre steg, och med hjälp av olika aktörer för varje steg. Detta för att säkerställa en oberoende och öppen process. I stödet ingår även insatser för kapacitetsutveckling av förtagen inom en rad olika områden, märklarservice för framgångsrika företag att få tillgång till kapital för att utöka sin verksamhet, lärande och påverkansarbete i nationella och regionala frågor (lagar, handelshinder etc.). Totalt ska cirka 324 000 hushåll få förbättrad tillgång till förnybar energi samtidigt som cirka 200 000 ton CO2 utsläpp undviks.
Insatsbeslutet är femårigt och uppgår totalt till 400 MSEK. Av beloppet avsätts 2 MSEK inom den regionala strategin för extern uppföljning och bedömning av resultat samt för att bidra till lärande mellan olika länder.

participating-org.narrative: Investment funds and other collective investment institutions

sector.narrative: Energy generation, renewable sources - multiple technologies

tag.narrative: 17.3 - Mobilisera additionella finansiella resurser till utvecklingsländerna från många olika källor.
17.3 - Mobilize additional financial resources for developing countries from multiple sources.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.
7.2 - By 2030, increase substantially the share of renewable energy in the global energy mix.
7.2 - Till 2030 väsentligen öka andelen förnybar energi i den globala energimixen.
7.3 - By 2030, double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency.
7.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla den globala förbättringstakten vad gäller energieffektivitet.

7.a - By 2030, enhance international cooperation to facilitate access to clean energy research and technology, including renewable energy, energy efficiency and advanced and cleaner fossil-fuel technology, and promote investment in energy infrastructure and clean energy technology.

7.a - Till 2030 stärka det internationella samarbetet för att underlätta tillgång till forskning och teknik inom ren energi, inklusive förnybar energi, energieffektivitet samt avancerad och renare fossilbränslebaserad teknik, samt främja investeringar i energiinfrastruktur och ren energiteknik.

title.narrative: COVID-19 LOGIC - myndighetsinitativ för lokal klimatanpassning
COVID-19 Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)

description.narrative: Project Goal: Improved and inclusive local level planning and a strengthened financing mechanism for community-based climate change adaptation solutions through local governments. Output 1: Strengthened capacity of local governments, households and other local stakeholders to develop local plans that integrate climate change adaptation measures and disaster risk management. Output 2: Established financing mechanism to fund local governments and communities for implementing climate change adaptation measures. Output 3: Experience and evidence inform and contribute to further improvements in policies and practices for UPs and national systems in relation to climate change adaptation.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Programmet strävar efter att minska effekterna av klimatförändringar i Bangladesh. IPCC(International Panel on Climate Change) rankar Bangladesh som det sjätte mest utsatta landet i världen för klimatförändringar och det land som är mest utsatt för höjningen av havsnivån (undantaget små ö-riken). Förändringar av nederbörden förväntas leda till både fler och svårare översvämningar samt till perioder av torka i vissa områden. Inträngning av havsvatten samt fler och kraftigare cykloner ökar risken för förhöjd saltkoncentration i mark, floder och grundvattnet. Bangladesh regering uppskattar att de fem största naturkatastroferna sen 1998 har minskat BNP med 15%. Återkommande katastrofer har störst påverkar på den fattigaste delen av befolkningen och bidrar till en i vissa områden cementerad fattigdomsproblematik.
Bangladesh har varit ett föregångsland när det gällde att ta fram strategiska planer för att möta klimathotet (ex. National Adaptation Plan of Action - NAPA och Bangladesh Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan - BCCSAP) och att utveckla en nationell finansieringsmekanism för klimatanpassning (Bangladesh Climate Change Trust Fund - BCCTF) men trots att lokala initiativ för klimatanpassning identifieras som ett prioriterat område i både BCCSAP och NAPA så har endast en liten del av öronmärkta resursers implementerats av lokala myndigheter. Lokala klimatanpassningsprojekt som genomförs med en förankring hos befolkningen kan med relativt små medel minska utsattheten hos sårbara delar av befolkningen och medför ofta mindre risker än storskaliga infrastruktursatsningar.
UNDP och UNCDF har gemensamt utvecklat programmet (LoGIC) som avser att stärka lokala myndigheters kapacitet att integrera klimatanpassning i lokala utvecklingsplaner, förbättra nationella mekanismer för lokal klimatfinansiering och implementera klimatanpassningsåtgärder som har identifierats i samråd mellan lokala myndigheter och lokalbefolkningen. Civilsamhällets har en viktig funktion när det kommer till att mobilisera lokalbefolkningen och verka för transparens och ansvarsutkrävande gentemot lokal myndigheter och har därför en tydlig roll i programmet.
Programmet pågår under 48 månader och har en budget på c:a USD 20 milj., Sidas bidrag uppgår till 85 milj. kr vilket motsvarar ungefär hälften av programbudgeten och EU har redan beslutat om ett stöd på € 8 miljoner. Programmet är fullfinansierat men möjligheten finns att skala upp programmet om ytterligare givare skulle ansluta. Programmets övergripande mål är att stärka finansieringsmekanismer och planeringsprocesser för att möjliggöra implementering av klimatfinansiering av lokala myndigheter som förväntas att bidra till fattigdomsbekämpning och minskad utsatthet hos den fattigare delen av befolkningen. C:a 60% av budget avser bidrag till lokala myndigheter och bidrag direkt till utsatta hushåll för genomförandet av resilienshöjande åtgärder. Bidragsdelen uppskattas gynna 200 000 utsatt hushåll i 72 Union Parishad, i 7 Distrikt, som har bedömts vara mycket utsatta för klimatförändringar och ha en stor fattigdomsproblematik.
Division of Local Government (LGD) under Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives kommer att ha det övergripande ansvaret för genomförandet av programmet enligt en etablerad samarbetsform mellan UNDP och Bangladsh regering. En styrgrupp för projektet kommer att tillsättas med deltagare från Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief, finansministeriet, miljöministeriet, och andra berörda departement. Strygruppenkommer att ansvara för övergirpande syryning av programmet och godkänna projektplaner. UNDP och UNCDF kommer tillsammans hantera en Project Management Unit bestående av nationell och internationell personal för att stödja LGD i genomförandet av programmet under ledning av en National Project Director.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The project will address climate change impact in Bangladesh. The country is ranked 6th among the 10 countries of the world most affected by climate change and disasters and the country most at risk for sea level rise (with the exeption of small island states). It is experiencing change in rainfall, rise in temperature, and is often battered by extreme weather events like cyclones, floods and rise in sea level which compound into raised salinity of water resources and soil. A government estimate indicates that in five major disasters since 1998, the country suffered a loss of nearly 15% of GDP. These events exacerbate poverty and vulnerability of people on a regular basis.
The Government of Bangladesh already recognises the severity of climate change and therefore, the related concerns are being gradually mainstreamed in the national development policy planning and financing. The Government has formulated a national action plan (BCCSAP) that provides core programme direction. However, this sector is served by a number of sectoral policies which also shape the expenditure pattern in the national budget. While the local government institutions (LGIs) are mandated to implement many actions related to climate effects, these actions need to be included in the local plans as climate proofing initiatives.
The proposed programme will address gaps at local and national levels based on which the results have been designed. At the local level, despite being a repository of local knowledge and information, the LGIs fall short of harnessing the potentials from the local community. The mechanism for formulation of the Local Development Plans (LDP) has scope to engage the poor and vulnerable groups in a participatory way to reflect their climate-related needs and demands. Communities and households face difficulties in securing access to the planning and financing mechanism for sustainable development solutions. On the other hand, the Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) and local institutions who have long been functioning at local level for enhanced participation and accountability also shy off the process owing to lack of appropriate capacity. An in-depth analysis of the potentials and the gaps was carried out to identify the intervention areas at the local level.
The duration of the programme is 4 years, 2016-2020, with a total budget of US$ 20.0 million and a planned contribution of approximately USD 10 million (85 million SEK) by Sida and an already approved contribution of € 8 million by the EU. The project will enhance the capacity of vulnerable communities, local government institutions and civil society organisations for planning and financing climate change adaptation solutions in selected climate vulnerable areas. By achieving the objectives and results, the project will contribute to the reduction of poverty and vulnerability in Bangladesh.
This is expected to to result in: -Strengthened capacity of vulnerable people and local stakeholders for accountable planning and financing on Climate Change Adaptation/Disaster Risk Reduction actions for building resilience. -Enhanced access of LGIs and vulnerable households to climate funds have for climate resilient infrastructures and adaptive livelihoods. -Established evidence based advocacy for a mechanism for financing local resilience.
The programme is designed to benefit roughly 200,000 most vulnerable households in 72 unions in seven districts. The benefits are expected to come out of climate change adaptation actions at various levels, scaled up through local government institutions incorporating high quality accountability and participation of the most vulnerable people.
The Local Government Division (LGD) of the Ministry of Local Government Rural Development and Cooperatives will be the implementing agency and will assume overall responsibility for management and implementation of the project in a manner consistent with GoB and UNDP polices. A Project Steering Committee (PSC) will be formed with the participation of Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief , Ministry of Finance, Ministry Environment and Forest, and other relevant ministries. The PSC will be responsible for consensus management decisions for the project when guidance is required, including approval of project plans and revisions. UNDP and UNCDF will jointly manage a Project Management Unit comprised of national and international staff members to support the LGD to implement the project, under the guidance of National Project Director.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

2.4 - By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

2.4 - Senast 2030 uppnå hållbara system för livsmedelsproduktion samt införa motståndskraftiga jordbruksmetoder som ökar produktiviteten och produktionen, som bidrar till att upprätthålla ekosystemen, som stärker förmågan till anpassning till klimatförändringar, extrema väderförhållanden, torka, översvämning och andra katastrofer och som successivt förbättrar mark- och jordkvaliteten.

5.4 - Erkänna och värdesätta obetalt omsorgs- och hushållsarbete genom att tillhandahålla offentliga tjänster, infrastruktur och socialt skydd samt genom att främja delat ansvar inom hushållet och familjen, i enlighet med vad som är nationellt lämpligt.

5.4 - Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.

9.1 - Bygga ut tillförlitlig, hållbar och motståndskraftig infrastruktur av hög kvalitet, inklusive regional och gränsöverskridande infrastruktur, för att stödja ekonomisk utveckling och människors välbefinnande, med fokus på ekonomiskt överkomlig och rättvis tillgång för alla.

9.1 - Develop quality, reliable, sustainable and resilient infrastructure, including regional and transborder infrastructure, to support economic development and human well-being, with a focus on affordable and equitable access for all.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification

title.narrative: Local Governements Initiative on Climate Change
Local Governements Initiative on Climater Change

description.narrative: This conclusion on performance covers the year 2019 and also covers the entire project implementation to draw a overall conclusion on performance as Embassy is planning for a costed extension of the contribution. This GoB-EU-SIDA-UNDP-UNCDF is a multi-donor joint project in Bangladesh plans to promote local action on climate change adaptation at scale. This project was initially developed as a concept together by EU, SIDA, UNDP and UNCDF during 2014-2016 along with Local Government Division. EU developed the initial action fiche in consultation with UNDP, UNCDF and LGD. The action fiche titled “GCCA+ support for enhancing communities' resilience to climate change and related disasters” was approved in 2015 in European Parliament. In 2015, Sida joined in the design team and collectively developed the project titled “Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)”. In 2016, the project was signed with GoB with the financial support of GoB [BDT. 60,000,000 equivalent to USD 714285], EU [EURO 8,000,000 equivalent to USD 8,968,610], SIDA [SEK 85,000,000 equivalent to USD 9,902,144], UNCDF [USD 200,000] and UNDP [USD 200,000]. This project is implemented by UNDP and UNCDF and executed by Local Government Division. This project was initially designed for 4 years and now based on an independent assessment of EU and success of initial results, the project will be extended for another 30 months including a 6 months closing period. Government of Bangladesh aims to make this project a flagship project in developing a climate finance mechanism/model to deliver climate finance for the most vulnerable for building local resilience and therefore, titled the project as “Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)” following UNDP’s Joint Project Document Framework. This Conclusion on Performance has been prepared based on their annual reports, two field visits conducted and participation in different meetings and informal discussions with GoB, UNDP, UNCDF and Project staff. There has been no mid-term evaluation conducted for this project but end of 2019 EU conducted an assessment of the project. This assessment report also provides a basis for this CoP. With a delayed start, the projects accomplishment was very encouraging during 2018, 2019 and 2020. The project made a good progress towards establishing the approach and mechanisms. Some of the process and mehtodological achievements. Establishing the LoGIC Model as key delivery mechanism: In delivering climate finance to the most vulnerable, LoGIC project has emerged as a system by now. It has evolved as the model for identifying the most vulnerable, be it the household or the local government institutions (Union Parishads) and building resilience of them. Selection of 72 most vulnerable, physically disconnected and hardest-to-reach Union Parishads frequently affected by climate change variabilities and extremes (cyclone, sea level rise, salinity, flood and flash flood) is justified by national vulnerability ranking and hard-to-reach mapping, also acknowledged by the government and the other stakeholders. The rigorous project facilitation for carrying out the technical and participatory Community Risk Assessment (CRA) exercise founded the stone for designing the long-term strategic climate actions for the local government institutions (LGIs). Direct transfer of grants to these most vulnerable institutions for implementing project actions (through the Performance Based Climate Resilience Grants- PBCRG) and individual households (Community Resilience Fund- CRF) made the process roll. The effectiveness of the PBCRG and CRF, in curving down the climate vulnerability of the people in high risk areas, is yet to be measured. The LoGIC project enhanced the financial inclusion of the most vulnerable 17,000 women, who never thought of having access to the formal banking system. It has resulted in enhanced confidence among the women participants expressed, through their empowerment and internalizing meaningful ways in building resilience. The other co-benefit is the economic and social empowerment of the women. Women are not alone while they implement their adaptive livelihood options but are in groups with unified business plans to reduce their investment risks. This has created enthusiasm among the local stakeholders to engage in the process of resilience building. Now, the project needs to measure the impact of the PBCRG and CRF in reducing the climate change induced vulnerability of the most vulnerable people. When the system is established, it is important that the climate change attribution to the model is strengthened and ensure to proof the model in relation to the reduction of vulnerabilities in the next two years, so that it is scalable to more than 200 climate vulnerable UPs by 2023, with support from Green Climate Fund (GCF), Government of Bangladesh (GoB) and other non-vertical development partners. Mainstreaming adaptation (resilience) at the local level: LoGIC, through the CRA process, facilitated the participatory representation of the LGIs and the vulnerable communities. This helped brainstorm and identify their risks, which was prioritized at the planning exercise and incorporated in the long-term strategic plan of the Union Parishads (UPs). While UPs plan on building public goods for climate resilience (Risk Reduction Action Plan or RRAP), the community, on the other hand, plan for their own adaptive livelihood options (HHRRAP) for the same. Out of 72, targeted 71 UPs have received PBCRG grants (USD 1.79M) for implementing 228 climate change adaptation (CCA) schemes from their RRAP to create climate resilient public goods. There is potential for scaling up nature-based solutions with support from other sources such as philanthropists, development agencies, local community etc. to finance resilience and adaptation at the community level. On the other hand, 17,000 households of the community in 1,070 groups (based on interest, convenience, homogeneity choices, geographic proximity and communication) received USD 4.64M (2.88m disbursed in 2019, and 1.76m disbursed in 2018) and came up with 22 types of gender-responsive adaptive livelihood options. Adaptation actions at household level through CRF, who are most vulnerable and often left out from public goods benefits and widening the community scale adaptation micro-projects to reduce the vulnerability to climate change both followed the community risk assessment methodology. The vulnerable households and community within the Local Government (LG) constituencies interact in such a manner that ultimately ensure readiness to tackle climate hazards and strengthens the means for survival of the vulnerable community. However, such links require further strengthening and be informed from science-led predictions and scenarios of climate-induced risks. While, the project is well articulated in terms of participatory CRA, what will be more beneficial for climate change adaptation in this regard is a top-down method blended approach in promoting science-driven, informed participation of community in prioritizing their adaptation options at household and community levels. Potential for scaling-up of climate resilient/adaptive livelihoods: The core process of the selection of vulnerable households include (1) CRA and RRAP, (2) based on CRA, identification of two/three vulnerable wards from each UP, (3) conducting the census in these 147 wards, (4) identifying eligible beneficiaries (46,000) by minimum 0.5 vulnerability scores , (5) selection of relatively most vulnerable (26,000) households, with a primary shortlist (17000) and a waiting list (9000 HHs), (6) run a grievance register and redress mechanism and (7) finalize the 17000 HHs as final beneficiaries for the CRF. 98% of these HHs identified women member of the household as primary participant in the CRF and therefore, 16,660 are women as primary beneficiaries of CRF. These beneficiaries are pursuing 22 different types of climate resilient livelihoods in group enterprises, as a follow-up of the choices of the means of livelihoods and start-up grant support from the Project in two tranches. There are three (3) options to scale-up these livelihoods: (1) reaching to all eligible vulnerable groups (46,000 HHs) with different grants packages or reaching to all most vulnerable people (26,000 HHs) with common grant package; (2) scale-up of the most viable climate resilient livelihood options with formal credit market with higher environmental safeguard (i.e. crab fattening); and (3) facilitate private sector actors and co-design business case for scalable business opportunities on climate resilient means of livelihoods where vulnerable people secured income with backed-up skill training and social guarantee. A few examples include hydroponics, bio-flake, aquaponics, sunflower, crab-fattening, saline tolerant pulse, fruits and oil seeds production. Use of innovation for tracking and measuring adaptation: LoGIC demonstrates a comprehensive approach to ensure climate resilience. To keep records, track and measure adaptation, LoGIC has developed and put in place the state-of-the-art Accounting & Management Information Systems (MIS), Adaptation Tracking and Measuring (ATM) system for the project to make sure all the climate money are spent with rationale, the data are regularly entered and updated in the software which generates reports and tell stories of change in the field. Project’s M&E system inculcates all the information from the software and the database to create reports. Tapping upon innovation towards maximizing results, project has successfully trained 72 Union Parishads (LGI) Secretary on Accounting & MIS software. Field level project staffs have been provided hands-on training on filed-level data entry in changing context, future risks, use of grants etc. in the app-Tab-based ATM software. This approach has started to evolve as a transparent and accountable tool to measure climate change and adaptation data on the ground. Sustainable Development Goals: Progressing towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) has been pressing for more attention towards environmental issues. Of the 17 proposed SDGs, four (4) are related to climate change and environment and LoGIC contributes to or works towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11, 13 and 16, i.e. contributing towards poverty eradiation, gender equality, sustainable communities, reduced inequalities, stronger institutions and climate change, broadly. LoGIC is working towards Goal 13.3, which is aimed to improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning through indicators (13.3.1 and 13.3.2). Likewise, with 13.2, i.e. to integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning. Although LoGIC has been working towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11 and 16, only Goal 13 is included in the Strategic Results Framework. Specific achievements against goals are being studied and will be compiled for reporting. During the period, in early March 2020 a joint field visit was made to the project sites at Barguna district for five days. The joint mission was composed of EU, UNDP, UNCDF, GoB and Embassy of Sweden. Overall the findings were impressive. The third Project Steering Committee meeting took place virtually on 12 August 2020 chaired by the Senior Secretary, Local Government Division, Ministry of Local Government. Where relevant government ministry and departments participated. The meeting agreed and advocated for the top up and 2 years extension (up to 30 June 2023), expressed their commitment by agreeing to add 100 MBDT (about 1.2 MUSD) from GoB. Both EU and Embassy of Sweden participated in the meeting. Some major accomplishments 1. Community Risk Assessment (CRA) completed for 147 words in 72 Unions, 17,000 most vulnerable identified and listed in a through participatory manner. Among them 98% are female 2. Vulnerability identified for 147 words, 3. Climate resilient livelihood identified for 17,000 most vulnerable, transferred 1st tranche of Community Resilience Fund (CRF) through formal banking process. All these very remote area people have their bank account now with a formal bank. 4. Capacity enhancement activities done for all these 17,000 people 5. 243 climate resilient schemes implemented under the Performance Based Climate Resilient Grant (PBCRG) through Union Councils. Capacity enhancement of these Union parishad officials done 6. Information on Covid 19 disseminated to all the communities using different media and community well-being information collected from all the communities 7. 11 issues identified and ready for policy advocacy, so far 1 successful policy advocacy event completed with very good government buy inn.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

COVID-19 Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)

The project will enhance the capacity of vulnerable communities, local government institutions and civil society organisations for planning and financing climate change adaptation solutions in selected climate vulnerable areas. By achieving the objectives and results, the project will contribute to the reduction of poverty and vulnerability in Bangladesh.
This is expected to to result in: -Strengthened capacity of vulnerable people and local stakeholders for accountable planning and financing on Climate Change Adaptation/Disaster Risk Reduction actions for building resilience. -Enhanced access of LGIs and vulnerable households to climate funds have for climate resilient infrastructures and adaptive livelihoods. -Established evidence based advocacy for a mechanism for financing local resilience.
The programme is designed to benefit roughly 200,000 most vulnerable households in 72 unions in seven districts. The benefits are expected to come out of climate change adaptation actions at various levels, scaled up through local government institutions incorporating high quality accountability and participation of the most vulnerable people.
The Local Government Division (LGD) of the Ministry of Local Government Rural Development and Cooperatives will be the implementing agency and will assume overall responsibility for management and implementation of the project in a manner consistent with GoB and UNDP polices. A Project Steering Committee (PSC) will be formed with the participation of Ministry of Planning, Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief , Ministry of Finance, Ministry Environment and Forest, and other relevant ministries. The PSC will be responsible for consensus management decisions for the project when guidance is required, including approval of project plans and revisions. UNDP and UNCDF will jointly manage a Project Management Unit comprised of national and international staff members to support the LGD to implement the project, under the guidance of National Project Director.

title.narrative: Local Governements Initiative on Climate Change
Local Governements Initiative on Climater Change

description.narrative: This conclusion on performance covers the year 2019 and also covers the entire project implementation to draw a overall conclusion on performance as Embassy is planning for a costed extension of the contribution. This GoB-EU-SIDA-UNDP-UNCDF is a multi-donor joint project in Bangladesh plans to promote local action on climate change adaptation at scale. This project was initially developed as a concept together by EU, SIDA, UNDP and UNCDF during 2014-2016 along with Local Government Division. EU developed the initial action fiche in consultation with UNDP, UNCDF and LGD. The action fiche titled “GCCA+ support for enhancing communities' resilience to climate change and related disasters” was approved in 2015 in European Parliament. In 2015, Sida joined in the design team and collectively developed the project titled “Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)”. In 2016, the project was signed with GoB with the financial support of GoB [BDT. 60,000,000 equivalent to USD 714285], EU [EURO 8,000,000 equivalent to USD 8,968,610], SIDA [SEK 85,000,000 equivalent to USD 9,902,144], UNCDF [USD 200,000] and UNDP [USD 200,000]. This project is implemented by UNDP and UNCDF and executed by Local Government Division. This project was initially designed for 4 years and now based on an independent assessment of EU and success of initial results, the project will be extended for another 30 months including a 6 months closing period. Government of Bangladesh aims to make this project a flagship project in developing a climate finance mechanism/model to deliver climate finance for the most vulnerable for building local resilience and therefore, titled the project as “Local Government Initiative on Climate Change (LoGIC)” following UNDP’s Joint Project Document Framework. This Conclusion on Performance has been prepared based on their annual reports, two field visits conducted and participation in different meetings and informal discussions with GoB, UNDP, UNCDF and Project staff. There has been no mid-term evaluation conducted for this project but end of 2019 EU conducted an assessment of the project. This assessment report also provides a basis for this CoP. With a delayed start, the projects accomplishment was very encouraging during 2018, 2019 and 2020. The project made a good progress towards establishing the approach and mechanisms. Some of the process and mehtodological achievements. Establishing the LoGIC Model as key delivery mechanism: In delivering climate finance to the most vulnerable, LoGIC project has emerged as a system by now. It has evolved as the model for identifying the most vulnerable, be it the household or the local government institutions (Union Parishads) and building resilience of them. Selection of 72 most vulnerable, physically disconnected and hardest-to-reach Union Parishads frequently affected by climate change variabilities and extremes (cyclone, sea level rise, salinity, flood and flash flood) is justified by national vulnerability ranking and hard-to-reach mapping, also acknowledged by the government and the other stakeholders. The rigorous project facilitation for carrying out the technical and participatory Community Risk Assessment (CRA) exercise founded the stone for designing the long-term strategic climate actions for the local government institutions (LGIs). Direct transfer of grants to these most vulnerable institutions for implementing project actions (through the Performance Based Climate Resilience Grants- PBCRG) and individual households (Community Resilience Fund- CRF) made the process roll. The effectiveness of the PBCRG and CRF, in curving down the climate vulnerability of the people in high risk areas, is yet to be measured. The LoGIC project enhanced the financial inclusion of the most vulnerable 17,000 women, who never thought of having access to the formal banking system. It has resulted in enhanced confidence among the women participants expressed, through their empowerment and internalizing meaningful ways in building resilience. The other co-benefit is the economic and social empowerment of the women. Women are not alone while they implement their adaptive livelihood options but are in groups with unified business plans to reduce their investment risks. This has created enthusiasm among the local stakeholders to engage in the process of resilience building. Now, the project needs to measure the impact of the PBCRG and CRF in reducing the climate change induced vulnerability of the most vulnerable people. When the system is established, it is important that the climate change attribution to the model is strengthened and ensure to proof the model in relation to the reduction of vulnerabilities in the next two years, so that it is scalable to more than 200 climate vulnerable UPs by 2023, with support from Green Climate Fund (GCF), Government of Bangladesh (GoB) and other non-vertical development partners. Mainstreaming adaptation (resilience) at the local level: LoGIC, through the CRA process, facilitated the participatory representation of the LGIs and the vulnerable communities. This helped brainstorm and identify their risks, which was prioritized at the planning exercise and incorporated in the long-term strategic plan of the Union Parishads (UPs). While UPs plan on building public goods for climate resilience (Risk Reduction Action Plan or RRAP), the community, on the other hand, plan for their own adaptive livelihood options (HHRRAP) for the same. Out of 72, targeted 71 UPs have received PBCRG grants (USD 1.79M) for implementing 228 climate change adaptation (CCA) schemes from their RRAP to create climate resilient public goods. There is potential for scaling up nature-based solutions with support from other sources such as philanthropists, development agencies, local community etc. to finance resilience and adaptation at the community level. On the other hand, 17,000 households of the community in 1,070 groups (based on interest, convenience, homogeneity choices, geographic proximity and communication) received USD 4.64M (2.88m disbursed in 2019, and 1.76m disbursed in 2018) and came up with 22 types of gender-responsive adaptive livelihood options. Adaptation actions at household level through CRF, who are most vulnerable and often left out from public goods benefits and widening the community scale adaptation micro-projects to reduce the vulnerability to climate change both followed the community risk assessment methodology. The vulnerable households and community within the Local Government (LG) constituencies interact in such a manner that ultimately ensure readiness to tackle climate hazards and strengthens the means for survival of the vulnerable community. However, such links require further strengthening and be informed from science-led predictions and scenarios of climate-induced risks. While, the project is well articulated in terms of participatory CRA, what will be more beneficial for climate change adaptation in this regard is a top-down method blended approach in promoting science-driven, informed participation of community in prioritizing their adaptation options at household and community levels. Potential for scaling-up of climate resilient/adaptive livelihoods: The core process of the selection of vulnerable households include (1) CRA and RRAP, (2) based on CRA, identification of two/three vulnerable wards from each UP, (3) conducting the census in these 147 wards, (4) identifying eligible beneficiaries (46,000) by minimum 0.5 vulnerability scores , (5) selection of relatively most vulnerable (26,000) households, with a primary shortlist (17000) and a waiting list (9000 HHs), (6) run a grievance register and redress mechanism and (7) finalize the 17000 HHs as final beneficiaries for the CRF. 98% of these HHs identified women member of the household as primary participant in the CRF and therefore, 16,660 are women as primary beneficiaries of CRF. These beneficiaries are pursuing 22 different types of climate resilient livelihoods in group enterprises, as a follow-up of the choices of the means of livelihoods and start-up grant support from the Project in two tranches. There are three (3) options to scale-up these livelihoods: (1) reaching to all eligible vulnerable groups (46,000 HHs) with different grants packages or reaching to all most vulnerable people (26,000 HHs) with common grant package; (2) scale-up of the most viable climate resilient livelihood options with formal credit market with higher environmental safeguard (i.e. crab fattening); and (3) facilitate private sector actors and co-design business case for scalable business opportunities on climate resilient means of livelihoods where vulnerable people secured income with backed-up skill training and social guarantee. A few examples include hydroponics, bio-flake, aquaponics, sunflower, crab-fattening, saline tolerant pulse, fruits and oil seeds production. Use of innovation for tracking and measuring adaptation: LoGIC demonstrates a comprehensive approach to ensure climate resilience. To keep records, track and measure adaptation, LoGIC has developed and put in place the state-of-the-art Accounting & Management Information Systems (MIS), Adaptation Tracking and Measuring (ATM) system for the project to make sure all the climate money are spent with rationale, the data are regularly entered and updated in the software which generates reports and tell stories of change in the field. Project’s M&E system inculcates all the information from the software and the database to create reports. Tapping upon innovation towards maximizing results, project has successfully trained 72 Union Parishads (LGI) Secretary on Accounting & MIS software. Field level project staffs have been provided hands-on training on filed-level data entry in changing context, future risks, use of grants etc. in the app-Tab-based ATM software. This approach has started to evolve as a transparent and accountable tool to measure climate change and adaptation data on the ground. Sustainable Development Goals: Progressing towards the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the Government of Bangladesh (GoB) has been pressing for more attention towards environmental issues. Of the 17 proposed SDGs, four (4) are related to climate change and environment and LoGIC contributes to or works towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11, 13 and 16, i.e. contributing towards poverty eradiation, gender equality, sustainable communities, reduced inequalities, stronger institutions and climate change, broadly. LoGIC is working towards Goal 13.3, which is aimed to improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning through indicators (13.3.1 and 13.3.2). Likewise, with 13.2, i.e. to integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning. Although LoGIC has been working towards Goals 1, 5, 10, 11 and 16, only Goal 13 is included in the Strategic Results Framework. Specific achievements against goals are being studied and will be compiled for reporting. During the period, in early March 2020 a joint field visit was made to the project sites at Barguna district for five days. The joint mission was composed of EU, UNDP, UNCDF, GoB and Embassy of Sweden. Overall the findings were impressive. The third Project Steering Committee meeting took place virtually on 12 August 2020 chaired by the Senior Secretary, Local Government Division, Ministry of Local Government. Where relevant government ministry and departments participated. The meeting agreed and advocated for the top up and 2 years extension (up to 30 June 2023), expressed their commitment by agreeing to add 100 MBDT (about 1.2 MUSD) from GoB. Both EU and Embassy of Sweden participated in the meeting. Some major accomplishments 1. Community Risk Assessment (CRA) completed for 147 words in 72 Unions, 17,000 most vulnerable identified and listed in a through participatory manner. Among them 98% are female 2. Vulnerability identified for 147 words, 3. Climate resilient livelihood identified for 17,000 most vulnerable, transferred 1st tranche of Community Resilience Fund (CRF) through formal banking process. All these very remote area people have their bank account now with a formal bank. 4. Capacity enhancement activities done for all these 17,000 people 5. 243 climate resilient schemes implemented under the Performance Based Climate Resilient Grant (PBCRG) through Union Councils. Capacity enhancement of these Union parishad officials done 6. Information on Covid 19 disseminated to all the communities using different media and community well-being information collected from all the communities 7. 11 issues identified and ready for policy advocacy, so far 1 successful policy advocacy event completed with very good government buy inn.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen utgörs av ett femårigt projekt inom området medieutveckling och mänskliga rättigheter vilket skall genomföras av Fojo Media Institute i samarbete med en lokal partner, Management and Resources Development Initiative (MRDI). Projektet har namnet Improving Investigative Journalism, Bangladesh. Verksamhet omfattar ett flertal komponenter som syftar till kapacitetsutveckling av medieorganisationer och individer verksamma inom media, nätverksbyggande, sektorstärkande och särskilda insatser på området säkerhet för medieaktörer.
Särskilt tematiskt fokus inom insatsen ligger på för Sida prioriterade frågor inom god samhällsstyrning, mänskliga rättigheter, arbetsrättsfrågor, jämställdhet och miljö och klimat.
Det är den Sidas bedömning att FOJO Media Institute har en unik ställning inom svenskt utvecklingssamarbete på området medieutveckling, har visat goda resultat i tidigare projekt av liknande natur i andra länder och har goda förutsättningar att nå uppställda resultat även i detta projekt i Bangladesh.
Insatsen i fråga är helt i linje med regeringens Strategi för Utvecklingssamarbetet med Bangladesh 2014-2020.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The development intervention consists of a five-year project in the field of media development and human rights, which will be implemented by the FOJO Media Institute in cooperation with a local partner, the Management and Resources Development Initiative (MRDI). The project is called Improving Investigative Journalism, Bangladesh. Operations comprise a number of components that aim at capacity development of media organizations and individuals active in the media, networking, sectoral strengthening and special efforts in the field of media security.
Special thematic focus within the initiative lies in Sida's priority issues in good governance, human rights, labor law, gender equality, environment and climate.
It is Sida's opinion that the FOJO Media Institute has a unique position in Swedish development cooperation in the field of media development, has shown good results in previous projects of similar nature in other countries and has good prospects for achieving results also in this project in Bangladesh.
The initiative in question is fully in line with the Government's Development Cooperation Strategy with Bangladesh 2014-2020.

The overarching development objective for the intervention is to: "Contribute to improving the conditions for people to raise themselves out of poverty, strengthening democracy, respect for human rights and gender equality, and to contribute to sustainable development." The specific objective of the intervention is stated as “Media in Bangladesh contributes to strengthened democracy and gender equality, greater respect for human rights and freedom from oppression.”To this Objective, Fojo links three outcomes – two immediate and one intermediate. 1) The first immediate outcome is linked to the strengthening of individual media outlets and journalists in their production of qualitative journalism: "Targeted media houses and news providers identify, research and produce high quality investigative journalism, particularly on gender equality, labour rights, corruption and environmental impact and climate change". 2) The second immediate outcome is focused on strengthening the media sector as a whole, to enable a conducive environment for this production: "Targeted partners in the media sector collaborate to create a conducive environment for investigative journalism, particularly on gender equality, labour rights, corruption and environmental impact and climate change". The theory of change links the outcomes to the overarching and the specific objective through the following logic: "The stories published result in an invigorated debate on issues related to gender equality, labour rights, corruption and environmental impact and climate change as well as other issues vital for the development of democracy, gender equality and respect for human rights. The debate contributes to strengthened democracy and gender equality, greater respect for human rights and freedom from oppression. Strengthened democracy and gender equality, greater respect for human rights and freedom from oppression contributes to improving the conditions for people to raise themselves out of poverty in a better environment.”

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.

17.9 - Enhance international support for implementing effective and targeted capacity-building in developing countries to support national plans to implement all the Sustainable Development Goals, including through North-South, South-South and triangular cooperation.

17.9 - Öka det internationella stödet för genomförande av effektiv och riktad kapacitetsuppbyggnad i utvecklingsländerna till stöd för nationella planer för att genomföra alla målen för hållbar utveckling, inklusive genom samarbete nord–syd och syd–syd samt trepartssamarbete.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative: The project has achieved important results since the start of the project and in the reporting period despite increasing contextual challenges. The gradually worsening situation with regard to freedom of speech and freedom of the press continued in the reporting period. The outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic in Bangladesh in March 2020 brought additional challenges for media outlets and journalists, as revenues sharply declined and journalists on the frontline were exposed to health and safety related risks. The number of journalists, bloggers, human rights activists and those critisizing the Government increased in the wake of the Covid-19 crisis. The Covid-19 crisis also had direct implications for the implemenation of the project. While the project quickly adapted by eg. adopting digital tools for trainings and capacity building, some activites were not possible to carry out and had to be shifted partly or fully to year 5. Some examples of results achieved and reported in the annual report include: - The project directly benefitted 46% more journalists with access to knowledge, techniques and tools to produce twice as many investigations than in the previous year. - Production of stories supported through the project significantly increased in the reporting period. Targeted media houses and journalists produced a total of 142 stories, which corresonds to a 364 % increase compared to the previous year. Among the stories produced, 47% were on corruption, 43% on environment and climate change, 3% on gender and the remaining on crime. 55 fact check stories were produced, 64 % of these on crime or Covid-19. - In response to Covid-19, the project quickly adapted and organized a series of webinars, a Covid-19 reporting handbook and collaborated with sector-wide media associations to support journalists covering the pandemic, while ensuring their own safety. Each webinar and safety training was aimed at specific target groups such as media leaders, camera men, women journalists, field reporters, etc. - The project reached 880 direct beneficiaries in the reporting period. Out of the total number of beneficiaries, 42% received knowledge on how to stay safe in the pandemic and how to investigate it. - Advocacy programmes organised, reached more than 35 000 through social media, and the knowledge contents created were read by hundreds of thousands, both in Bangladesh and around the world.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
