Decision 51110126 Kenya Social Protection UNICEF & WFP
Decision Amendment Kenya social protection UNICEF & WFP (2019)
Decision Kenya Social Protection UNICEF & WFP

description.narrative: Social Protection Government of Kenya (GoK) is gradually shifting towards universal approaches in social protection and UNICEF and WFP are strongly supporting this agenda with technical, financial, and advocacy support. The introduction of a Universal Child Benefit (UCB) in Kenya is a key goal, stated in both the revised policy and the investment plan, and will be a breakthrough for the sector and for the wellbeing of children in Kenya. UNICEF and WFP provided technical and financial support to Ministry of Labour and Social Protection (MLSP) to develop three key strategic documents for the social protection sector. These are an overarching Social Protection Policy, a 10-year Investment Plan and a 5-year Social Protection Strategy. These documents are expected to work synergistically and provide a blueprint to expand and strengthen the sector in the next years The Government of Kenya has developed regulations for the establishment of a Social Assistance Fund within the Public Finance Management Act (2012), with financial and technical support from WFP and UNICEF. Regulations were drafted in August 2019 by a taskforce led by the National Treasury and then tabled before Parliament for a first reading of the Social Assistance Bill 2020. The establishment of a Social Assistance Fund will be a major milestone for the social protection sector in Kenya in terms of enabling enhanced coverage and provision of timely, predictable and adequate benefits to beneficiaries, as well as clear grievances and case management mechanisms The Baseline Survey Report of Kenya’s Inua Jamii 70 Years and Above Cash Transfer Programme was developed by the Government of Kenya with technical and financial support of ILO, UNICEF and WFP, and officially launched on 1st October 2020 on the International Day of Older Persons. This baseline report provides a vital reference point for future impact evaluations of universal pensions and their subsequent effects on human well-being, including poverty alleviation, food and nutrition security Under the overall leadership of WFP, the two partners supported the continued development and enhancement of existing Management Information Systems (MISs), e.g. to accommodate cash plus and shock-responsive models within the framework of the National Safety Net Programme. At the same time, UNICEF and WFP continued to support the strengthening and expansion of the Single Registry, making sure all existing Social Protection MISs are linked to the registry, including linkages to complementary social protection programmes through data-sharing mechanisms. This allows county governments, non-governmental organizations, UN agencies, and other partners who provide complementary services to existing Inua Jamii beneficiaries and other social protection interventions to share data and information for enhanced coordination and integration. UNICEF continued to support the development of an evaluation plan and a set of tailored monitoring tools for monthly, quarterly and annual reporting on the Social Protection sector. The Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework 2018-2022 was initially developed in 2018 based on the 2011 Policy, and it has been updated to align it with the policy as revised in 2019 WFP and UNICEF supported the MLSP to develop, institutionalize and roll out a Learning and Development Curriculum for Social Protection. The curriculum was based on the most critical capacity development needs of the national and county governments as identified by MLSP. In the area of disability-inclusive Social Protection, UNICEF supported three Government Officers to participate in a short-course of University Bonn as part of the UNPRPD-ILO-UNICEF Inclusive Social Protection Initiative, which was conducted from June to November 2020. During the reporting period, WFP and UNICEF initiated a partnership with the National Hospital Insurance Fund (NHIF) to coordinate and support activities linking health and social protection and ultimately aim at mainstreaming NHIF membership into the National Safety Net Programme Child Protection UNICEF continued to work with National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)- Special Taskforce on Children Matters and the National Council for Children Services to advocate for the Children Bill to advance through the various stages of the legislative process to ensure its speedy enactment by parliament. The Bill is currently with the Cabinet. In 2020, UNICEF supported the government to complete three important studies that will inform the policy and programme decisions for strengthening child protection systems and services. The 2018 Census on Street Families and the 2019 Survey on Violence against children were completed and launched by Cabinet Secretary of the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection. The Survey was launched together with the National Prevention and Response Plan to address Violence against Children (VaC). On birth registration, UNICEF supported the Civil Registration Services (CRS) to establish a multi-sectoral technical working group which includes all UN agencies supporting with birth registration and also to facilitate with access to virtual platform (zoom-link) to conduct regular meetings On improved access to justice for children, UNICEF planned to support some of the ‘Big 7’ recommendations highlighted in the Status Report on Children in the Justice System (2019) which UNICEF had provided financial support for its preparation by national Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)-Special Taskforce on Children Matters. This was however was not possible with the onset of COVID-19. However, towards the end of 2020, when the situation normalized, UNICEF supported the NCAJ by seconding a child protection officer (National UN Volunteer) to support in the implementation of the Big 7 recommendations. UNICEF is supporting cash plus approaches in three key areas: maternal, newborn and child health (MCNH), nutrition, and energy. Moreover, an additional cash plus pilot currently under design in Mombasa includes a strong focus on disability-inclusive education, alongside a MNCH component. As part of the Covid-19 response, UNICEF Child and Social Protection sections initiated a joint, integrated activity to support children released from residential institutions (both statutory and charitable institution) after their partial closure due to Covid-19 At the same time, the first pilot phase of the Cash Plus Energy programme Mwangaza Mashinani in Garissa and Kilifi counties was successfully concluded, with the last payments going out in July 2020, despite the challenges posed by Covid-19. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK to establish a Technical Working Group (TWG) and a National Steering Committee at national level that include all relevant social protection stakeholders. Moreover, in June 2020, UNICEF and WFP founded the Sectoral Group for Social Protection (SGSP) to gather development partners working in the sector in Kenya. The Sectoral Group aims to ensure that development partners in the social protection sector provide support to the government in a predictable and coordinated manner that aligns with the latter’s strategic development priorities. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK in establishing a Community of Practice (CoP) for Social Protection. Led by the Directorate for Social Protection, the CoP was launched in October 2020 with a high-level event (held virtually, with few government representatives participating in person) and has hosted two webinars so far (Social Protection Adaptations to COVID-19; Launch of the Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework), with a third one being planned at the moment. Social Protection and Child Protection Response to Covid-19 Activities during the reporting period were deeply affected by the Covid-19 outbreak and the resulting movement restrictions. USD 733,293 of UNICEF’s funds from this grant were reprogrammed towards the Covid-19 response and are being used to support the upcoming UCB pilot. Similarly, WFP launched an emergency cash assistance programme for urban vulnerable groups in Mombasa and Nairobi where each targeted household received KES. 4000 per month for a period of three and four months respectively (the cash transfer funds were from USAID and Finland but with the use the system supported by Sida funds). To improve on the national system within the context of a complex emergency, USD 53,000 of this grant was set aside to facilitate an assessment that seeks to explore the social and economic impacts of COVID and how the existing social protection system has enhanced resilience at household level. The findings of this study will be disseminated in high level advocacy events with policy makers. Overall, to support effective coordination and appropriate response to the affected communities, WFP developed an Application Programming Interface (API) for the Enhanced Single Registry (ESR). This system provides an interface that allows a program to communicate with other programs, running in the same environment. Accordingly, different agencies and institutions with long-term and emergency specific social assistance interventions are able to link and use the ESR which in turn enhances greater collaboration among partners, effective use of available resources, increases transparency while supporting appropriate decision making based on available data. Building on government social and child protection systems, UNICEF is targeting families with children returned home from Charitable Children’s Institutions (CCIs) and Statutory Children’s Institutions (SCIs) during the Covid-19 outbreak in Garissa, Kilifi, Kisumu Nairobi and Turkana. The intervention, developed and implemented in close collaboration with MLSP at national and county level, provides a monthly cash transfer of Kes 2,000 for six months to support these families, using the existing government mechanism within MLSP, including identification and registration mechanism, as well as NSNP transfer value, payment cycles and payment modalities. Some tweaks to NSNP system were implemented to cater for the emergency nature of the intervention (e.g. the transfer value was adjusted to KES 2000 per child in for the first three months and reverted to the NSNP rate of KES 2000 per household for the remaining 3 months; use of M-Pesa as payment modality instead of banks; use of Kobo tools and Child Protection Information System (CPIMS) to register children and caregivers; support from social workers in the institutions. In light of Covid-19, the urgent need for support of children and adolescents in street situations became more evident. As a result, UNICEF is currently commissioning a study to assess the situation and needs of children and adolescents in street situations to hence design of a tailored social and child protection emergency intervention to support children and adolescent in street situations in light of the Covid-19 pandemic with cash and an ad-hoc package of services Within the framework of the activities to introduce a long-term nation-wide Universal Child Benefit (UCB), UNICEF and WFP, in close collaboration with MSLP, analyzed the possibility of introducing a temporary UCB to cushion vulnerable households during Covid-19. This is in line with the global surge of interest towards social protection, and particularly universal or quasi-universal approaches, as a tool to not only address long-term vulnerabilities but also protect people during crises. A concept note on the rationale for the roll-out of a temporary UCB was developed through intense discussion with the government and other UN agencies in mid-2020, and UNICEF and WFP are now working on the design and preparatory activities for the roll-out a pilot UCB in selected areas During the onset of COVID-19 and the crisis that followed the containment measures, the child protection was unfortunately not classified as one of the essential services by government. All officers from Department of Children services and National Council of Children Services worked from home. UNICEF supported both NCCS and Department of Children Services (DCS) to coordinate partners to continue supporting required services as well as emerging concerns from COVID-19 situation. UNICEF supported the development and provision of virtual training to 450 children officers and staff from NGOs through a series of 12 webinars. The trainings focused on child protection and mental health and psychosocial effects of COVID-19 on children, parents and their communities and required response. UNICEF provided financial and technical support to increase the number of telephone counsellors at the child helpline 116 services from 15 to 30 counsellors, configured the child line laptops for remote access and procured additional 8 laptops to improve the performance of Childline during the Covid-19 period. The staff at child helpline were provided with virtual training related to facts about Covid-19, related messages, referral service points and sensitized on mental health and psychosocial support during the Covid-19 period. Overall, between January and December 2020, a total of 92,672 (46,245 girls, 44,465 boys and 1,962 gender undisclosed) children, parents and caregivers were reached with mental health and psychosocial support services across Kenya with various UNICEF supported interventions including the CPVs support, child helpline and support within the Kakuma and Dadaab Refugee Camps. SIDA funds were also used to procure some personal protective equipment (PPE) that were distributed to CCIs and SCIs that requested for support through the MLSP, to NGOs working in the refugee camps and also to officers of Civil Registration Officers who had to continue with issuance of birth certificates. The PPEs included water jerricans, soap, and masks.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Kenya Social Protection Support - UNICEF & WFP
Kenya Social Protection Support - UNICEF & WFP

description.narrative:
FN:s WFP och UNICEF har lämnat ett gemensamt programförslag till Sverige gällande ett stöd på totalt 78 MSEK till den kenyanska staten. Syftet är att bygga upp ett system som ger rättvis tillgång till sociala skyddssystem och barnskyddssystem.
Den långsiktiga visionen är ett socialt skyddssystem som är integrerat, tar hänsyn till barn och fungerar i nödsituationer, som ger förmånstagarna tillgång till ett grundläggande socialt skydd samt att ett ökat antal män, kvinnor, pojkar och flickor från de fattigaste och mest sårbara hushållen får tillgång till detta.
Förslaget går ut på att ge teknisk assistans vid revidering, utveckling och införande av lagar, rutiner och strategier gällande socialt skydd och barnskydd, att förstärka system, öka kapaciteten och effektiviteten i de sociala skyddsprogrammen samt stärka koordinationen mellan olika sektioner på nationell och regional nivå. Det föreslagna programmet kommer att utgå från befintliga modeller och fokusera på att koppla kontantöverföringsmottagare till barnskyddstjänster med hjälp av integrerad ärendehantering.
Det kommer att vara en insats med två avtal (ett med WFP och ett med UNICEF). Planen är att bedömningar, revisioner, fältuppdrag och utvärderingar ska utföras gemensamt. Sverige har de senaste tre åren arbetat med att stödja sociala skyddssystem i Kenya tillsammans med WFP samt under de 14 senaste åren tillsammans med UNICEF arbetat med socialt skydd, barnskydd och utveckling och genomförande av olika sorters sociala skyddsmekanismer.
Det nuvarande förslaget är 78 MSEK under tre år, fördelade enligt följande – UNICEF 66 MSEK och WFP 34 MSEK. Eftersom det inte bildats någon ny regering i Sverige efter valet och biståndsbudgeten för 2019 ännu inte är beslutad kommer ambassaden att teckna ettåriga avtal på totalt 40 MSEK med UNICEF (30 MSEK) och WFP (10 MSEK) för 2018. Om den nya regeringen anslår mer medel kan Sverige besluta att avsätta mer medel och förlänga aktivitetsperioden.

Support to UNICEF/WFP Social Protection in Kenya
UN WFP and UNICEF have submitted a joint programme proposal to Sweden for support to the Government of Kenya to provide assistance towards equitable access to social and child protection for a total of 78 MSEK.
The long-term vision for change is an integrated, child-sensitive and shock-responsive social protection system that links beneficiaries to basic social services, so as to benefit an increased number of men, women, boys and girls; from the poorest and most vulnerable households.
The proposal aims at i) Support Technical Assistance to review, develop and implement legislation, processes and strategies on Social Protection(SP) and Child Protection (CP), systems strengthening, ii) Enhanced capacity and increased efficiencies in the delivery of social protection programmes and to iii) strengthen intersectoral coordination linkages at the national and county level.
The proposed programme will use already existing models and focus on linking cash transfers beneficiaries to child protection services through integrated case management.
There will be one contribution with two agreements (one with WFP and another with UNICEF). It is expected that the appraisal, reviews, field missions and evaluations will be conducted jointly. SE in Kenya has worked previously with support to social protection via both WFP over the last 3 years and UNICEF to both social and child protection over the last 14 years in the development and implementation of different aspects of social protection.
The current assessment is for 78MSEK for 3 years distributed as follows - UNICEF 66MSEK and WFP 34MSEK. However, due to the fact that currently there is no government formed in Sweden and the aid budget for 2019 is not yet decided, the Embassy will sign with both UNICEF and WFP a one year agreement in 2018 for a total of 40 MSEK - 30MSEK for UNICEF and 10MSEK for WFP. However, should funds be available after the government appropriation, Sweden can then take a decision to avail more funds and prolong the activity period.

The proposed programme has an overall goal to ensure that people in Kenya, especially the most vulnerable groups, live in dignity, are free from poverty, hunger, violence, abuse and exploitation, to be able to exploit their full human capabilities and contribute to the national development. The original assessment of the objectives and contribution's theory of change still stands save for the current Covid-19 pandemic which has brought in positive aspects of testing the shock-responsiveness of the Social Protection system in Kenya and how to enhance the system to address varying types of shocks which will affect Kenya in future.

The proposed programme has an overall goal to ensure that people in Kenya, especially the most vulnerable groups, live in dignity, are free from poverty, hunger, violence, abuse and exploitation, to be able to exploit their full human capabilities and contribute to the national development. The original assessment of the objectives and contribution's theory of change still stands save for the current Covid-19 pandemic which has brought in positive aspects of testing the shock-responsiveness of the Social Protection system in Kenya and how to enhance the system to address varying types of shocks which will affect Kenya in future.

title.narrative: Agreement 51110126 Kenya Social Protection UNICEF & WFP
Agreement 2nd amendment WFP strengthening child and social protection system
Agreement UNICEF Strengthening child and social protection
Agreement amendment UNICEF Strengthening Child and social protection
Agreement amendment no-cost UNICEF Strengthening Child and social protection
Decision 51110126 Kenya Social Protection UNICEF & WFP
Decision Amendment Kenya social protection UNICEF & WFP (2019)
Decision Kenya Social Protection UNICEF & WFP

description.narrative: Social Protection Government of Kenya (GoK) is gradually shifting towards universal approaches in social protection and UNICEF and WFP are strongly supporting this agenda with technical, financial, and advocacy support. The introduction of a Universal Child Benefit (UCB) in Kenya is a key goal, stated in both the revised policy and the investment plan, and will be a breakthrough for the sector and for the wellbeing of children in Kenya. UNICEF and WFP provided technical and financial support to Ministry of Labour and Social Protection (MLSP) to develop three key strategic documents for the social protection sector. These are an overarching Social Protection Policy, a 10-year Investment Plan and a 5-year Social Protection Strategy. These documents are expected to work synergistically and provide a blueprint to expand and strengthen the sector in the next years The Government of Kenya has developed regulations for the establishment of a Social Assistance Fund within the Public Finance Management Act (2012), with financial and technical support from WFP and UNICEF. Regulations were drafted in August 2019 by a taskforce led by the National Treasury and then tabled before Parliament for a first reading of the Social Assistance Bill 2020. The establishment of a Social Assistance Fund will be a major milestone for the social protection sector in Kenya in terms of enabling enhanced coverage and provision of timely, predictable and adequate benefits to beneficiaries, as well as clear grievances and case management mechanisms The Baseline Survey Report of Kenya’s Inua Jamii 70 Years and Above Cash Transfer Programme was developed by the Government of Kenya with technical and financial support of ILO, UNICEF and WFP, and officially launched on 1st October 2020 on the International Day of Older Persons. This baseline report provides a vital reference point for future impact evaluations of universal pensions and their subsequent effects on human well-being, including poverty alleviation, food and nutrition security Under the overall leadership of WFP, the two partners supported the continued development and enhancement of existing Management Information Systems (MISs), e.g. to accommodate cash plus and shock-responsive models within the framework of the National Safety Net Programme. At the same time, UNICEF and WFP continued to support the strengthening and expansion of the Single Registry, making sure all existing Social Protection MISs are linked to the registry, including linkages to complementary social protection programmes through data-sharing mechanisms. This allows county governments, non-governmental organizations, UN agencies, and other partners who provide complementary services to existing Inua Jamii beneficiaries and other social protection interventions to share data and information for enhanced coordination and integration. UNICEF continued to support the development of an evaluation plan and a set of tailored monitoring tools for monthly, quarterly and annual reporting on the Social Protection sector. The Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework 2018-2022 was initially developed in 2018 based on the 2011 Policy, and it has been updated to align it with the policy as revised in 2019 WFP and UNICEF supported the MLSP to develop, institutionalize and roll out a Learning and Development Curriculum for Social Protection. The curriculum was based on the most critical capacity development needs of the national and county governments as identified by MLSP. In the area of disability-inclusive Social Protection, UNICEF supported three Government Officers to participate in a short-course of University Bonn as part of the UNPRPD-ILO-UNICEF Inclusive Social Protection Initiative, which was conducted from June to November 2020. During the reporting period, WFP and UNICEF initiated a partnership with the National Hospital Insurance Fund (NHIF) to coordinate and support activities linking health and social protection and ultimately aim at mainstreaming NHIF membership into the National Safety Net Programme Child Protection UNICEF continued to work with National Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)- Special Taskforce on Children Matters and the National Council for Children Services to advocate for the Children Bill to advance through the various stages of the legislative process to ensure its speedy enactment by parliament. The Bill is currently with the Cabinet. In 2020, UNICEF supported the government to complete three important studies that will inform the policy and programme decisions for strengthening child protection systems and services. The 2018 Census on Street Families and the 2019 Survey on Violence against children were completed and launched by Cabinet Secretary of the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection. The Survey was launched together with the National Prevention and Response Plan to address Violence against Children (VaC). On birth registration, UNICEF supported the Civil Registration Services (CRS) to establish a multi-sectoral technical working group which includes all UN agencies supporting with birth registration and also to facilitate with access to virtual platform (zoom-link) to conduct regular meetings On improved access to justice for children, UNICEF planned to support some of the ‘Big 7’ recommendations highlighted in the Status Report on Children in the Justice System (2019) which UNICEF had provided financial support for its preparation by national Council on Administration of Justice (NCAJ)-Special Taskforce on Children Matters. This was however was not possible with the onset of COVID-19. However, towards the end of 2020, when the situation normalized, UNICEF supported the NCAJ by seconding a child protection officer (National UN Volunteer) to support in the implementation of the Big 7 recommendations. UNICEF is supporting cash plus approaches in three key areas: maternal, newborn and child health (MCNH), nutrition, and energy. Moreover, an additional cash plus pilot currently under design in Mombasa includes a strong focus on disability-inclusive education, alongside a MNCH component. As part of the Covid-19 response, UNICEF Child and Social Protection sections initiated a joint, integrated activity to support children released from residential institutions (both statutory and charitable institution) after their partial closure due to Covid-19 At the same time, the first pilot phase of the Cash Plus Energy programme Mwangaza Mashinani in Garissa and Kilifi counties was successfully concluded, with the last payments going out in July 2020, despite the challenges posed by Covid-19. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK to establish a Technical Working Group (TWG) and a National Steering Committee at national level that include all relevant social protection stakeholders. Moreover, in June 2020, UNICEF and WFP founded the Sectoral Group for Social Protection (SGSP) to gather development partners working in the sector in Kenya. The Sectoral Group aims to ensure that development partners in the social protection sector provide support to the government in a predictable and coordinated manner that aligns with the latter’s strategic development priorities. UNICEF and WFP supported GoK in establishing a Community of Practice (CoP) for Social Protection. Led by the Directorate for Social Protection, the CoP was launched in October 2020 with a high-level event (held virtually, with few government representatives participating in person) and has hosted two webinars so far (Social Protection Adaptations to COVID-19; Launch of the Kenya Social Protection M&E Framework), with a third one being planned at the moment. Social Protection and Child Protection Response to Covid-19 Activities during the reporting period were deeply affected by the Covid-19 outbreak and the resulting movement restrictions. USD 733,293 of UNICEF’s funds from this grant were reprogrammed towards the Covid-19 response and are being used to support the upcoming UCB pilot. Similarly, WFP launched an emergency cash assistance programme for urban vulnerable groups in Mombasa and Nairobi where each targeted household received KES. 4000 per month for a period of three and four months respectively (the cash transfer funds were from USAID and Finland but with the use the system supported by Sida funds). To improve on the national system within the context of a complex emergency, USD 53,000 of this grant was set aside to facilitate an assessment that seeks to explore the social and economic impacts of COVID and how the existing social protection system has enhanced resilience at household level. The findings of this study will be disseminated in high level advocacy events with policy makers. Overall, to support effective coordination and appropriate response to the affected communities, WFP developed an Application Programming Interface (API) for the Enhanced Single Registry (ESR). This system provides an interface that allows a program to communicate with other programs, running in the same environment. Accordingly, different agencies and institutions with long-term and emergency specific social assistance interventions are able to link and use the ESR which in turn enhances greater collaboration among partners, effective use of available resources, increases transparency while supporting appropriate decision making based on available data. Building on government social and child protection systems, UNICEF is targeting families with children returned home from Charitable Children’s Institutions (CCIs) and Statutory Children’s Institutions (SCIs) during the Covid-19 outbreak in Garissa, Kilifi, Kisumu Nairobi and Turkana. The intervention, developed and implemented in close collaboration with MLSP at national and county level, provides a monthly cash transfer of Kes 2,000 for six months to support these families, using the existing government mechanism within MLSP, including identification and registration mechanism, as well as NSNP transfer value, payment cycles and payment modalities. Some tweaks to NSNP system were implemented to cater for the emergency nature of the intervention (e.g. the transfer value was adjusted to KES 2000 per child in for the first three months and reverted to the NSNP rate of KES 2000 per household for the remaining 3 months; use of M-Pesa as payment modality instead of banks; use of Kobo tools and Child Protection Information System (CPIMS) to register children and caregivers; support from social workers in the institutions. In light of Covid-19, the urgent need for support of children and adolescents in street situations became more evident. As a result, UNICEF is currently commissioning a study to assess the situation and needs of children and adolescents in street situations to hence design of a tailored social and child protection emergency intervention to support children and adolescent in street situations in light of the Covid-19 pandemic with cash and an ad-hoc package of services Within the framework of the activities to introduce a long-term nation-wide Universal Child Benefit (UCB), UNICEF and WFP, in close collaboration with MSLP, analyzed the possibility of introducing a temporary UCB to cushion vulnerable households during Covid-19. This is in line with the global surge of interest towards social protection, and particularly universal or quasi-universal approaches, as a tool to not only address long-term vulnerabilities but also protect people during crises. A concept note on the rationale for the roll-out of a temporary UCB was developed through intense discussion with the government and other UN agencies in mid-2020, and UNICEF and WFP are now working on the design and preparatory activities for the roll-out a pilot UCB in selected areas During the onset of COVID-19 and the crisis that followed the containment measures, the child protection was unfortunately not classified as one of the essential services by government. All officers from Department of Children services and National Council of Children Services worked from home. UNICEF supported both NCCS and Department of Children Services (DCS) to coordinate partners to continue supporting required services as well as emerging concerns from COVID-19 situation. UNICEF supported the development and provision of virtual training to 450 children officers and staff from NGOs through a series of 12 webinars. The trainings focused on child protection and mental health and psychosocial effects of COVID-19 on children, parents and their communities and required response. UNICEF provided financial and technical support to increase the number of telephone counsellors at the child helpline 116 services from 15 to 30 counsellors, configured the child line laptops for remote access and procured additional 8 laptops to improve the performance of Childline during the Covid-19 period. The staff at child helpline were provided with virtual training related to facts about Covid-19, related messages, referral service points and sensitized on mental health and psychosocial support during the Covid-19 period. Overall, between January and December 2020, a total of 92,672 (46,245 girls, 44,465 boys and 1,962 gender undisclosed) children, parents and caregivers were reached with mental health and psychosocial support services across Kenya with various UNICEF supported interventions including the CPVs support, child helpline and support within the Kakuma and Dadaab Refugee Camps. SIDA funds were also used to procure some personal protective equipment (PPE) that were distributed to CCIs and SCIs that requested for support through the MLSP, to NGOs working in the refugee camps and also to officers of Civil Registration Officers who had to continue with issuance of birth certificates. The PPEs included water jerricans, soap, and masks.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: UNDP Peace & Security for Inclusive and sustainable Development
UNDP Peace & Security for Inclusive and sustainable Development

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det föreslagna programmet för fred och hållbar utveckling "UNDP Transcending Foundations of Peace and Security for inclusive and Sustainable development in Kenya" syftar till att komma åt de omedelbara och underliggande orsakerna till konflikter, inklusive fattigdom och ojämlikhet, ungas arbetslöshet och sårbarhet, utnyttjande av etniska minoriteter, ojämlik fördelning av knappa miljötillgångar, motverka miljöförstöring och negativa effekter av klimatförändringar, socioekonomisk marginalisering, våldsbejakande extremism, öka kvinnors deltagande i konfliktlösning samt förhindra spridningen av små och lätta vapen. Sverige har tidigare finansierat UNDP:s freds- och säkerhetsprogram. Det föreslagna programmet bygger vidare på de resultat som uppnåtts och de lärdomar som dragits av tidigare program.
En slututvärdering har gjorts av det tidigare programmet, vilket visar att programmet har bidragit till att öka kapaciteten vid statliga institutioner, civila samhällsorganisationer och fredsstrukturen. Detta har skett genom utbildning, upprättandet av lokala fredsforum med kapacitet för tidiga varningar, förebyggande arbete och konfliktlösning. Det bidrog även till att integrera genus och fredsbyggande i statliga och regionala policyer samt budgetar. Programmet använde innovativa metoder för att förena befolkningens behov med statens mandat att upprätthålla säkerhet och fredlig samexistens mellan samhällsgrupper. Man identifierade också möjligheter att förebygga och motverka våldsbejakande extremism (P/CVE). I utvärderingen noterades även att det skett förseningar i tidsplanen, vilket lett till försenade utbetalningar från UNDP och försenade programaktiviteter. Där framgår även att fredskommittéerna inte hade nödvändig struktur för att kunna hantera alla framväxande problem. Ovanstående problem har tagits i beaktande när det nya föreslagna programmet utformats. Sverige har haft ett bra samarbete med UNDP och dess genomförande partner, inklusive civilsamhället och staten under föregående programperiod.
Det föreslagna programmet genomförs på nationell nivå, uppdelat på 10 regioner med två resultatmål: i) Normativ standardkompetens hos staten att omsätta policyer och juridiska ramverk gällande konflikthantering, sammanhållning och säkerhet ii) Stärkt kapacitet för fredsbyggande på nationell, regional och lokal nivå beträffande fred, inkludering, försoning, social sammanhållning och integration.
Programmets resultatmål kommer att fokusera på följande områden: 1) Policyer, juridiska ramverk för fredsbyggande, konfliktförebyggande, sammanhållning, säkerhet och motverkande av våldsbejakande extremism (PVE) ska utformas, granskas och genomföras på nationell och regional nivå; 2) Kapaciteten för fredsbyggande på nationell och regional nivå för hållbar fred, inkludering, sammanhållning, integration, säkerhet och PVE ska stärkas och koordineras; 3) Att unga, funktionsnedsatta, kvinnor och andra marginaliserade grupper inkluderas och blir delaktiga i freds- och säkerhetsaktiviteter; och 4) Partnersamarbeten för att förhindra att det uppstår våldsamheter på lokal, regional och nationell nivå.
Det föreslagna programmet ligger strategiskt i linje med de nationella utvecklingsprioriteringar som anges i Kenyas Vision 2030, den medellånga planen (MTP) III och regeringens utvecklingsagenda the Big Four. Det är i linje med nationella fredsbyggnadsprocesser, som t.ex. Building Bridges Initiative (BBI), ett nationellt initiativ som syftar till att främja en mer enad stat. Programmet bidrar till FN:s utvecklingsramverk UNDAF (2018-2022) och de hållbara utvecklingsmålen (SDG), i synnerhet SDG 1 (fattigdom), SDG 5 (jämställdhet mellan könen), 10 (minskad ojämlikhet), 16 (fred, rättvisa och starka institutioner) samt 17 (partnerskap). Det bidrar till resultatmål 2 i FN:s utvecklingsprograms (UNDP) landsprogramsdokument (CPD), nämligen att Kenyas befolkning ska leva i ett säkert, fredligt, inkluderande och sammanhållet samhälle. Fortsatt stöd till konflikt- och försoningsprocesser i Kenya.
I programbedömningen klassas tre risker som höga. a) Svag finansiering: Den totala föreslagna budgeten jämfört med den totala kärnfinansieringen från utvecklingspartner, Kenyas regering och UNDP visar på ett underskott på 57 %. Hittills är det endast Sverige, UNDP och Kenyas regering som har åtagit sig att finansiera det föreslagna programmet. b) Klimatförändringar som leder till konflikter och ökad förekomst av små och lätta vapen samt c) Att Covid-19 orsakat svåra ekonomiska problem, vilket lett till ökad osäkerhet. Två riskfaktorer anses enligt granskningen från 2018 vara medelhöga a) ägarskapet för programmet då det leds av Kenyas regering och NGO:er måste anta ett nytt förhållningssätt. b) Svag intern kontroll från UNDP av deras partner samt på organisatorisk nivå. Sverige kommer att fortsätta följa upp detta tillsammans med UNDP samt delta i uppföljningar, fältbesök och årliga granskningar. Flera förmildrande faktorer beskrivs i bedömningen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposed programme "UNDP Transcending Foundations of Peace and Securty for inclusive and Sustainable development in Kenya" seeks to address immediate and underlying drivers of conflict, including poverty and inequality, youth unemployment and vulnerability, exploitation of ethnic difference, inequitable distribution of scarce environmental goods, environmental degradation and adverse effects of climate change, socio economic exclusion and marginalization, prevention of violent extremism, engagement of women in conflict transformation, and prevention of the proliferation of small arms and light weapons. SE has previously funded UNDP on Peace and Security programmes. The proposed programme builds on the achievements and lessons learned from the previous programmes.
An End term evaluation was conducted of the previous programme which showed that the programme contributed to enhancing capacities of national institutions, civil society organizations and the peace architecture through training, establishment of county peace forums with capacities for conflict early warning, prevention and response. It further contributed towards the mainstreaming of gender and peacebuilding into national and county government policies, plans and budgets. The programme had ingenious ways of merging community needs with government mandate of maintaining security and peaceful coexistence amongst communities and identified opportunities in preventing and countering violent extremism (P/CVE). The evaluation also noted delays in clearance of work plans and subsequent disbursement of funds from UNDP which led to delayed implementation of programme activities. It also found that the Peace committees did not have te requisite infrastructure to respond to all emerging issues. The above issues have been considered in the new proposed programme. SE had a good cooperation with UNDP and its implementing partners including civil society and Government in the previous programme.
The proposed programme is implemented at a national level divided into 10 regions with two outcomes:- i) Government has normative standard capacities to operationalize policies and legal frameworks on conflict management, cohesion and human security ii) Strengthened capacities of peace architecture at national, county and community levels on peace, inclusion, reconciliation, social cohesion and integration
The programme outputs will focus on the following areas: 1) Policies, legal and regulatory frameworks for peacebuilding, conflict prevention, cohesion, community security and prevention of violent extremism (PVE) formulated, reviewed and implemented at national and county levels; 2) Capacities for peace architecture at national and county levels for sustainable peace, inclusion, cohesion, integration, community security and PVE strengthened and coordinated; 3) Inclusion and participation of youth, persons with disabilities (PWDs), Women and other marginalized groups in peace and security interventions strengthened; and 4) Collaborative partnerships to prevent incidences of violence at community, county and national levels
This proposed programme has strategic alignment to national development priorities as outlined in Kenya Vision 2030, the Medium-Term Plan (MTP) III, and the Big Four Government development agenda. It is aligned with national Peace building processes, such as the Building Bridges Initiative (BBI), a national unity drive seeking to nurture a more united nation. The Programme contributes to the UN Development Assistance Framework, UNDAF (2018-2022) and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 1 (Poverty), SDG 5 (Gender Equality), 10 (Reduced Inequalities), 16 (Peace, justice and strong institutions) and 17 (Partnerships). It contributes to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Country Programme Document (CPD) outcome area 2 which envisions that the people of Kenya live in a secure, peaceful, inclusive and cohesive society. Continued support to conflict and reconciliation issues in Kenya.
In the programme assessment, three risks are rated as high. a) Low funding: - The total proposed budget as compared to the total commitment from Development partners, Government of Kenya and UNDP core funds indicates a deficit of 57%. So far, only Sweden, UNDP and the Government of Kenya who have committed to financing the proposed programme. b) Climate change which leads to conflict and proliferation of small arms and light weapons and c) Effects of Covid 19 which has seen severe economic shocks leading to increased insecurity. current effects of the Covid 19. There are two medium risks foreseen a) ownership of the programme as it is lead by the National Government and the NGO's have to adopt an engage disengage approach. b) Weak internal control by UNDP of its partners and at the corporate level as per the 2018 audit. SE will continue to follow up this with UNDP and participate in monitoring, field visits and annual reviews. Several mitigating factors are outlined in the assessment.

The objective of the programme is to contribute to a secure, peaceful, inclusive and cohesive Kenya through addressing the immediate and underlying causes of conflict. This includes interalia; Ensuring the Government has normative standards to operationalize policies and legal frameworks on conflict management, cohesion and human security as well as strengthening capacities of peace architecture at national, county and community levels. The programme will strengthen formulation, implementation and review of policy, legal and institutional frameworks on peace building, national cohesion and conflict management; build institutional capacity to prevent and respond to community security threats and promote the inclusion of youth, women, Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) and marginalised groups in peacebuilding, prevention of violent extremism, cohesion and conflict management. The programme is envisaged to significantly contribute to enhanced coordination, increased capacities for proactive conflict early warning, prevention, management and infrastructure for peace. Ultimately, this will set Kenya onto the path of a secure, peaceful, inclusive and cohesive society, underpinned by good governance and guided by Vision 2030 aspirations.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

16.a - Stärka berörda nationella institutioner, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete, i syfte att bygga upp kapacitet på alla nivåer, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, för att förebygga våld och bekämpa terrorism och brottslighet.

Två riskfaktorer anses enligt granskningen från 2018 vara medelhöga a) ägarskapet för programmet då det leds av Kenyas regering och NGO:er måste anta ett nytt förhållningssätt. b) Svag intern kontroll från UNDP av deras partner samt på organisatorisk nivå. Sverige kommer att fortsätta följa upp detta tillsammans med UNDP samt delta i uppföljningar, fältbesök och årliga granskningar. Flera förmildrande faktorer beskrivs i bedömningen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposed programme "UNDP Transcending Foundations of Peace and Securty for inclusive and Sustainable development in Kenya" seeks to address immediate and underlying drivers of conflict, including poverty and inequality, youth unemployment and vulnerability, exploitation of ethnic difference, inequitable distribution of scarce environmental goods, environmental degradation and adverse effects of climate change, socio economic exclusion and marginalization, prevention of violent extremism, engagement of women in conflict transformation, and prevention of the proliferation of small arms and light weapons. SE has previously funded UNDP on Peace and Security programmes. The proposed programme builds on the achievements and lessons learned from the previous programmes.
An End term evaluation was conducted of the previous programme which showed that the programme contributed to enhancing capacities of national institutions, civil society organizations and the peace architecture through training, establishment of county peace forums with capacities for conflict early warning, prevention and response. It further contributed towards the mainstreaming of gender and peacebuilding into national and county government policies, plans and budgets. The programme had ingenious ways of merging community needs with government mandate of maintaining security and peaceful coexistence amongst communities and identified opportunities in preventing and countering violent extremism (P/CVE). The evaluation also noted delays in clearance of work plans and subsequent disbursement of funds from UNDP which led to delayed implementation of programme activities. It also found that the Peace committees did not have te requisite infrastructure to respond to all emerging issues. The above issues have been considered in the new proposed programme. SE had a good cooperation with UNDP and its implementing partners including civil society and Government in the previous programme.
The proposed programme is implemented at a national level divided into 10 regions with two outcomes:- i) Government has normative standard capacities to operationalize policies and legal frameworks on conflict management, cohesion and human security ii) Strengthened capacities of peace architecture at national, county and community levels on peace, inclusion, reconciliation, social cohesion and integration
The programme outputs will focus on the following areas: 1) Policies, legal and regulatory frameworks for peacebuilding, conflict prevention, cohesion, community security and prevention of violent extremism (PVE) formulated, reviewed and implemented at national and county levels; 2) Capacities for peace architecture at national and county levels for sustainable peace, inclusion, cohesion, integration, community security and PVE strengthened and coordinated; 3) Inclusion and participation of youth, persons with disabilities (PWDs), Women and other marginalized groups in peace and security interventions strengthened; and 4) Collaborative partnerships to prevent incidences of violence at community, county and national levels
This proposed programme has strategic alignment to national development priorities as outlined in Kenya Vision 2030, the Medium-Term Plan (MTP) III, and the Big Four Government development agenda. It is aligned with national Peace building processes, such as the Building Bridges Initiative (BBI), a national unity drive seeking to nurture a more united nation. The Programme contributes to the UN Development Assistance Framework, UNDAF (2018-2022) and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly SDG 1 (Poverty), SDG 5 (Gender Equality), 10 (Reduced Inequalities), 16 (Peace, justice and strong institutions) and 17 (Partnerships). It contributes to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Country Programme Document (CPD) outcome area 2 which envisions that the people of Kenya live in a secure, peaceful, inclusive and cohesive society. Continued support to conflict and reconciliation issues in Kenya.
In the programme assessment, three risks are rated as high. a) Low funding: - The total proposed budget as compared to the total commitment from Development partners, Government of Kenya and UNDP core funds indicates a deficit of 57%. So far, only Sweden, UNDP and the Government of Kenya who have committed to financing the proposed programme. b) Climate change which leads to conflict and proliferation of small arms and light weapons and c) Effects of Covid 19 which has seen severe economic shocks leading to increased insecurity. current effects of the Covid 19. There are two medium risks foreseen a) ownership of the programme as it is lead by the National Government and the NGO's have to adopt an engage disengage approach. b) Weak internal control by UNDP of its partners and at the corporate level as per the 2018 audit. SE will continue to follow up this with UNDP and participate in monitoring, field visits and annual reviews. Several mitigating factors are outlined in the assessment.

The objective of the programme is to contribute to a secure, peaceful, inclusive and cohesive Kenya through addressing the immediate and underlying causes of conflict. This includes interalia; Ensuring the Government has normative standards to operationalize policies and legal frameworks on conflict management, cohesion and human security as well as strengthening capacities of peace architecture at national, county and community levels. The programme will strengthen formulation, implementation and review of policy, legal and institutional frameworks on peace building, national cohesion and conflict management; build institutional capacity to prevent and respond to community security threats and promote the inclusion of youth, women, Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) and marginalised groups in peacebuilding, prevention of violent extremism, cohesion and conflict management. The programme is envisaged to significantly contribute to enhanced coordination, increased capacities for proactive conflict early warning, prevention, management and infrastructure for peace. Ultimately, this will set Kenya onto the path of a secure, peaceful, inclusive and cohesive society, underpinned by good governance and guided by Vision 2030 aspirations.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.4 - By 2030, significantly reduce illicit financial and arms flows, strengthen the recovery and return of stolen assets and combat all forms of organized crime.

title.narrative: COVID-19 OneUN-SRHR for girls and young women in Mozambique
COVID-19 OneUN-SRHR för Flickor och unga kvinnor i Mocambique

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 One UN i Moçambique har, genom Resident Coordinators kontor, inkommit med ett programförslag (2 oktober 2015) till Sveriges ambassad med titeln "Action for girls and young women’s Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights in Mozambique" (Insats för flickors och unga kvinnors sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa och rättigheter i Moçambique), som föreslår en gemensam FN-insats (UN-Joint program, inkl. UNFPA, UNICEF, UN Women och UNESCO) som syftar till att "främja och skydda flickors och unga kvinnors sexuella och reproduktiva hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR) genom ett helhetsgrepp som utgår ifrån flickor och unga kvinnor som "hela individer" och placerar dem i centrum av sin egen utveckling som förändringsaktörer snarare än offer". Det föreslagna programmet är fyraårigt (april 2016- mars 2020) och har föregåtts av en 7,5 månaders inledande förberedelsefas 1 juli-14 februari 2016 (Beslut om beredning 37/15, Beslut om insats 45/15 Insats ID: 51140105) omfattande stöd om SEK 5 000 000 för att UNFPA och UNICEF skulle genomföra förberedelser i form av bl.a. baslinjestudier för att definiera programmets utgångspunkter och mål inför genomförandet av det fyraåriga huvudprogrammet. Det totala sökta beloppet för huvudprogrammet uppgår till USD 13 970 447 (ca. SEK 120 000 000). Programmet syftar till att uppnå resultat inom fyra olika kompletterande områden och kommer att bidra till uppnåendet av resultat inom FN:s gemensamma och koordinerade resultatramverk för samarbete med Moçambique (Development Assistance Framework för Moçambique, UNDAF 2012-2016 samt dess efterföljare 2017-2021). Programmet kommer att genomföras av följande FN-organ som kommer att engagera sig i kompletterande aktiviteter baserat på mandat och komparativa fördelar: 1. Stärkande av flickors och unga kvinnors egenmakt (UNFPA, UNICEF) 2. Sexuell och reproduktiv hälsoservice (UNFPA, UNESCO, UN Women) 3. Mobilisering av familjer och lokalsamhällen (UNFPA, UNICEF) 4. Policy, påverkansarbete och deltagande (UNFPA, UNICEF)
Vidare så kommer One UN programmet bidra till ett koordinerat agerande på nationell nivå och stärkandet av FN:s normativa roll i Moçambique inom SRHR för ungdomar då policystöd, påverkansarbete, teknisk rådgivning samt kommunikation kommer att utgöra viktiga delar inom programmet.
Det andra centrala målet för programmet är stöd till vidareutvecklingen och genomförandet av det sektorsövergripande statliga programmet för främjande av SRHR och hiv/aids-förbyggande bland ungdomar, Programa Geração Biz (PGB). FN har för avsikt att i samarbete med andra partners involverade i koordination och genomförande, Ministerierna för Ungdom & Sport, Hälsa, Utbildning, samt Jämställdet, och deras motsvarighet på provins och distriktsnivå, hälsocentraler, skolor, samt media och organisationer inom civila samhället, stödja ytterligare innovation samt fördjupa och förstärka PGB:s ansats. Programmet bör dock först och främst ses som ett One UN program för stärkt samordning och resultat uppnåelse inom området SRHR för ungdomar i Moçambique snarare än stöd riktat till den Moçambikiska staten. Det föreslagna programmet kommer också att bidra till att bygga kapacitet inom lokalsamhällen och ungdomsorganisationer som vidare kommer att bidra till att stärka och förbättra civilsamhällets roll och förmåga att delta i arbetet för att öka SRHR för ungdomar i landet. Programmet kommer att genomföras i två provinser i centrala och norra Moçambique, Zambezia och Nampula, på landsbygden och i stadsnära områden. Dessa provinser har valts baserat på att de är de två folkrikaste provinserna i landet med en betydande målgrupp, att SRHR indikatorer ligger under nationella genomsnitt och att programmet kan bygga på tidigare FN-insatser inom bl.a. hälsa.
Avtalsstrukturen innefattar ett ”Standard Adminsitrative Arrangement” (SAA) för gemensamma program (Joint Programs) (Beslutade i juni 2015 av UN Development Group i samarbetet med givare inklusive Sverige, Sida beslut 2015-003649). Sveriges avtalspart är UNDP-Multi Partner Trust Fund Office i New York som också agerar ”Administrative Agent” och ansvarar för administration av det svenska bidraget på central nivå och att sammanställa finansiell rapportering från de genomförande FN-organisationerna (Participating UN Organisations). Till SAA biläggs en kopia för information av ett signerat ”Memorandum of Understanding” (MoU) upprättat specifikt för programmet mellan de genomförande FN-organisationerna, där deras inbördes ansvar klargörs och programmets innehåll beskrivs (detta MoU görs inte till avtalsinnehåll).
Styrning och översikt av programmet kommer att ske genom en styrkommitté sk. Steering Committee (SC) där alla genomförande FN-organisationer, regeringsrepresentanter inom ramen för det statliga ungdomsprogrammet Programa Geração Biz (Ministerierna för Hälsa-, Utbildning-, Ungdom & Sport samt Jämställdhet) och givare kommer att vara medlemmar. SC har beslutsrätt avseende planering och budgetering inom programmet och de kommer att samanträda två gånger per år. Ambassaden i Maputo kommer att delta i SC och representera Sverige som givare.
Resident Coordinators Office (RCO, UNDP på landnivå) kommer att agera lokal ”Administrative Agent” och kommer att ha den övergripande tillsynen av programmet, leda SC tillsammans med regeringsrepresentanter och koordinera lokal finansiell rapportering inom programmet och till SC, samt den årliga UNDAF rapporten.
UNFPA som ledande tematisk FN-organisation för programmet kommer att agera s.k. ”Convening agent” och ansvarar för koordinering av programmets partners, planering, och genomförande samt ansvara för kontinuerlig uppföljning, lärande inkl. analys av resultat och narrativ rapportering. UNFPA kommer också koordinera SC (organisera möten samt underlag till dessa) samt husera programmets koordinator.
Medel kommer att utbetalas till UNDP-Multi Partner Trust Fund Office i New York som förmedlar dem vidare i enlighet med budget till de genomförande FN-organisationerna som kommer att upprätta och administrera projektkonton i enlighet med deras regelverk. UNFPA och UNICEF är de FN-organisationer som kommer att vidareförmedla medel till genomförande civilsamhällesorganisationer och statliga institutioner genom kontrakts/avtalsförfarande. Dessa genomförande partners kommer att rapportera användning av medel till UNFPA respektive UNICEF i enlighet med deras avtal med dessa FN-organisationer. Ca. 43% av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas till tredje part, ca. 70% av dessa till civilsamhällesorganisationer och 30% till statliga institutioner.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The One UN program in Mozambique will implement a joint UN intervention (incl. UNFPA,UNICEF,UN Women,UNESCO,UNAIDS,UNDP) which aims to "promote and protect the SRHR of girls/young women through a holistic approach which sees the girls and young women as "whole individuals"; placing them at the center of their own development as change agents.

Sexual and reproductive health and rights of girls and young women in two provinces in Mozambique are fully realized through improved capacities to make informed choices and improved access to SRH services.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: In the second year of implementation Rapariga Biz expanded into 7 more districts which makes up a total of 14 districts reached across Nampula and Zambezia provinces. The implementation focused on establishing and ensuring the programmatic quality and synergies across the outcomes and implementing partners through the holistic and integrated approach at the national, provincial, district and community levels. The multi-sectoral committees at all levels continue to provide a strategic mechanism for leadership and coordination of the implementation of Rapariga Biz. The key achievements during the first 2 years are: - 2,299 mentors were empowered to lead the mentorship which represents 40% against the target of 5,799. - 8,084 girls and young women aged 10-24 years were empowered with knowledge, skills and voice on their SRHR in the safe spaces. - 2,213 of girls and young women out-of-school have been integrated into schools. - 6,722 adolescent girls have their citizenship rights enhanced by obtaining civil registration (birth certificates & ID). - 49,568 (78%) of girls and young women visiting a SAAJ or health facility adopted at least one family planning method other than condoms. - 1,506 (1,6%) cases of child marriage were reported of which 53 (0,1%) are aged 10–14 years and 1,453 (3,9%) aged 15-19 years. - 110 (0,1%) cases of early pregnancy where reported in the age of 15-19 years. - 400 adolescent’s media producers shared and discussed issues related to their SRHR, education, empowerment and economic opportunities in radios and TV programs. - 47,755 girls and young women have been reached through mobile clinics conducted to provide integrated SRH services. - 127,904 adolescents of which 73,487 were girls and young women aged 10–24 years sought family planning services at SSR corners in schools and 46,1% (33,878) adopted at least one modern family planning method other than a condom. - 1,001 girls and young women participated in vocational and professional training. - 240 religious leaders empowered to contribute towards the promotion and protection girls and young women’s SRHR. - 732 community leaders, parents and midwives mobilized and empowered with SRHR knowledge through 31 community dialogues. - 59,262 adolescents empowered with ASRHR information in Zambezia and Nampula through SMS Biz, having in the system 140,063 adolescents and young people. The challenges faced in keeping the girls and young women in the safe spaces are multifaceted due to family movements, school transition, distance to the safe space, girls and young women’s lack of interest or incentives to participate, lack of parents support, parents demand for the target group to undertake work at home or small sales in the streets etc. In response to those challenges, Rapariga Biz intends to improve the awareness of and engagement with the program at the community level through several complementary efforts; a) the use of community radios; b) the launch of a monthly “community girl Biz champion” and quarterly “mentor champion” at the community level and; to strengthen the work with families of the target group and the mobilization of the community through the community dialogues and mobilization through local leaders in order to strengthen and sustain their engagement in girls and young women’s SRHR. The complementary efforts across sectors coordinated by the multi sector committees under Outcome 2 (Availability of quality integrated ASRH services for girls and young women increase) yield positive results and also proved to be key to the delivery of quality integrated, youth-friendly and gender sensitive ASRH services at the level of schools and communities. Additionally, evidence shows the importance of ensuring coordinated efforts and synergies with the demand creation side of Rapariga Biz in order to establish integrated, youth-friendly and sensitive services where investments are made to create the demand among adolescents and youth. Due to the efforts under Outcome 1 and 3 (Girls and young women’s knowledge, voice and capacities strengthened to make informed decisions on their SRH, demand for and uptake of essential SRH services and on an enabling, free and safe environment for increased participation of girls and young women and the promotion of their SRH rights created), the demands for family planning and sexual health services are increasing among the target group. However, the SAAJ services in many health facilities are still facing challenges with regards to the possibility for privacy and integrated, youth-friendly and gender sensitive counselling, which is a concern raised by the girls and young women under Rapariga Biz. Additionally, there is a limited number of SAAJs operating in the two provinces. In Nampula there are currently 136 SAAJs with only 38 providing exclusive SAAJ service, and in Zambezia the number is 42 with 11 (26%) providing exclusive SAAJ service. In the case of Nampula, the first 7 Rapariga Biz districts have 45 SAAJs catering for a girl’s population of 244,195, thus per capita of 5,426 at least 2,000 higher than the provincial average A general challenge during the 2nd year of implementation has been the lack of an supportive and enabling environment for the work of the mentors in some district which have resulted in dropouts among the girls and young women. However, in other districts local and religious leaders mobilized under Rapariga Biz have prevented or stopped early marriages from occurring in their community. It demonstrates the need for mobilizing key community stakeholders, such as local leaders, parents, families, boys and men. Synergies have been sought across interventions to maximize the impact of the holistic and integrated approach at the community level. With the mentors being at the heart of the holistic approach, one of the key synergies across implementing partners, is their role as reference points across the different interventions. One example is the participation of mentors in the community dialogue and the coordination across partners implementing the community interventions towards a more enabling environment for girls and young women’s SRHR. Another example is the mentors’ use and promotion of the SMS BIZ/U-Report platform. All mentors that were trained in August 2017 in the 7 new districts have been trained to use the application in their weekly mentorship sessions, which provide them with an immediate source of additional information and knowledge related to the specific sexual and reproductive health issue being addressed. Outcome 4 (Governance and coordination for integrated SRH programming at all levels strengthened) is key to the successful implementation of the first 3 outcomes in its aim towards strengthening governance, coordination and generation of evidence and learning for integrated SRH programming. Evidence shows from the 2nd year of implementation that strengthened coordination is key to maximize the impact of the holistic and integrated approach across outcomes. In that regard, positive trends have been reported from the revitalization of the District Multi-Sector Committees in the first 14 Rapariga Biz districts as they play a significant role in the coordination towards greater synergies and complementary efforts across ministries and implementing partners. Therefore, a lesson learned is to continue to strengthen coordination and ensure regular coordination meetings at the district level with the participation of key Rapariga Biz partners. Secondly, it is key to the Government leadership and coordination to ensure the capacity of the PGB focal points at the provincial and district levels in priority areas as SRHR, monitoring and evaluation, management and coordination. During the expansion from 7 to 14 districts it has been proven important to increase the technical assistance from UN agencies to maintain and strengthen the quality implementation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Organisationen Technoserve har till Sida inkommit med ansökan om finansiellt stöd på 56 500 000 SEK till genomförande av insatsen "Women IN Business (WIN)", ett femårigt program för Moçambique med start 2019 och förväntad sluttid i december 2022.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till att stärka kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt i Moçambique. Programmet riktar sig till kvinnliga låginkomsttagare och baseras på metoden "Market System Development" (MSD). Programmet har genomfört en inledande designfas med stöd från Sida under de senaste två åren, och förväntas nu gå in i en mer storskalig genomförandefas, som bygger på slutsatser och lärdomar från förra fasen.
MSD-metoden innebär att genomföraren gör en diagnos av marknad och värdekedjor för att rikta och testa olika alternativa lösningar kring kvinnors företagande. TechnoServe har i tidigare fas tittat särskilt på fyra sektormarknader - textil, handlen, barnvård och jordbruk (agro-processing). Slutsatsen från denna analys var att textilmarknaden är den med bästa potential att börja arbeta i. De andra sektorerna kommer utredas vidare för att hitta fungerande marknadslösningar.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 TechnoServe has applied to Sida for funding of 56.5 million SEK to carry out the "Women IN Business (WIN)" programme in Mozambique during the period 2019-2022.
The intervention intends to contribute to increasing women’s economic empowerment in Mozambique by identifying, catalysing and scaling up systemic solutions that benefit low-income women. The WIN programme applies a method called Market System Development (MSD), a diagnostic tool for markets and value chain to target and test alternatives to female led businesses.
TechnoServe carried out four sector market assessments (textiles, trade sector, childcare services and agro-processing), and decided to start with textile sector interventions while deepen the understanding of others. New sectors and value chains will be added as market system opportunities are identified.

The objective of the programme (expected impact) is increased access to services and support, particularly for women and young people in rural areas, improving their opportunities to start and run commercial businesses. Achievement of this objective would contribute to increased women’s economic empowerment in Mozambique by identifying, catalysing and scaling up systemic solutions that benefit low-income women, which is the overall goal of the programme. Using a gender-transformative approach, WIN programme will seek multiple ways to increase women’s economic empowerment with solutions covering increase of business revenue or wages, reduce the cost of doing business / working, reduce women’s unpaid work and/or improve access to services. Given that most low-income women in Mozambique are operating micro or small businesses, a priority target group for WIN is women-owned businesses in markets with high growth potential. Instead of women-led business, women who own their businesses can benefit more easily from a program that targets business performance, as they have more direct control over the resulting business income increases. The program will also look for opportunities to benefit women as customers, managers and staff.

tag.narrative: 5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.
