description.narrative: The performance in this 6th year is perhaps the most exceptional in the lifespan of the programme, posting an overall 11.3% improvement since last year. Four out of the 14 Disbursement-Linked Results (DRLs) disbursed this year has improved in performance, despite the second half of the year being affected by the Covid 19 pandemic. Improvement in results can be contributed to governments commitment to this programme. Main improvements cover student retention, effective school quality assurance system as well as adequate and timely resource management and improved information system. The DLRs that improved performance are “foundational activities, setting up the underlying systems necessary for the other DLRs” with 60 % improvement, “improved student retention” improved with 28 % and “adequate and timely resource flows” with 4 %. Being outcome indicators, the exemplary performance in these indicators indicate that the programme has been successful in contributing to improved learning in Tanzania. The programme has also improved the learning for girls. This year, the indicator on girls’ transition continued to perform very well. Only three Regions (Geita, Kigoma and Mara) had a GPI of girls transition of less than 90%. In general therefore, the performance against most DLRs is viewed by the Embassy as above satisfactory-level.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) i Tanzania är designat för att stärka FN-systemets samstämmighet och effektivitet på nationell nivå, som bidrag till Tanzanias arbete för hållbar fattigdomsminskning och förverkligandet av mänskliga rättigheter. Den breda verksamheten motsvarar flera av de mål som anges i den svenska resultatstrategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Tanzania 2013-2019. Fyra av totalt tolv resultatområden är särskilt relevanta för den svenska strategin: god samhällstyrning/mänskliga rättigheter/gender; våld mot kvinnor och barn; kvinnligt deltagande och politiskt ledarskp; samt ekonomisk tillväxt och sysselsättning. Den svenska strategin identifierar kvinnor, barn och ungdomar som prioriterade målgrupper vilket också reflekteras väl i de områden för stöd som Sida valt.
UNDAP II är helt i linje med givarnas s k Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) och med Tanzanias nationella visioner (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II är också utvecklad i linje med Tanzanias femårsplan 2015/16 - 2020/21 och med de globala hållbarhets- och utvecklingsmålen. Programmet bidrar till FN:s fokus på förbättrade resultat och samstämmighet genom att sammanföra ett 20-tal FN-organs planering, budgetering och rapportering i ett gemensamt resultatramverk för Tanzania. UNDAP II minskar därför i viss utsträckning även dubbelarbete för nationella partner såväl som för FN organisationer.
Det svenska stödet ska ges via One UN Fund, i linje med Sveriges politik att stödja ett sammanhållet och mer effektivt FN-arbete i länderna (FN-reformen "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP är det av FN utsedda FN-organ som administrerar One UN Fund (genom UNDP-kontoret i Dar es Salaam och huvudkontoret i New York), och UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) FN:s högste representant i Tanzania, varför båda dessa står som FN:s undertecknande av SAA med Sida. I linje med Sveriges resultatstrategi för Tanzania kommer stödet inte att gå generellt till UNDAP, utan som öronmärkt till de fyra nämnda resultatområdena.
Medlen kommer att fördelas enligt nedan till följande resultatområden: - Ekonomisk tillväxt och anställning: 125 000 000 SEK - God samhällsstyrning och mänskliga rättigheter: 82 500 000 SEK - Kvinnors politiska deltagande: 50 000 000 SEK - Våld mot kvinnor och barn: 42 500 000 SEK

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the co-ordination and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzania's efforts to achieve sustainable poverty reduction and the implementation of human rights. The broad business corresponds to several of the goals set out in the Swedish Development Cooperation Development Strategy Tanzania 2013-2019. Four out of twelve results areas are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy: good governance / human rights / gender; violence against women and children; female participation and political leadership; as well as economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and adolescents as prioritized target groups, which also reflects well in the areas of support chosen by Sida.
UNDAP II is fully in line with the donors' Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) and with Tanzania's National Visions (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II is also developed in line with Tanzania's five-year plan 2015/16 - 2020/21 and with global sustainability and development goals. The program contributes to the UN's focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together 20 UN agencies' planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore, to a certain extent, also reduces duplication for national partners as well as UN organizations.
Swedish support will be provided through One UN Fund, in line with Sweden's policy to support a coherent and more effective UN work in the countries (UN reform "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP is the UN-designated UN body that manages the One UN Fund (through the UNDP office in Dar es Salaam and the headquarters in New York), and the UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) UN High Representative in Tanzania, why both of them stand as UN signing of SAA with Sida. In line with Sweden's earnings strategy for Tanzania, the support will not go to UNDAP generally, but as earmarked for the four mentioned results areas.
The funds will be distributed as follows to the following results areas: - Economic growth and employment: SEK 125,000,000 - Good governance and human rights: 82 500 000 SEK - Women's political participation: SEK 50,000,000 - Violence against women and children: 42 500 000 SEK

description.narrative: Progress towards Outcomes results Economic Growth and Employment The outcome area comprises of 13 UN agencies contributing towards three outputs, see below. The outcome group is currently contributing to two Joint Programmes, one in Kigoma (the Kigoma Joint Programme) and one in Zanzibar (the Zanzibar Joint Programme) The outcome group is coordinated by ILO and have a designated person coordinating monitoring and results reporting. The group have monthly meetings where the different UN agencies are present. This is an opportunity for the UN agencies to share lessons learnt and exchange ideas and find synergies between themselves. In March 2019 the outcome group had a joint retreat focusing on the MSD approach to learn from each other and deepen the understanding of the concept. The EoS is present in the outcome meetings and it gives a good opportunity to get an insights of the work of the outcome group. The delivery rate for the outcome Economic Growth and employment for the period 2018-2019 is 83% of annual targets fully or close to fully achieved. Output 1 Relevant MDAs and selected LGAs have strengthened capacities to review and implement evidence based economic policies and plans to be business enabling, environmentally sustainable and gender responsive: In Zanzibar, technical and financial assistance contributed to the finalisation of the Agriculture Sector Development Programme and the Youth Development Policy. On mainland inputs supported the finalization of the Microfinance Act and Microfinance Regulations. At sub-national level 33 regional and LGAs were enabled to create national plans, budgets and investments that integrated poverty, environmental and gender concerns. Concrete examples are six Regional Investment Guidelines designed to attract local/foreign investments and nine private partnerships resulting in revenue generating facilities. Training in Gender responsive budgeting have provided eight LGAs better equipped to manage district development funds for women and youth, demonstrated by a 26,5% increase in allocations and utilization over the last two years and the figures rised from TZS 592.8 million to 796.5 million. Input on Output 2 Relevant institutions have enhanced capacities to provide gender-responsive, market-oriented, quality programmes, products and services Following UN technical advice and financial support, 74 institutions with national or local reach delivered market-oriented and gender responsive training programmes and business development support products and services. This includes 8 skills development institutions such as the NCT and ZITOD, leading to the successful graduation of the first batch of 52 apprentices from the Zanzibar Quality Apprenticeship Programme in Hotel Operations. Strengthen the capacity of Tanzania Investment Centre to manage e-regulations platforms, which has made it easier for investors and entrepreneurs to start a business Through trainings and technical advice, 11 LGAs and 3 agricultural training institutions have strengthened capacity to provide agri-business development support including on good agronomic practices, climate-smart agriculture, and entrepreneurship. This will contribute to improved access to quality extension advice for women and men farmers and entrepreneurs. Input on Output 3 Micro, small, medium and large enterprises, in particular those led by women and youth, have strengthened capacities to increase productivity, add value to their products and access markets More than 38 000 micro enterprises (both on mainland and Zanzibar) have strengthened capacities to increase productivity, add value to their products and access markets. The assistance from UNDAPII has ranged from providing trainings on GAP and construction of aggregation centres and storage facilities (28, 500 famers have reported a decrease in post-harvest losses from 40% to 27%) to facilitating links between farmers and traders. In Zanzibar, 180 primarily women seaweed farmers were provided with knowledge and skills to embark on sea cucumber farming as a new livelihood opportunity, while training of 40 youth (60% women) on value addition led to improved packaging and increased competitiveness. Access to finance initiatives led to more than 35,220 people (W: 21,504, M: 11,343, Y: 2,373) accessing financial services through savings groups, SACCOS, community banks and commercial banks. Additional 4,170,503 people (55% women) were reached through an IFAD loan. Progress towards Outcomes result Democratic Governance, Human Rights & Gender Equality The outcome area comprises of 4 UN agencies contributing towards three outputs, see below. The outcome group is coordinated by UNDP and it has a designated person who is responsible for coordinating, monitoring and results reporting. The group does meet every now and then, but it is not clear how regularly this occurs and whether all the involved UN agencies are always present. EoS has only been invited to and present at 2 outcome meetings during the period Aug 2018 – Aug 2020, which substantially limits the EoS’ opportunity to get an insight into the work of the outcome group. Minutes from potential meetings where EoS has not been invited have also not been shared. This is a pity since such meetings are an opportunity for the UN agencies to share lessons learnt and exchange ideas and find synergies between themselves, from which the EoS can learn and understand the effectiveness of the outcome group and the work it delivers. Output 1 Citizens of Tanzania especially the most marginalized have increased capacity to engage and participate in policy formulation, implementation and monitoring. During the reporting period, 119 CSOs were supported to engage with parliamentary committees and/or participate in public hearings across a range of issues, including discussions around the Political Parties (Amendment) Bill, the Finance Bill and sectoral budget reviews. The National Assembly was also enabled to better integrate gender equality and women’s empowerment (GEWE) concerns, with support in mainstreaming gender equality in all functions following a gender audit and capacity needs assessment. Follow-up initiatives included the introduction of a HeforShe Advocacy strategy promoting male MP champions for GEWE and the production/dissemination of a handbook on gender mainstreaming and programming. Output 2 The Government of Tanzania has enhanced capacity to comply with International and Regional human rights standards and implement recommendations from human rights mechanisms, including those related to access to justice for women, children and other vulnerable groups. There is a clear recognition that during this period there have been some challenging developments in the country however, despite these developments quite a number of important activities have been advanced under UNDAP II. The UN reports that the Government of Tanzania has increased its capacity to comply with human rights standards during the reporting period, especially in areas related to access to justice for women and children and other vulnerable groups. Legal Aid services were expanded through a range of measures including the roll-out of a MOU between the Ministry of Constitutional and Legal Affairs, Ministry of Home Affairs, Tanzania Police Force and Tanzania Prison Services for improved access by Legal Aid Providers to prisons and other places of detention plus the piloting of a legal aid coordination mechanism which reduced bureaucracy, improved sub-national oversight and provided clear referral pathways. Furthermore, following technical and financial assistance to Tanzania Network of Legal Aid Providers (TANLAP) 127,452 people (84,932 females and 42,550 males) in Kagera region benefitted from legal aid services who would otherwise been left unserved. In addition, access to justice specifically for minors was also improved with UN support. Following trainings of 500+ personnel attached to 130 Juvenile Courts, magistrate adherences to statutes of limitations (adhering to the maximum time after a criminal act within which legal proceeding shall be initiated) was increased and reviews of past cases were undertaken, with fewer children sent to prison as a result. In addition, child protection was integrated into the training curriculum of an estimated 4,500 community-based paralegals and the Zanzibar Kadhi Court Rules were amended to include the best interest of the child and presence of Social Workers during hearings. Further, the Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Elderly and Children (MHCDGEC) signed Community Rehabilitation Programme Guidelines (CRP), formalizing diversion for children in conflict with the law. Rather than focusing on punishment, diversion programmes aim at rehabilitation of the offender and prevention of further offences by seeking to address the underlying factors that contribute to criminal behaviour. Tanzania mainland now has three such CRPs operating independent of UN financial support with six more in development. Output 3 Relevant Governance stakeholders have increased capacities to generate, analyse and use evidence to formulate and implement gender responsive, inclusive policies, strategies and programmes for the most marginalized. With UN support, the Government of Tanzania met their reporting obligations with submissions for the CEDAW Mid Term Review and the Beijing Platform for Action 25+. The Government also presented their 2019 Voluntary National Review (VNR) at the High-Level Political Forum in New York in July 2019. In the lead-up, the MHCDGEC was assisted to engage with the VNR national technical team to produce a Gender Report for the relevant SDGs, thereby ensuring GEWE concerns were strongly represented. The UN also reports that their support has ensured that relevant Governance stakeholders now are more capable of generating, analysing and using evidence to inform policies, strategies and programmes. One important example includes the expansion of the Simplified Birth Registration System (SBRS) for children under five from 11 to 13 regions with approximately 3.6 million now registered and issued with a birth certificate. This is an increase of the overall birth certification rate in the 13 regions from 12.7% (2012) to 42.9% on the mainland and 9.3% (2012) to 80.2% in Zanzibar and represents significant progress under SDG 16.9.1. Another example concerns gender responsive budgeting where relevant stakeholders now have improved their capacity to cost, track and report on public resource allocations following the finalisation of Guidelines to operationalize the Gender and Development Policy (2016) in Zanzibar and the development of a matrix to track resource allocations across MDAs and LGAs developed by the Gender Mainstreaming Working Group-Macro Policy. Progress towards Outcomes results Womens Political Participation and Leadership Interventions under this outcome were intended to increase the number of women who will stand for upcoming elections. During this period some of the key results included: 1. Capacities of 289 key stakeholders (232 women; 57 men) from Mainland and Zanzibar were strengthened on gender gaps in five election related laws through training sessions. 2. Information Lab has been set up to raise awareness on violence against women in politics.The information Laboratory has a role to collect, analyse, disseminate data and raise awareness on VAWP and has been established in collaboration with the University of Dar es Salaam Department of Political Science and the Institute of Gender Studies. A total of 32 women aspirants have been supported by the Information Lab. 3. Capacity of 402 political party leaders (202 women, 200 men) were trained on their role to advance WLPP and hence their capacities strengthened on this area. 4. Three women were appointed to the Ethical Committee by ZEC as a result of policy level advocacy and dialogues with the Zanzibar Electoral Committee. 5. Advocacy through TWPG and WROs undertaken on the inclusion of GEWE principles in the Political Parties (Amendment) Act, 2019. 6. A comprehensive training manual to strengthen capacities of political parties on women’s leadership and political participation was developed. furthermore, a comprehensive Training of trainers manual and workbook for women aspiring for political leadership was adopted. 7. Two political parties’ manifestos have specific provisions indicating commitment to promote WLPP and unofficial data from parliamentary parties indicated an increase of 7% of nominations of women for Parliament positions. 8. In 2019, all the 19 registered political parties adopted a formula to guide the selection of women aspirants for the transformational leadership trainings. 9. A total of 202 women leaders from all registered political parties were trained on their role to promote women’s leadership and participation and committed to influence nominations. 10. An assessment on the strength and weaknesses of women wings in political parties was conducted to identify gaps and provide recommendations for improvement. 11. The Tanzania Chapter of African Women Leaders Network was launched on the 26th of February 2020. Over 200 women and young women leaders in politics, academia, research, civil society, civil service, the private sector, women living in rural areas, and the media are members and participated in the launch. 12. A total of 361 Womens Rights Organisations and networks are implementing various interventions to advance women’s leadership and political participation in Tanzania Mainland and Zanzibar. Progress towards Outcome Ending Violence Against Women and Children 1. The Government became a signatory to the WeProtect Statement of Action, which presents opportunities for Tanzania to access global expertise in formulating policies, legislation and programmes to tackle online exploitation and abuse of children. 2. Increased advocacy for the inclusion of interventions (and budgets) to implement the National Plan of Action to End Violence Against Women and Children in the national planning and budgeting guidelines for 2018/2019 resulted in 8 key Ministries committing USD 2million. 3. Increased efforts to strengthen violence prevention and response services resulted in the renovation of six Mainland and 3 Zanzibar Police and Gender Desks. Training of Police Officers was also done in order to build their capacity to provide a comprehensive, respectful and effective response to violence cases. The Tanzania Police Force was also supported to develop national Guidelines on the Gender Responsive Reporting System, which has been disseminated to police stations nationwide. 4. Development of a mobile phobe application that will be linked to the District case management system ( DCMS) and hence improve case and data management as it will enable Social Welfare Officers to receive information on initial investigation of child protection cases. 5. Strengthened capacity of service providers to ensure accessibility and availability of essential services for women survivors of violence and Social workers in Dodoma and Shinyanga assigned to provide psychosocial support for women traders and vendors in the marketplace. 6. Advocacy efforts resulted in reporting of 2,163 cases of violence against women and girls following activities organised by community and youth activists, community development officers and healthcare workers across six districts. furthermore, a total of 14,245 cases of violnce against women were reported at Police Gender and Children Desks in Mainland and 752 cases reported in Zanzibar. 7. In the education sector, the UN partnership with the Ministry of Education and Presidents Office-Regional and Local Government resulted in training of teachers to provide guidance and counselling services and to assist establishment of TUSEME ( Lets Speak Out) Clubs. 2,227 primary schools were reached in Mbeya, Iringa and Njombe. In Zanzibar, 463 Guidance and Counselling Teachers in 232 schools have been trained and 138,912 students recived messages on the prevention and response to violnce.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) i Tanzania är designat för att stärka FN-systemets samstämmighet och effektivitet på nationell nivå, som bidrag till Tanzanias arbete för hållbar fattigdomsminskning och förverkligandet av mänskliga rättigheter. Den breda verksamheten motsvarar flera av de mål som anges i den svenska resultatstrategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Tanzania 2013-2019. Fyra av totalt tolv resultatområden är särskilt relevanta för den svenska strategin: god samhällstyrning/mänskliga rättigheter/gender; våld mot kvinnor och barn; kvinnligt deltagande och politiskt ledarskp; samt ekonomisk tillväxt och sysselsättning. Den svenska strategin identifierar kvinnor, barn och ungdomar som prioriterade målgrupper vilket också reflekteras väl i de områden för stöd som Sida valt.
UNDAP II är helt i linje med givarnas s k Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) och med Tanzanias nationella visioner (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II är också utvecklad i linje med Tanzanias femårsplan 2015/16 - 2020/21 och med de globala hållbarhets- och utvecklingsmålen. Programmet bidrar till FN:s fokus på förbättrade resultat och samstämmighet genom att sammanföra ett 20-tal FN-organs planering, budgetering och rapportering i ett gemensamt resultatramverk för Tanzania. UNDAP II minskar därför i viss utsträckning även dubbelarbete för nationella partner såväl som för FN organisationer.
Det svenska stödet ska ges via One UN Fund, i linje med Sveriges politik att stödja ett sammanhållet och mer effektivt FN-arbete i länderna (FN-reformen "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP är det av FN utsedda FN-organ som administrerar One UN Fund (genom UNDP-kontoret i Dar es Salaam och huvudkontoret i New York), och UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) FN:s högste representant i Tanzania, varför båda dessa står som FN:s undertecknande av SAA med Sida. I linje med Sveriges resultatstrategi för Tanzania kommer stödet inte att gå generellt till UNDAP, utan som öronmärkt till de fyra nämnda resultatområdena.
Medlen kommer att fördelas enligt nedan till följande resultatområden: - Ekonomisk tillväxt och anställning: 125 000 000 SEK - God samhällsstyrning och mänskliga rättigheter: 82 500 000 SEK - Kvinnors politiska deltagande: 50 000 000 SEK - Våld mot kvinnor och barn: 42 500 000 SEK

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the co-ordination and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzania's efforts to achieve sustainable poverty reduction and the implementation of human rights. The broad business corresponds to several of the goals set out in the Swedish Development Cooperation Development Strategy Tanzania 2013-2019. Four out of twelve results areas are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy: good governance / human rights / gender; violence against women and children; female participation and political leadership; as well as economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and adolescents as prioritized target groups, which also reflects well in the areas of support chosen by Sida.
UNDAP II is fully in line with the donors' Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) and with Tanzania's National Visions (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II is also developed in line with Tanzania's five-year plan 2015/16 - 2020/21 and with global sustainability and development goals. The program contributes to the UN's focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together 20 UN agencies' planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore, to a certain extent, also reduces duplication for national partners as well as UN organizations.
Swedish support will be provided through One UN Fund, in line with Sweden's policy to support a coherent and more effective UN work in the countries (UN reform "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP is the UN-designated UN body that manages the One UN Fund (through the UNDP office in Dar es Salaam and the headquarters in New York), and the UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) UN High Representative in Tanzania, why both of them stand as UN signing of SAA with Sida. In line with Sweden's earnings strategy for Tanzania, the support will not go to UNDAP generally, but as earmarked for the four mentioned results areas.
The funds will be distributed as follows to the following results areas: - Economic growth and employment: SEK 125,000,000 - Good governance and human rights: 82 500 000 SEK - Women's political participation: SEK 50,000,000 - Violence against women and children: 42 500 000 SEK

sector.narrative: Public sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Progress towards Outcomes results Economic Growth and Employment The outcome area comprises of 13 UN agencies contributing towards three outputs, see below. The outcome group is currently contributing to two Joint Programmes, one in Kigoma (the Kigoma Joint Programme) and one in Zanzibar (the Zanzibar Joint Programme) The outcome group is coordinated by ILO and have a designated person coordinating monitoring and results reporting. The group have monthly meetings where the different UN agencies are present. This is an opportunity for the UN agencies to share lessons learnt and exchange ideas and find synergies between themselves. In March 2019 the outcome group had a joint retreat focusing on the MSD approach to learn from each other and deepen the understanding of the concept. The EoS is present in the outcome meetings and it gives a good opportunity to get an insights of the work of the outcome group. The delivery rate for the outcome Economic Growth and employment for the period 2018-2019 is 83% of annual targets fully or close to fully achieved. Output 1 Relevant MDAs and selected LGAs have strengthened capacities to review and implement evidence based economic policies and plans to be business enabling, environmentally sustainable and gender responsive: In Zanzibar, technical and financial assistance contributed to the finalisation of the Agriculture Sector Development Programme and the Youth Development Policy. On mainland inputs supported the finalization of the Microfinance Act and Microfinance Regulations. At sub-national level 33 regional and LGAs were enabled to create national plans, budgets and investments that integrated poverty, environmental and gender concerns. Concrete examples are six Regional Investment Guidelines designed to attract local/foreign investments and nine private partnerships resulting in revenue generating facilities. Training in Gender responsive budgeting have provided eight LGAs better equipped to manage district development funds for women and youth, demonstrated by a 26,5% increase in allocations and utilization over the last two years and the figures rised from TZS 592.8 million to 796.5 million. Input on Output 2 Relevant institutions have enhanced capacities to provide gender-responsive, market-oriented, quality programmes, products and services Following UN technical advice and financial support, 74 institutions with national or local reach delivered market-oriented and gender responsive training programmes and business development support products and services. This includes 8 skills development institutions such as the NCT and ZITOD, leading to the successful graduation of the first batch of 52 apprentices from the Zanzibar Quality Apprenticeship Programme in Hotel Operations. Strengthen the capacity of Tanzania Investment Centre to manage e-regulations platforms, which has made it easier for investors and entrepreneurs to start a business Through trainings and technical advice, 11 LGAs and 3 agricultural training institutions have strengthened capacity to provide agri-business development support including on good agronomic practices, climate-smart agriculture, and entrepreneurship. This will contribute to improved access to quality extension advice for women and men farmers and entrepreneurs. Input on Output 3 Micro, small, medium and large enterprises, in particular those led by women and youth, have strengthened capacities to increase productivity, add value to their products and access markets More than 38 000 micro enterprises (both on mainland and Zanzibar) have strengthened capacities to increase productivity, add value to their products and access markets. The assistance from UNDAPII has ranged from providing trainings on GAP and construction of aggregation centres and storage facilities (28, 500 famers have reported a decrease in post-harvest losses from 40% to 27%) to facilitating links between farmers and traders. In Zanzibar, 180 primarily women seaweed farmers were provided with knowledge and skills to embark on sea cucumber farming as a new livelihood opportunity, while training of 40 youth (60% women) on value addition led to improved packaging and increased competitiveness. Access to finance initiatives led to more than 35,220 people (W: 21,504, M: 11,343, Y: 2,373) accessing financial services through savings groups, SACCOS, community banks and commercial banks. Additional 4,170,503 people (55% women) were reached through an IFAD loan. Progress towards Outcomes result Democratic Governance, Human Rights & Gender Equality The outcome area comprises of 4 UN agencies contributing towards three outputs, see below. The outcome group is coordinated by UNDP and it has a designated person who is responsible for coordinating, monitoring and results reporting. The group does meet every now and then, but it is not clear how regularly this occurs and whether all the involved UN agencies are always present. EoS has only been invited to and present at 2 outcome meetings during the period Aug 2018 – Aug 2020, which substantially limits the EoS’ opportunity to get an insight into the work of the outcome group. Minutes from potential meetings where EoS has not been invited have also not been shared. This is a pity since such meetings are an opportunity for the UN agencies to share lessons learnt and exchange ideas and find synergies between themselves, from which the EoS can learn and understand the effectiveness of the outcome group and the work it delivers. Output 1 Citizens of Tanzania especially the most marginalized have increased capacity to engage and participate in policy formulation, implementation and monitoring. During the reporting period, 119 CSOs were supported to engage with parliamentary committees and/or participate in public hearings across a range of issues, including discussions around the Political Parties (Amendment) Bill, the Finance Bill and sectoral budget reviews. The National Assembly was also enabled to better integrate gender equality and women’s empowerment (GEWE) concerns, with support in mainstreaming gender equality in all functions following a gender audit and capacity needs assessment. Follow-up initiatives included the introduction of a HeforShe Advocacy strategy promoting male MP champions for GEWE and the production/dissemination of a handbook on gender mainstreaming and programming. Output 2 The Government of Tanzania has enhanced capacity to comply with International and Regional human rights standards and implement recommendations from human rights mechanisms, including those related to access to justice for women, children and other vulnerable groups. There is a clear recognition that during this period there have been some challenging developments in the country however, despite these developments quite a number of important activities have been advanced under UNDAP II. The UN reports that the Government of Tanzania has increased its capacity to comply with human rights standards during the reporting period, especially in areas related to access to justice for women and children and other vulnerable groups. Legal Aid services were expanded through a range of measures including the roll-out of a MOU between the Ministry of Constitutional and Legal Affairs, Ministry of Home Affairs, Tanzania Police Force and Tanzania Prison Services for improved access by Legal Aid Providers to prisons and other places of detention plus the piloting of a legal aid coordination mechanism which reduced bureaucracy, improved sub-national oversight and provided clear referral pathways. Furthermore, following technical and financial assistance to Tanzania Network of Legal Aid Providers (TANLAP) 127,452 people (84,932 females and 42,550 males) in Kagera region benefitted from legal aid services who would otherwise been left unserved. In addition, access to justice specifically for minors was also improved with UN support. Following trainings of 500+ personnel attached to 130 Juvenile Courts, magistrate adherences to statutes of limitations (adhering to the maximum time after a criminal act within which legal proceeding shall be initiated) was increased and reviews of past cases were undertaken, with fewer children sent to prison as a result. In addition, child protection was integrated into the training curriculum of an estimated 4,500 community-based paralegals and the Zanzibar Kadhi Court Rules were amended to include the best interest of the child and presence of Social Workers during hearings. Further, the Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Elderly and Children (MHCDGEC) signed Community Rehabilitation Programme Guidelines (CRP), formalizing diversion for children in conflict with the law. Rather than focusing on punishment, diversion programmes aim at rehabilitation of the offender and prevention of further offences by seeking to address the underlying factors that contribute to criminal behaviour. Tanzania mainland now has three such CRPs operating independent of UN financial support with six more in development. Output 3 Relevant Governance stakeholders have increased capacities to generate, analyse and use evidence to formulate and implement gender responsive, inclusive policies, strategies and programmes for the most marginalized. With UN support, the Government of Tanzania met their reporting obligations with submissions for the CEDAW Mid Term Review and the Beijing Platform for Action 25+. The Government also presented their 2019 Voluntary National Review (VNR) at the High-Level Political Forum in New York in July 2019. In the lead-up, the MHCDGEC was assisted to engage with the VNR national technical team to produce a Gender Report for the relevant SDGs, thereby ensuring GEWE concerns were strongly represented. The UN also reports that their support has ensured that relevant Governance stakeholders now are more capable of generating, analysing and using evidence to inform policies, strategies and programmes. One important example includes the expansion of the Simplified Birth Registration System (SBRS) for children under five from 11 to 13 regions with approximately 3.6 million now registered and issued with a birth certificate. This is an increase of the overall birth certification rate in the 13 regions from 12.7% (2012) to 42.9% on the mainland and 9.3% (2012) to 80.2% in Zanzibar and represents significant progress under SDG 16.9.1. Another example concerns gender responsive budgeting where relevant stakeholders now have improved their capacity to cost, track and report on public resource allocations following the finalisation of Guidelines to operationalize the Gender and Development Policy (2016) in Zanzibar and the development of a matrix to track resource allocations across MDAs and LGAs developed by the Gender Mainstreaming Working Group-Macro Policy. Progress towards Outcomes results Womens Political Participation and Leadership Interventions under this outcome were intended to increase the number of women who will stand for upcoming elections. During this period some of the key results included: 1. Capacities of 289 key stakeholders (232 women; 57 men) from Mainland and Zanzibar were strengthened on gender gaps in five election related laws through training sessions. 2. Information Lab has been set up to raise awareness on violence against women in politics.The information Laboratory has a role to collect, analyse, disseminate data and raise awareness on VAWP and has been established in collaboration with the University of Dar es Salaam Department of Political Science and the Institute of Gender Studies. A total of 32 women aspirants have been supported by the Information Lab. 3. Capacity of 402 political party leaders (202 women, 200 men) were trained on their role to advance WLPP and hence their capacities strengthened on this area. 4. Three women were appointed to the Ethical Committee by ZEC as a result of policy level advocacy and dialogues with the Zanzibar Electoral Committee. 5. Advocacy through TWPG and WROs undertaken on the inclusion of GEWE principles in the Political Parties (Amendment) Act, 2019. 6. A comprehensive training manual to strengthen capacities of political parties on women’s leadership and political participation was developed. furthermore, a comprehensive Training of trainers manual and workbook for women aspiring for political leadership was adopted. 7. Two political parties’ manifestos have specific provisions indicating commitment to promote WLPP and unofficial data from parliamentary parties indicated an increase of 7% of nominations of women for Parliament positions. 8. In 2019, all the 19 registered political parties adopted a formula to guide the selection of women aspirants for the transformational leadership trainings. 9. A total of 202 women leaders from all registered political parties were trained on their role to promote women’s leadership and participation and committed to influence nominations. 10. An assessment on the strength and weaknesses of women wings in political parties was conducted to identify gaps and provide recommendations for improvement. 11. The Tanzania Chapter of African Women Leaders Network was launched on the 26th of February 2020. Over 200 women and young women leaders in politics, academia, research, civil society, civil service, the private sector, women living in rural areas, and the media are members and participated in the launch. 12. A total of 361 Womens Rights Organisations and networks are implementing various interventions to advance women’s leadership and political participation in Tanzania Mainland and Zanzibar. Progress towards Outcome Ending Violence Against Women and Children 1. The Government became a signatory to the WeProtect Statement of Action, which presents opportunities for Tanzania to access global expertise in formulating policies, legislation and programmes to tackle online exploitation and abuse of children. 2. Increased advocacy for the inclusion of interventions (and budgets) to implement the National Plan of Action to End Violence Against Women and Children in the national planning and budgeting guidelines for 2018/2019 resulted in 8 key Ministries committing USD 2million. 3. Increased efforts to strengthen violence prevention and response services resulted in the renovation of six Mainland and 3 Zanzibar Police and Gender Desks. Training of Police Officers was also done in order to build their capacity to provide a comprehensive, respectful and effective response to violence cases. The Tanzania Police Force was also supported to develop national Guidelines on the Gender Responsive Reporting System, which has been disseminated to police stations nationwide. 4. Development of a mobile phobe application that will be linked to the District case management system ( DCMS) and hence improve case and data management as it will enable Social Welfare Officers to receive information on initial investigation of child protection cases. 5. Strengthened capacity of service providers to ensure accessibility and availability of essential services for women survivors of violence and Social workers in Dodoma and Shinyanga assigned to provide psychosocial support for women traders and vendors in the marketplace. 6. Advocacy efforts resulted in reporting of 2,163 cases of violence against women and girls following activities organised by community and youth activists, community development officers and healthcare workers across six districts. furthermore, a total of 14,245 cases of violnce against women were reported at Police Gender and Children Desks in Mainland and 752 cases reported in Zanzibar. 7. In the education sector, the UN partnership with the Ministry of Education and Presidents Office-Regional and Local Government resulted in training of teachers to provide guidance and counselling services and to assist establishment of TUSEME ( Lets Speak Out) Clubs. 2,227 primary schools were reached in Mbeya, Iringa and Njombe. In Zanzibar, 463 Guidance and Counselling Teachers in 232 schools have been trained and 138,912 students recived messages on the prevention and response to violnce.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Gemensamt påverkansarbete för SRHR i Uganda
Joint Advocacy for SRHR in Uganda (JAS programme)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen är ett programstöd till en lokal organisation, Centre for Health, Human Rights and Development (CEHURD), med fokus på gemensamt påverkansarbete inom sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa & rättigheter (SRHR) i Uganda. Stödet avser att bygga en progressiv gräsrotsrörelse för påverkansarbete inom SRHR, vilket är en nyckelpelare i CEHURD:s strategiska plan 2020-2024.
CEHURD har ansökt om SEK 75 000 000 för att genomföra programmet under perioden 2020 - 2023. Programmet utgör en huvuddel av organisationens strategiska plan med en uppskattad total budget på SEK 122 371 959.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This contribution is a program support to the Centre for Health, Human Rights and Development (CEHURD) with focus on joint advocacy for Sexual & Reproductive Health & Rights (SRHR) in Uganda. The support is proposed to work on building a progressive SRHR advocacy movement which is a key pillar of CEHURD's strategic plan 2020-2024.
CEHURD has applied for 75 000 000 SEK från the Embassy of Sweden to implement this program during 2020 - 2023. The program is part of the overall 5-year strategic plan of the organization, which is estimated at 122 371 959 SEK.

The goal of the program is to have a progressive social movement boldly challenging the deep structures affecting the realization of SRHR in Uganda. The proposed goal for this programme is linked to CEHURD’s strategic goal of “increased participation amongst rights holders, transparency and accountability amongst duty bearers towards the realization of the right to health” and is a part of CEHURD's strategic plan 2020 - 2024. The programme goal will be achieved through five specific objectives: - To enhance a sustainable SRHR movement that will collaborate and collectively advocate for SRHR in Uganda - To nurture and sustain grassroots progressive social movements that engage with deep structures on SRHR at the individual and systemic levels, hold duty bearers accountable; and collectively organize towards the realization of SRHR. - To strengthen legal rights and enhance access to justice for communities, SRHR advocates and service providers in Uganda. (Strategic Litigation Programme) To generate evidence to inform SRHR advocacy and programming in Uganda. - To strengthen CEHURD's institutional capacity and operational efficiency to deliver on its mandate

participating-org.narrative: CEHURD/The Center for Health, Human Rights and Development

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Some results achieved during the inception phase Jan-Jun 2020: During this inception period CEHURD and partners mainly implemented preparatory activities for programme roll-out. This period was disrupted by the Covid-19 pandemic from end of Mar 2020 with strict measurements on movement and public gatherings put in place by the Ugandan government. During the reporting period CEHURD has engaged with School of Law and School of Gender and Women and Women studies – Makerere University to establish a formal working relationship for their planned research studies and baseline. While the plan was to conduct research on how masculinities and norms affect the realization of SRHR in Uganda, the outbreak of the pandemic brought to light some more serious issues that continue to affect SRHR in Uganda. CEHURD has therefore decided to adapt the research to also capture emerging SRHR issues arising from Covid-19 and how the pandemic has led to retrogression in the realization of SRHR in Uganda. CEHURD has despite the interruption of the pandemic been able to make progress against the five programme objectives. This has been possible due to adaptations made on programme implementation approaches. Some activities were however postponed to the next reporting period. The pandemic has also created new opportunities for advocacy on SRHR which has informed the changes proposed in the revised year 1 work plan and budget. Collaboration with other partners especially civil society has been proven very important during this pandemic. CEHURD states that is has been clear that sections of the health sector that have an amplified voice have received attention much faster from the government. During the inception period CEHURD has done organisational capacity assessments (OCA) of 6 national partners that they will collaborate with during the implementation of the programme. The partners are Akina Mama wa Afrika (AMwA); Human Rights Awareness and Promotional Forum (HRAPF); Reach a Hand Uganda (RAHU); Coalition for Health Promotion and Social Development (HEPS – Uganda); National Forum of People Living with HIV/AIDS in Uganda (NAFOPHANU); and Network of key population service organisations LTD (UNESO). The programme has been introduced to Ministry of Health to get their buy-in and support at both national and district level. The Director of Curative Services in the Ministry, Dr Charles Olaro, has been identified as a champion for the programme. With the country lock down due to the pandemic media interventions has been recognized by CEHURD as one of the most affective approaches for strategic advocacy and communication on issues of SRHR and impact of Covid-19. CEHURD invested quite a lot in media interventions that heighted the plight of SRHR services during the implementation of the national response towards Covid-19, calling for the prioritisation of SRHR as an essential service that could not be closed down during the lockdown. They also conducted several online meetings to discuss Maternal health issues in Uganda in the face of Covid-19 and attended webinars organised by other partners as key note speakers. The media activities including public statements and open letters to policy makers together with partners yielded successes as the President of Uganda and the National Task Force on Covid-19 relaxed the transportation measures for expecting mothers and those who were sick with pre-existing conditions. The JAS advisory committee has been formed with members representing various organisations involved in the different thematic areas of the JAS programme. The programme has been introduced to the district level in five pilot districts where implementation will be done through Community Health Advocates (CHA’s). Also these CHA’s have gone through a OCA process. CEHURD had not planned to do much of strategic litigation under programme during the inception phase. However, due to the Covid-19 pandemic and the lock down many SRHR and HR violations has taken place. CEHURD has therefore done more strategic litigation during this period than initially planned for and this support has continued as the violations continue to rise. Cases have increased the demand for rapid legal responses which calls for reallocation of resources to facilitate this. They have also strengthened their legal services through establishing a legal aid clinic and pursuing the registration of CEHURD as a legal aid service provider. They have also realised the need to procure a better toll-free line system that can record and handle more than one call at a time. Reallocation for more funds for the toll-free helpline has therefore been suggested in the revised work plan and budget. To strengthen institutional capacity CEHURD staff has been oriented on the new strategic plan as well as the JAS programme. They went through a successful board transition and strengthening of the governance structure. Identification of the JAS team was done as well as seven new staff were brought on board. They also procured 2 new vehicles, 2 big photocopiers, desktop computers, laptops and printers to enhance the delivery of their work with the JAS programme. The Embassy assisted CEHURD during this reporting period with an RBM consultant from NIRAS to revise their result matrix and develop an M&E framework. The consultant also did RBM training for CEHURD and the national partners to together be able to improve the goals, objectives and indicators that an advocacy programme can deliver on.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Health support for women, children and youth in Zambia
COVID-19 Hälsostöd för kvinnor, barn och ungdomar i Zambia

description.narrative: Determinants for maternal and child health will be measured by four impact indicators: maternal mortality, child and newborn deaths and children under five who are stunted. The impact will be measured through a mini-DHS in 2019-2020 and compared to the 2013-2014 DHS. The following improvements in health outcomes are planned (in the target Provinces): - The Maternal Mortality Ratio reduced by 25% from baseline - The Newborn Mortality Rate reduced by 10% from baseline - The Under 5 Mortality Rate reduced by 15% from baseline - The Under 5 Stunting Rate reduced by 3% from baseline The objectives of the intervention are: - Increasing availability and readiness of quality health & nutrition services for mothers, newborns, children and adolescents in two target provinces in Zambia. - Increasing demand and uptake of physically, culturally, and financially accessible services for mothers, newborns, children and adolescents in two target provinces in Zambia. - Strengthening Health Systems at national and sub-national levels as necessary to providing an enabling environment for effective RMNCAH&N service delivery.

New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The intervention will contribute to improving the health of women, children and adolescents by increased access to and demand for quality-assured health services at district level. The activities at district/primary health care level will be complimented by support to strengthen the national health system in order to maximize sustainability.
The intervention has been developed by Ministry of Health, Ministry of Community Development, Mother and Child Health, Ministry of Finance, civil society, Sida and DFID in consultation with the major health actors in Zambia (UN, USAID, World Bank and EU). The initial plan was that two health ministries would jointly implement the contribution. However, on 18 September 2015, the Government made the unpredictable and abrupt decision that all health issues should again be managed by the Ministry of Health. As of 2012, primary health care including maternal and child health was managed by the Ministry of Community Development, Mother and Child Health. The decision to manage all health issues under the same ministry is most welcome as the separation of primary health care from health system building blocks (policy, medicines and supplies, human resources, information systems, health financing etc.) presented formidable challenges to health development in Zambia. This grant will thus be managed by one (Ministry of Health) instead of two ministries which will greatly facilitate and improve coordination, governance, management, reporting, procurement, supervision, capacity building etc. At the same time, the startup of the implementation is expected to be slowed down due to the administrative changes needed. The appraisal of this contribution was made prior to the Government’s decision to merge all health activities to one ministry. Capacity and risk assessments have been made for both ministries and evaluations show that the Ministry of Health has better governance, management and human resource capacity. As a result, Sida considers that a decision can be made on this contribution despite the significant changes in the Government structure.
The intervention follows international and national policies and guidelines for cost-effective and high-impact reproductive, maternal, newborn, child and adolescent health (RMNCAH) and nutrition services. Three out of a total of 10 provinces (central, eastern and southern) have been chosen following analysis of health indicators, socioeconomic data and a mapping of partner organizations work. Sweden will support interventions in eastern and southern provinces and DFID is expected to support the central province.
The Swedish contribution is MSEK 408.8 for 2015-2019. The majority of funds (82%) will support activities at district level. The remaining part (18%) will be managed centrally by Ministry of Health as well as by provincial medical offices. The initial installment of MSEK 70 will cover for preparatory activities including procurement of supplies and renovation and extension of health facilities. As a result of public financial management limitations of the Ministry of Finance, the funds will be channeled directly to the Ministry of Health and not through treasury. This approach will change should public financial management improve.
The overarching goal with the contribution is to improve the health situation in initially eastern and southern provinces as follows:
- Reduce maternal mortality by 25% compared with 201 - Reduce newborn mortality by 10% compared with 2014 - Reduce child mortality by 15% compared with 2014 - Reduce the child stunting rate by 3% compared with 2014
This will be achieved by three outcomes:
1. Effective RMNCAH services available in initially two provinces 2. Increase community and client demand and uptake of RMNCAH services in initially two provinces 3. Health system capacity strengthening to enable effective RMNCAH service delivery at national level and in two target provinces
The strategic interventions that will be supported include:
- Capacity building for health care providers, community-based volunteers and managerial staff at central, province and district levels - Recruitment of supplementary human resources - Procurement of health commodities and supplies - Renovation and expansion of health facilities at district level and construction of maternity waiting homes - RMNCAH and nutrition service promotion and health education - Use of quality health information for decision making and management - Effective financial management (at all levels of the health system) - Sector and partner harmonization and coordination for RMNCAH
After a period of fragmentation and volatility of health aid to Zambia, Sweden and UK are keen to revitalize a sector-wide approach to health. During the last few years, and following the corruption scandal in the health sector in 2009, most external health resources have been channeled to non-governmental organizations. The health ministries have since improved their governance and management capacity systems partly through technical and financial support from the Sida. Sweden and UK wants to revive the sector-wide approach according to International Health partnership principles (agreement on priorities that are reflected in a single national health strategy, resource inputs recorded on budget and in line with national priorities, financial management systems harmonized and aligned, us of national procurement systems, joint monitoring of process and results, well-coordinated technical support). Performance-based funding in combination with a sector-wide approach would increase ownership, lower transaction costs and reduce duplication. It is hoped that this contribution will contribute to increased equity and sustainability, improved aid effectiveness and health sector efficiency.
Sweden will be the first country to contribute to this basked fund but later on DFID will join (2015 or 2016). USAID is also showing interest to increase its funding directly to the Government and through this basket fund. Additional risk mitigating contributions will be developed in collaboriton with DFID. Procurement activities will commence during autumn 2015.
Sida considers that the contribution's results-based component is in line with the organizations contribution rule. Payments resulting from the variable tranche will contribute to the programme, as outlined in the draft agreement. These funds will also be subject to auditing as part of the programme. Consultations have been held with Sida's audit advisors.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen ska bidra till att främja kvinnors, barns och ungdomars grundläggande hälsa genom ökad tillgång till och efterfrågan av en kvalitativ hälso- och sjukvård på distriktsnivå. Ansatserna på distrikts/primärvårdsnivå kommer att kompletteras med stöd för att stärka det nationella hälso- och sjukvårdssystemet. Det senare sker i syfte att säkra resultatens långsiktiga hållbarhet.
Stödet har utarbetats av hälsoministeriet, ”Ministry of Community Development, Mother and Child Health” finansministeriet, civilsamhället, Sida och DFID i samråd med de huvudsakliga hälsoaktörerna i Zambia (FN, USAID, Världsbanken och EU). Den ursprungliga planen var att två hälsoministerier ("Ministry of Health" och "Ministry of Community Development, Mother and Child Health") gemensamt skulle genomföra insatsen. Den 18 september 2015 fattade dock regeringen det oförutsägbara och plötsligta beslutet att alla hälsofrågor återigen ska förvaltas av hälsoministeriet. Från 2012 administrerade ”Ministry of Community Development, Mother and Child Health” primärvården inklusive mödra- och barnhälsovården. Beslutet att återigen låta ett ministerium hantera alla hälsofrågor är mycket välkommet eftersom separeringen av primärvården från hälsosystemet (policy, läkemedel och förnödenheter, personal, informationssystem, hälsofinansiering etc.) var utmanande för hälsoutvecklingen i Zambia. Denna insats kommer således att hanteras av ett (hälsoministeriet) i stället för två ministerier vilket i hög grad kommer att underlätta och förbättra samordning, styrning, rapportering, ägarskap, upphandling, övervakning, kapacitetsuppbyggnad etc. Samtidigt kommer starten av insatsen ta längre tid på grund av nödvändiga administrativa förändringar inom förvaltningen. Beredningen av denna insats gjordes innan regeringens beslut att förena all hälsovård till ett ministerium. All kapacitet- och riskbedömning har gjorts av två ministerier och utvärderingarna beskriver att hälsoministeriet har bättre styr-, förvaltning- och personalkapacitet. Därför bedömer Sida att ett beslut om denna insats kan fattas trots denna stora förändring.
Interventionerna följer internationella och nationella policy och riktlinjer för kostnadseffektiva och hög-effektiva ansatser inom reproduktiv-, mödra-, nyfödd-, barn- och ungdomshälsa (RMNCAH) samt nutrition. Tre utav totalt 10 provinser i Zambia (centrala, södra och östra) har valts ut efter analys av hälsoindikatorer, socioekonomisk data samt kartläggning av andra givares arbete. Sverige kommer att stödja interventioner i södra och östra provinserna. DFID förväntas stödja centrala provinsen.
Det svenska bidraget är 408.8 MSEK för perioden 2015-2019. Huvuddelen av pengarna (82%) kommer att stödja aktiviteter på distriktsnivå. Den resterande delen (18%) kommer att hanteras centralt av hälsoministeriet samt av hälsomyndigheter på provinsnivå. Den första utbetalningen om MSEK 70 miljoner ämnar täcka kostnader för upphandling av förnödenheter och varor samt renovering och tillbyggnad av vårdinrättningar på distriktsnivå. På grund av brister hos finansministeriet, avseende offentlig finansiell styrning, kommer det svenska bidraget att kanaliseras direkt till hälsoministeriet och inte via det Zambiska finansministeriet (treasury). Skulle den offentliga finansiella styrningen förbättras, kommer Sida att ompröva detta beslut.
De övergripande målen med insatsen är att förbättra hälsosituationen i framför allt södra och östra provinserna enligt följande:
- Minska mödradödligheten med 25% jämfört med 2014 - Minska dödligheten bland nyfödda barn med 10% jämfört med 2014 - Minska barnadödligheten med 15% jämfört med 2014 - Minska andelen kortväxta barn med 3% jämfört med 2014
Detta kommer att ske via tre övergripande komponenter:
1. Tillgång till effektiva, säkra och högkvalitativa hälsoinsatser i två provinser 2. Ökad efterfrågan och användning av RMNCAH tjänster i två provinser 3. Förbättrade hälsovårdssystem på nationell nivå samt i två provinser för att möjligöra bättre RMNCAH samt att säkra resultatens långsiktiga hållbarhet
Följande aktiviteter kommer genomföras för att uppnå de förväntade resultaten:
- Kapacitetsuppbyggnad för vårdgivare, samhällsbaserade volontärer och ledande personal på central-, provins- och distriktsnivå - Rekrytering av kompletterande personal - Upphandling av kompletterande förnödenheter och varor - Renovering och tillbyggnader av vårdinrättningar på distriktsnivå - Tillhandahållande av RMNCAH samt nutrition-tjänster och hälsoundervisning - Användning av kvalitativ hälsoinformation för beslutsfattning - Hälsosektor och partner harmonisering och koordinering för RMNCAH
Med insatsen vill Sida återuppliva ett sektorsövergripande tillvägagångssätt inom hälsa samt stärka regeringens ägarskap. Efter en period av splittring inom hälsobiståndet på grund av tidigare korruption inom hälsosektorn (år 2009), har majoriteten av de externa hälsoresurserna gått till icke-statliga organisationer. På senare år har regeringen förbättrat sina kontroll- och styrsystem delvis via tekniskt och finansiellt stöd från Sida. Sverige och Storbritannien vill nu blåsa nytt liv i sektorsövergripande tillvägagångssätt i linje med "International Health Partnership" principer (anpassning till nationella hälsostrategin, finansiellt stöd inkluderat i statsbudgeten, användning av landsspecifika finans- och upphandlingssystem, gemensamma utvärderingsprocesser, samordnat tekniskt stöd etc.).
För att dela risker, fokusera på resultat och öka incitament för regeringens egen finansiering, kommer en del av bidraget (30%) basera sig på i vilken grad överenskomna resultat har uppnåtts. Den resultatbaserade finansieringsmodellen är utformad för att säkerställa en nivå av förutsägbar finansiering medan samtidigt bibehålla fokus på att mäta och stimulera resultat. Den rörliga finansieringsdelen bygger på två indikatorer som är avgörande för att nå hållbara resultat inom hälso- och sjukvårdssektorn:
1. Hälsoförbättringar: prestation av fem RMNCAH nyckelindikatorer 2. Budgetanslag: offentliga hälsomedel som frigörs till distrikten gentemot den godkända distriktsbudgeten
Resultatbaserad finansiering i kombination med en sektorövergripande ansats förväntas öka ägarskapet, minska transaktionskostnader och risken för dubblering. Förhoppningen är också denna ansats ska bidra till en rättvisare resursfördelning och förbättrad biståndseffektivitet inom hälsosektorn.
Sverige kommer att vara den första givaren som bidrar till denna korgfond. Storbritannien kommer troligen att ansluta till fonden senare under 2015 eller 2016. Även USA visar interesse för ökade anslag direkt till regeringen via denna korgfond. Kompletterande insatser av riskreducerande karaktär kommer utarbetas i samarbete med DFID. Upphandlingar kommer att påbörjas hösten 2015.
Detta stöd är utformat som ett programstöd och därför har stat-stat avtalsmallen använts med vissa tillägg med anledning av den resultatbaserade delen. Sidas bedömning är att insatsens resultatbaserade komponent följer myndighetens insatshanteringsregel. Som framgår av avtalsutkastet kommer utbetalningar som resulterar från den variabla tranchen bidra till programmet. De kommer likaså revideras som en del av programmet. Samråd har skett med Sidas revisionsrådgivare.
UPPDATERING 2017: Under hösten 2016 hölls ett flertal konsultationer mellan USAID, MOH och ambassaden varvid föreslogs att USAID kommer att finansiera programmet med ytterligare 38 miljoner USD under en fyraårsperiod 2017-2020 och önskar kanalisera sina medel via Sida i formen av ett delegerat partnerskap. Denna modell reducerar transaktionskostnaderna avsevärt för både USAID och MOH. Ambassaden får av USAID ersättning för administrativa utlägg genom rekrytering av en anställd programpersonal liksom ersättning för dennes kostnader.

tag.narrative: 3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Contribution with the aim of increasing financial services for women and youth, with a special focus on the rural popultation. The independent organisation FSDZ is the implementing partner. It has a market approach, working both with private actors who provide services, the government who sets the policy framework and independent organisations within civil society. The intention is to both develop financial services for poor women and youth, as well as increasing capacity within the target group. FSDZ has a results framework which is easy to follow, with clear indicators to ensure fulfilment of objectives.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen syftar till att öka tillgången till finansiella tjänster för kvinnor och ungdomar, särskilt på landsbygden. Insatsen genomförs av en oberoende organisation, FSDZ, som har en marknadsansats där man arbetar både med privata aktörer som tillhandahåller tjänster, regering och myndigheter som sätter ramverket, samt med oberoende organisationer i civila samhället. Arbetet kommer både bidra till att utveckla tjänster som gynnar fattiga kvinnor och unga, samt till att öka målgruppens kunnande om hur finansiella tjänster fungerar. Organisationen har ett uppföljningsbart resultatramverk med tydliga indikatorer för att säkerställa att FSDZ uppnår sina målsättningar.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

1.5 - By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.

1.5 - Till 2030 bygga upp motståndskraften hos de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer och minska deras utsatthet och sårbarhet för extrema klimatrelaterade händelser och andra ekonomiska, sociala och miljömässiga chocker och katastrofer.

1.a - Ensure significant mobilization of resources from a variety of sources, including through enhanced development cooperation, in order to provide adequate and predictable means for developing countries, in particular least developed countries, to implement programmes and policies to end poverty in all its dimensions.

1.a - Säkra en betydande resursmobilisering från en mängd olika källor, inklusive genom ökat utvecklingssamarbete, i syfte att ge utvecklingsländerna, i synnerhet de minst utvecklade länderna, tillräckliga och förutsebara medel för att genomföra program och politik för att avskaffa all form av fattigdom.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.
