description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The new proposed project is a continuation of a programme called SHARED managed by iDE Zambia from 2014 to 2016. It aims at creating a network/cadre of private farm business advisors working mainly on commission from farmer and private sector agricultural byers and suppliers. The intervention strategy focuses on increasing the incomes of rural communities by ensuring their meaningful and sustainable participation in Zambian markets. It operates across five pillars of support to strengthen FBA performance and income earning opportunities in the market place: These pillars are; access to inputs, access to credit, access to markets, access to entrepreneurship skills, and access to agriculture extension support. An FBA’s earnings come from new lines of business such as selling of seeds or agro chemicals, linkages to credit service providers, and new output market opportunities. Growing FBA earnings is the best indicator that the programme is effectively creating the ‘push-pull’ effect i.e. FBAs linking suppliers and buyers to farmers, and farmers increasingly being able to access and profit from vital services and markets generating growth.
To achieve the expected results iDE has thus applied for 40,045,559 SEK to carry out an extension of the SHARED project that was initiated in 2014 and concluded in 2016. The new proposed SHARED project will continue operating in five provinces of central, Lusaka, copperbelt, southern and north-western during the period 2016-18.
The goal of ‘SHARED’ is ‘to contribute to the reduction of rural poverty through improved service delivery by Farm Business Advisors (FBAs). Therefore, second phase moves away from overall focus of SHARED phase one that was focused on FBA recruitment, training and capacity building. This new SHARED will focus on FBA ‘mentorship and enterprise empowerment’. The intention is to reasonably deepen the technical and market focus, including positioning, of the FBAs as small-scale, but vibrant, diverse and self-reliant entrepreneurs, providing packaged solutions of significant value to the rural community. The new SHARED intervention will build on what was achieved in the previous SHARED project by incorporating learning, refinements and upgrades to the model as well as new investments. It is assessed that with this approach, the intervention will fully embed the FBA model in rural smallholder communities by the end of the proposed three years

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektet är en fortsättning av programmet SHARED som leds och genomförs av organisationen iDE Zambia. Projektet syftar till att skapa ett nätverk eller en grupp av privata ”Farm Business Advisors (FBA)” eller jordbruksrådgivare som främst arbetar för uppköpare och leverantörer på den privata marknaden mot provision. Insatsens strategiska fokus ligger vid att öka inkomsterna för bönder på landsbygden genom att stärka deras roll på den zambiska marknaden. Projektet verkar inom fem områden som alla syftar till att stärka jordbruksrådgivarna i deras arbete och öka deras inkomstmöjligheter. Dessa områden är: Tillgång till insatsvaror, tillgång till krediter, marknadstillträde, kunskaper och färdigheter kopplade till entreprenörskap, samt tillgång till det offentligfinansierade jordbruksrådgivningssystemet. En jordbruksrådgivares (FBAs) inkomster genereras från nya affärsområden som t.ex. försäljning av utsäde och kemikalier, förmedling av kontakter med kreditgivare, samt genom nya möjligheter på olika produktmarknader. Växande inkomster för jordbruksrådgivarna är den bästa indikatorn på att projektet är effektivt i att skapa en sk "push-pull"-effekt, dvs att rådgivarna kopplar samman leverantörer och köpare med bönder, och att bönder kan få större tillgång till och dra nytta av viktiga tjänster och marknader vilket genererar tillväxt.
För att uppnå det förväntade resultatet har iDE ansökt om SEK 40 045 559 för att genomföra en förlängning av fas I av SHARED-programmet som inleddes 2014 och avslutades 2016. Det föreslagna projektet kommer genomföras under perioden 2016-18 och fortsätta sin verksamhet i de fem zambiska provinserna; Central, Lusaka, Copperbelt, Southern och Northwestern.
Målet med SHARED är att bidra till att minska fattigdomen på landsbygden genom en förbättrad service som tillhandahålls av jordbruksrådgivare (Farm Business Advisors, FBA). I den andra fasen förflyttas projektets fokus från att anställa rådgivare, genomföra utbildning och kapacitetsuppbyggnad till att fokusera på mentorskap och företagsbyggande. Avsikten är att i högre grad fördjupa ett tekniskt- och marknadsmässigt fokus och att bidra till en framflyttad positionering av rådgivarna som småskaliga, men dynamiska, diversifierade och självständiga företagare, som erbjuder paketlösningar av betydelse för landsbygden. Den nya SHARED-insatsen kommer att bygga vidare på vad som har åstadkommits under föregående insats genom att införliva lärande och förbättringar av tidigare modeller samt genom nya investeringar. Bedömningen är att med denna ansats kommer insatsen ha förankrat rådgivningsmodellen på landsbygden vid den föreslagna treårsperiodens slut.

The objective of the intervention is to improve commercial capacity of small holder farmers through scaling up of farm business advisor model. Three outcomes are anticipated from this intervention. 1: Sustainable delivery of high quality inputs and production support services to small-scale enterprises through FBAs 2: improved smallholder participation in the output market facilitated by FBAS. 3: increased FBA capability to participate in and provide commodity aggregation services.

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.

2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

description.narrative: The project’s purpose is to improve the commercial capacity of small holder farmers through the scaling up of the FBA model. Results under this purpose show that FBAs have continued to increase both the outreach and range of services offered to farmers. In the reporting period, the following results were recorded: - FBAs increased the number of farm enterprises being reached from 104,747 to 110,372 exceeding the project target of 72,73 -Average change in net farm income per farming household increased by 19% to ZMW 3,558 from ZMW 3,545 recorded last year. -78% of the 110, 372 smallholder farmers reached, attained an income diversification index of 0.7 or better against the project annual target of 64%. The index reflects the proportion of smallholder farm enterprises earning income from at least four different crops; and no single crop contributes more than 50% of the total income. This is important for improved nutrition and household resilience. The following was achieved under each of the three outcomes: Outcome 1- Sustainable delivery of high-quality inputs and production support services to small-scale enterprises -The value of inputs and equipment sold to smallholder farmers through FBAs increased from ZMW 72,633,544 to ZMW 79,800,372, well above the target of ZMW33,500,000. - Number of Smallholder farmers accessing climate smart technologies increased to 38,630 smallholder farmers from 33,450 last year. Outcome 2- Improved smallholder participation in the output market facilitated by FBAs: -Out of 110,372 farmers that had access to market information, 41% were able to sell to buyers facilitated by FBAs -The number of 127 FBAs actively supporting output market activities has increase to 127 from 116 in the previous year. Outcome 3- Increased FBA capability to participate in and provide commodity aggregation services: -The value of sales per FBA client has increased from the ZMW 1,997 reported at the end of year 3 to ZMW 2,360.50. -Number of FBAs accessing affordable and timely working capital increase from 90 to 114. -The value of working capital accessed by FBAs increased from ZMW 657, 500 to ZMW 2,580, 500.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 ProValAB/Agricultural valorization of small dams in Burkina Faso
COVID-19 Valorisering av dammar Burkina Faso

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project aims to assure an improved agricultural valorization of hydraulic infrastructure already in place in Burkina Faso. The project aims at both rehabilitating 17 to 20 of Burkina Faso's many water dams and improve the use of the dams. The overall expected objective of the project is: "Households sustainable development of food security/nutritional security and increase of their incomes by exploiting water from small dams through the development of beneficial value chains".
The specific objectives are : • users put in place good governance for the sustainable management of infrastructures, water resources and developed lands; • farmers increase quantitatively and qualitatively their agricultural, forestry, pastoral and fishery production (ASPF) ; • producers and other players in value chains improve their economic and social performance.
The project runs in its totality over 5 years, where a first phase (2017-2020) is financed in collaboration between the Government of Burkina Faso and Sweden. Sweden contributes XX million SEK.
The contribution is is in line with the following goal of the strategy for Sweden's development cooperation in Burkina Faso "... to help boost incomes and improve security among the poor, especially among women and girls, by promoting environmentally sustainable increases in productivity in the natural resource management sectors." Further, the contribution is of a vital importance for Burkina Faso's capacity to adapt to climate change.
The project contributes to at least eight of the seventeen sustainable goals stated by the United Nation in 2015 and signed both by Sweden and Burkina Faso. It is also in coherence with several public policy objectives of Burkina Faso such as the National Plan for Economic and Social Development (NPESD) adopted in 2016 and the development strategy SCADD. It is further in line with the National Adaptation Program of Action on Climate Change (NAPA). ProValAB falls within the framework of the implementation of the National Water Policy by considering the National Program for Integrated Water Resources Management and the National Hydro Development.
In Burkina Faso around 85% of the population gain their living from natural resources, agriculture, livestock and silviculture. This is more so in the rural areas where the incomes are very low, however these livelihood activities still contributes to around 40% of the Gross Domestic Budget (GDP). The most limiting factor to increase the productivity of natural resources is the access to water. With climate change the rainfall have become more irregular and more intense once it occurs, which means that the risk of soil erosion increases, that the topsoil disappears and the possibility to keep the humidity in the soil diminish. The dams allow farmers to produce an important supplement of vegetables and fruits, which in addition will increase their cash income and make them more market-oriented. It should also improve nutrition and health status of the farmers' families.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektets övergripande mål är att uppnå ett mer effektivt och rättvist nyttjande av existerande regnvattendammar för jordbruksändamål i Burkina Faso. De specifika målen är:
1) Användarna skapar system för god och hållbar förvaltning av dammarna, vattenresursen och odlingsmarken; 2) Odlarna ökar sin kvantitativa respektive kvalitativa produktion från träd, jordbruk, husdjur och fiskodling; 3) Producenter och andra värdekedjeaktörer förbättrar sitt ekonomiska och sociala uppträdande.
Projektet löper över 5 år under vilka fas 1 (2017-2020) samfinansieras av Burkina Faso och Sverige. Sverige avser bidra med 79 000 000 miljoner kronor.
Projektet överensstämmer med minst åtta av de sjutton hållbara utvecklingsmål som fastställdes av FN 2015 och som undertecknats av både Sverige och Burkina Faso. Projektet överensstämmer också med den nationella planen för ekonomisk och social utveckling (NPESD), utvecklingsstrategin SCADD, den nationella planen för adaptering till klimatförändringarna (PANA) och landets prioriteringar inom resiliens för livsmedelssäkerhet och nutrition antagen 2015.
I Burkina Faso lever omkring 85% av befolkningen, främst på landsbygden, av naturresurser, jordbruk, boskap och skogsbruk. Inkomsterna är mycket låga, men trots detta bidrar dessa försörjningsaktiviteter till cirka 40% av BNP. Den mest begränsande faktorn att öka produktiviteten av naturresurser är tillgången till vatten. Med klimatförändringen har nederbörden blivit mer oregelbundet och mer intensiv när det inträffar, vilket innebär att risken för jorderosion ökar, att översta jordlagret försvinner och möjligheten att hålla fuktigheten i jorden minskar. Dammarna tillåter jordbrukare att producera ett viktigt tillskott av grönsaker och frukter, vilket dessutom kommer att öka sina kontantinkomster och göra dem mer marknadsinriktade. Det kommer att leda till att förbättra böndernas hushåll närings- och hälsotillstånd.

tag.narrative: 1.2 - By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.
1.2 - Till 2030 minst halvera den andel män, kvinnor och barn i alla åldrar som lever i någon form av fattigdom enligt nationella definitioner.

1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.

15.8 - By 2020, introduce measures to prevent the introduction and significantly reduce the impact of invasive alien species on land and water ecosystems and control or eradicate the priority species.

15.8 - Senast 2020 införa åtgärder för att förhindra införseln av invasiva främmande arter och avsevärt minska deras påverkan på land- och vattenekosystem samt kontrollera eller utrota prioriterade arter.

2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.
3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.
7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

description.narrative: Examples of results that have been achieved, both expected and unexpected: - In terms of improving the capacities and means of agricultural and fishery production, we note, the production of fifteen (15) environmental and social impact notices and one (01) environmental prescription for the implementation of environmental and social measures within the framework of infrastructure construction and the carrying out studies to rehabilitate five (05) dams, develop and rehabilitate irrigated areas, and additional works to secure dams. These results will help increase the production capacities of producers in 2020. - Regarding the better management of water resources and developed land, the activities carried out have improved the representativeness of women in the office of the Water User Committees with at least 30% of women. - Regarding the development of water and developed land, the activities have improved production techniques and technologies adapted to climate change for producers at the intervention sites. They have also made it possible to increase the proportion of fishermen who apply modernization techniques and technology. Special attention was paid to women by supporting their capacity building in the transformation component in 2019. - Concerning the economic development of agricultural products, the major results achieved concern the training of 17 producers in commercial negotiation techniques, contractualization, marketing and pricing, the identification of promising value chains with the rice, onion, tomato and fish and some speculation depending on the potential specific to the sites selected as a value chain to promote. These results achieved will allow players to have better access to the market.- Regarding support for the development of business plans for the benefit of women, the project enabled the acquisition of two (02) rice parboiling units, one hundred and seventy (170) chorkor ovens made to be made available. The actions carried out have contributed to good post-harvest management of products and better access to the market. In 2019, unexpected results in terms of effects were not observed. Brief analysis of satisfaction: As part of the better management of dams, there is satisfaction with the establishment of governance structures for the management of dams and developed land with good representation of women in the bodies (at least 30%). We also note an improvement in the participation of women in training sessions (at least 40%), the beginning of the organization of fishermen for better management of fishing activities and processing of fishery products by women. Analysis of dissatisfaction: We note an inaccessibilitydue to security issues of two (2) sites for the conduct of activities. As well as a lack of financial resources for the conduct of soft activities that can support certain actions planned under the project lead by technical assistance.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Hygien och sanitet i regionerna Nord, Centre-Nord och Centre-Sud i BF 2018-2022
COVID-19 Hygiene& sanitation in the regions Nord, Centre-Nord &Centre-Sud in BF 2018-2022

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Project name: "Project for Promotion of Hygiene and sanitation in the regions Nord, Centre-Nord and Centre-Sud in Burkina Faso 2018-2022"
Agreement partner : WaterAid Burkina Faso.
Consortium members for implementation: WaterAid and Eau Vive. They will work with the national Sanitation Board.
Activity period: 1 July 2018 - 31 December 2022
Amount of financial support by Sida: 79 000 000 SEK (95% of the project's total cost) Funds transfers :
1. Sida to WaterAid (95 %of the total budget) 2. WaterAid to Eau Vive (29%), SEI (2,6%) and local NGOs/local Governments (32%) 3. Local NGOs/local Governments A to local Associations A (11%) 4. Eau Vive to local NGOs/local Governments (16%) 5. local NGOs/local Governments B to local Associations B (5,6%)
The activities take 59.7% of the budget, monitoring and evaluation (monitoring meetings at the municipal / regional / national level, evaluations, capitalization, production of articles and films, field monitoring etc.) estimated at 11.1%.
50% of the total budget is used for "Investment Related Technical Cooperation (IRTC)" in that the share of physical investments is estimated at 27.6% of the budget and includes: subsidies for family latrines and catch basins, latrines realizations / rehabilitations for health centers and schools, boreholes, school gardens, Sludge treatment plant and unloading sites, etc.
The target groups (households, craftsmen masons, store managers, sanitation service providers, students, associations, communal technical services)/ will according to estimates receive at least 49% of the budget, including investments.
Project sites: Central-North, North, Central-South Regions
Background
The project’s overarching aim is to help improve sustainable and equitable access to safe water and sanitation for communities in 3 regions of Burkina Faso.
Specific Objectives are : - Sustainable access to hygiene, sanitation and safe water to communities in North, Central-North and Central-South regions - Increased reuse of sanitation by-products at school and community levels - Increased number of local service providers managing waste water and human waste - Improved local governance in managment of safe water, waste water and excreta.
The target groups are : - communities in all three (3) regions/North, Central North and Central South ; - children, particularly girls, in and outside schools; - local masons, Hygiene Promotion Volunteers (HPV, Community health workers, local service providers); - youth and women associations, - businesses promoting management of waste water and excreta - partner NGOs, - local Governments/municipalities in the 3 regions ; - regional boards for: water & sanitation, health, education and agriculture in the 3 regions.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektnamn: "Sanitet, hälsa, motståndskraft och trygg vattenförsörjning i regionerna Nord, Centre-Nord och Centre-Sud i Burkina Faso 2018-2022"
Avtalspartner: WaterAid Burkina Faso.
Konsortiemedlemmar för implementering: WaterAid och Eau Vive. De kommer att arbeta med det nationella sanitetsverket.
Aktivitetsperiod: 1 juli 2018 - 31 december 2022
Finansiellt stöd från Sida: 79 000 000 kr (95% av projektets totala kostnad).
Finansiella transfereringar:
1. Sida till WaterAid 95% av totala budgeten 2. WaterAid vidareförmedlar till Eau Vive (29% av sitt bidrag), SEI (2,6%) och lokala icke-statliga organisationer / kommuner (32%) 3. Lokala icke-statliga organisationer / kommuner vidareförmedlar till lokala föreningar (11%) 4. Eau Vive vidareförmdelar till lokala icke-statliga organisationer / kommuner (16%) 5. Lokala icke-statliga organisationer / lokakommuner vidareförmedlar till lokala föreningar (5,6%)
För aktiviteter planeras 59,7% av budgeten. Fältuppföljning, utvärdering & kommunikation inkl möten på kommunal / regional / nationell nivå, utvärderingar, kapitalisering, artiklar och filmer etc.) uppskattas till 11,1%. 50% av den totala budgeten används för "Investment Related Technical Cooperation (IRTC)", eftersom andelen fysiska investeringar uppskattas till 27,6% av budgeten och inkluderar subventioner för familjelatriner och fängelseinterner, latriner för hälsocenter och skolor, borrhål, skolor, slamhanteringsanläggningar och sopanläggningar etc.
Målgrupperna (hushåll, hantverkare, murare, sanitärtjänsteleverantörer, studenter, föreningar, kommunala tekniska tjänster) beräknas dra direkt nytta av 49% av budgeten, inklusive investeringar.
Projektområden: Regionerna Central-North, North, Central-South
Bakgrund
Projektets övergripande mål är att bidra till en hållbar och rättvis tillgång till säker vatten och sanitet för samhällen i tre regioner i Burkina Faso.
Specifika mål är: - Hållbar tillgång till hygien, sanitet och rent vatten till samhällen i norra, centrala och nord-sydliga regioner - Ökad återanvändning av biprodukter av sanitet på skolan och på kommunnivå - Ökat antal lokala tjänsteleverantörer som hanterar avloppsvatten och mänskligt avfall - Förbättrat lokalt styre i hantering av rent vatten, avloppsvatten och excreta.
Målgrupperna är: - befolkningen i alla tre (3) regionerna/North, Central North and Central South; - barn, i synnerhet flickor, såväl inom som utom skolor; - Lokala murare, Hygien Promotion Volunteers (HPV, hälsoarbetare, lokala tjänsteleverantörer); - Ungdoms- och kvinnoförbund; - Företag inom förvaltning av avloppsvatten och excreta; - NGO-partners; - kommuner i de tre regionerna; - Regionala styrelser för vatten och sanitet, hälsa, utbildning och jordbruk i de tre regionerna.

The project’s aim is to help improve sustainable and equitable access to safe water and sanitation for communities in the regions Nord, Centre-Nord &Centre-Sud in Burkina Faso. The specific objectives are: Provide sustainable access to hygiene, sanitation and safe water services to communities in North, Central-North and Central-South regions, Promote the reuse of sanitation by-products at school and community levels, Foster the development of local service providers to manage waste water and excreta and Improve local governance on safe water and management of waste water and excreta. The project will help to address the root causes of safe water and sanitation issues in communities, households, health centers and schools through creating demand from community members; offer quality sanitation; support municipalities to effectively and efficiently manage projects and delivery of safe water and sanitation to school children. Expected outcomes are : -19 000 households have access to waste water and excreta management services - 250 000 people display good hygiene practices - 14 health care facilities provided with facilities to manage waste water and excreta - 10 000 school children have access to sustainable safe water, hygiene and sanitation, including Menstrual Hygiene Management - 13 blue schools are created - 3 clean and productive communities exist - 5 initiatives are supported to develop and promote sanitation by-products - 25 women associations and 25 youth associations become professional in managing waste water and excreta - 750 local masons and 25 sanitation shop managers/attendants and 25 manual pit cleaners/emptiers are operational - 2 eco-business are set up for management of excreta and waste water - local authorities’ leadership has increased - communities are empowered to claim their rights of access to sustainable safe water and sanitation services - local accountability platforms are created and operational

tag.narrative: 3.3 - By 2030, end the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases and combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases and other communicable diseases.
3.3 - Senast 2030 utrota epidemierna av aids, tuberkulos, malaria och försummade tropiska sjukdomar samt bekämpa hepatit, vattenburna sjukdomar och andra smittsamma sjukdomar.
6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.

description.narrative: Examples of the most important results obtained in 2019 and analysis of the link between the results and the expected objectives of the project The important results obtained in 2019: - 21. 000 people in the project intervention communes had access to sanitation services through the construction of nearly 2,212 family latrines. The construction of these structures made it possible, between the end of 2018 and the end of 2019, to increase by 0.3 point the rate of access to sanitation in the Center-North region, by 1 point in the North region and 2.3 points in the Center-Sud region. Recall that, at the national level, the average increase in the rate of access to sanitation between the end of 2018 and the end of 2019 is 1.2 points. This result contributes to the achievement of objective 1 of the project, about "19,000 households in target communities have access to wastewater and excreta sanitation services". - The increase in the proportion of the population of the project area who adopt good hygiene practices following awareness actions. In fact, the populations of the project area now have access to hygiene facilities and the awareness campaigns allow a gradual adoption of good hygiene practices. This result contributes to the achievement of objective 2 of the project, about "250,000 people adopt good hygiene practices". - "Communal Water and Sanitation Technicians" were recruited, trained and equipped to support the project implementation with a view to perpetuating the results thereafter. There were no unexpected results for 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Support to BF Integrated water resources management
COVID-19 Verksamhetsplan för BF Integrerade Vatten Förvaltning

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektets syfte är att tillämpa en integrerad styrning och hantering av nationella vattenresurser i fem vattenregioner i Burkina Faso. Vatten är en grundläggande resurs för människors överlevnad och för stora delar av livsnödvändig produktion i Burkina Faso där 85 procent av befolkningen bor på landsbygden, mestadels livnär sig på delvis självförsörjande jordbruk och andra verksamheter baserade på naturresurser. En förbättrad hantering av vattenresurser är tänkt att nås genom förstärkning och ytterligare kapacitetsuppbyggnad av de fem operativa vattenmyndigheterna, utvecklande och tillämpning av övergripande vattenresurs-planer, utvecklandet och tillämpningen av ett vatteninformations-system, samt insatser för att höja medvetenheten bland vattenanvändare och allmänhet. De olika vattenmyndigheterna samarbetar sedan i sin tur med kommuner, organisationer i civilsamhället, särskilt organisationer för vattenanvändare, samt privata företag. Genomgående för arbetet är att det sker med hög grad av lokalt deltagande. Vattenavgifter för användning och nedsmutsning kommer att tillämpas. Projektet, som i sin helhet löper över 15 år, finansieras av Danmark och Sverige i samarbete under en första del av denna period. Sverige bidrar med 45 miljoner kronor under åren 2016-2018. --------------------------------- The purpose of the contribution is to support the implementation of the integrated water resources management (IWRM) in five river sub-basins in Burkina Faso. Water is a key resource for survival and economic production in Burkina Faso where 85 percent of the population live in rural areas, mainly from semi subsistence farming and other activities based on natural resource management.The improved water management will be achieved through capacity building of the newly created operative agencies for the five sub-basins, development and implementation of IWRM plans, development and implementation of a water information system and activities aiming at raising awareness of IWRM issues among water users and the public. The water authorities cooperate in their turn with municipalities, civil society organisations, especially water user associations and private companies. The work is to a high degree participative. Fees for water use as well as for pollution will be used. The project runs in its totality over 15 years, where a first phase is finance in collaboration between Denmark and Sweden. Sweden contributes 45 million SEK over the 2016-2018 period.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The programme objective is to apply IWRM in all the five river basins of Burkina Faso by 2015. This will be done through the establishment of operational river basin agencies, the developement and implementation of water resources (master) management plans, the developement of a water information system etc. A water fee will be also applyed to all the water users and polluters.

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 13.2 - Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
13.2 - Integrera klimatåtgärder i politik, strategier och planering på nationell nivå.

14.4 - By 2020, effectively regulate harvesting and end overfishing, illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing and destructive fishing practices and implement science-based management plans, in order to restore fish stocks in the shortest time feasible, at least to levels that can produce maximum sustainable yield as determined by their biological characteristics.

14.4 - Senast 2020 införa en effektiv fångstreglering och stoppa överfiske, olagligt, orapporterat och oreglerat fiske liksom destruktiva fiskemetoder samt genomföra vetenskapligt baserade förvaltningsplaner i syfte att återställa fiskbestånden så snabbt som möjligt, åtminstone till de nivåer som kan producera maximalt hållbart uttag, fastställt utifrån deras biologiska egenskaper.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.
6.6 - By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.
6.6 - Senast 2020 skydda och återställa de vattenrelaterade ekosystemen, däribland berg, skogar, våtmarker, floder, akviferer och sjöar.

description.narrative: In 2018, cooperation with the ministry responsible for water, specifically the permanent secretariat for integrated water resources management (IWRM), with regard to the funding of the first phase of the National IWRM Program worked in accordance with the terms of the Agreement. The partner was able to submit disbursements on time, all of which contributed to facilitating the execution of the activities listed in the Work Plan and Budget 2018. Partner capacities to carry out the projectAssessment of 2018 activities implementation was satisfactory. Physical execution rate is 79.21% and financial rate is 70.63%. Many constraints recorded:•Country security situation;• financial services agents strike who delayed or disrupted disbursements and procurement plan in 2018;• mobility of water police staff.In view of this performance, IWRM actors have a good capacity for carrying out activities. The most important results recorded during 2018 are as follows: - In terms of effective application of the water police: * five (05) other water police services were operational, making the total number of functional water police services from five (5) to ten (10). These are water police services of Cascades, Center, Center-South, Center-East and Center-West regions. * Indeed, at the end of 2018, 3 additional functional water police services were expected. Which should bring the cumulative number of water police to eight (08). However, as of December 31, 2018, ten (10) out of thirteen (13) water police services are functional through technical and financial support. * The various interventions of the water police services made it possible to raise awareness among stakeholders, inspect the rivers banks of 33 water reservoirs and check compliance with regulations in: 216 prepackaged water production units ; 32 stand-alone water stations ; 16 gold panning sites ; 05 mining companies ; 07 industrial units ; 03 processing units for various products. - For the adaptation of the institutional framework and management instruments: * 10 Local Water Committee’s have been set up, including 03 by Gourma Water Agency, 02 by Liptako Water Agency, 01 by Mouhoun Water Agency and 04 by Nakanbé water agency, * ten (10) local water committees have been implemented place, this increase the number of existing local water committee to forty-two (42). In addition, the country has been subdivided into 159 areas of competence of local water committees. However, local water committees are experiencing difficulties in their operations due to funding mechanisms which suffer from heavy administrative burdens due to their unclear status. - The process of developing Nakanbé Water Agency Water development and management master plan is being finalized. Indeed, the document has been validated by the Basin Committee and the report of environmental and strategic assessment by Technical Commission for Environmental Assessment of the National Office of Environmental Assessments and those of Gourma and Liptako competence area, are starting up. - In terms of capacity building for water agencies and other stakeholders: training of twenty-five (25) students at Agrhymet Institute- Niamey/Niger. These students will reinforce the staff of the IWRM implementation structures. -Protection of water resources against pollution, filling and invasive aquatic plants : 70 km of river banks were protected by plants and beacons, actions of destruction invasive plants in several reservoirs and monitoring of water pollution at certain critical sites, particularly gold panning. - Within the framework of the implementation of the national IWRM program, communication is essential with a view to changing the behavior of stakeholders regarding protection and uses of water. For this, a actions have been carried out, like: strengthening the capacities of media personnel in IWRM (30 different press bodies), design and dissemination of radio and television spots, production of radio and television broadcasts. Also, for the awareness of field actors, theater-forums are organized through all the water agencies. Unexpected results: The awareness of the populations on the phenomena of silting up and their responsibility as for the state of their course and bodies of water. Environment, gender and human rights perspectives are integrated into the activities through information, awareness, communication, consultation, appropriation, commitment of the beneficiary actors and participation: - Two actions out of 10 included in the project take gender and human rights into change. - Environment is integrated into all other actions in terms of adaptation or mitigation. This through protection and restoration actions such as identification of water sources and their protection, treatment of sub-basins with technical actions, treatment of gullies and installation of filter dikes. Awareness-raising, information and capacity-building actions for populations on techniques for economical use of water, better water management help take environment into account.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UNFPAs föreslagna projekt 'Empower and Fulfilled' har en aktivitetsperiod om fyra år under 2016-2020 och en total projektkostnad om 44 miljoner SEK, varav Sverige avser bidra med 40 miljoner SEK som den enda givaren. UNFPA ska själva bidra med 4 miljoner SEK. Projektet har ett mål på medellång sikt att öka tillgången och användningen av service för sexuell- och reproduktiv hälsa samt familjeplanering bland unga människor mellan 10 och 19 år. Det långsiktiga målet är att bidra till en minskad andel tonårsgraviditeter i Liberia, vilket för närvarande ligger på en hög nivå . Det huvudsakliga utvecklingsproblemet som insatsen avser att bemöta är den nu begränsade möjligheten att nyttja sina rättigheter inom sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa, särskilt för unga flickor och pojkar.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The proposed intervention by UNFPA 'Empower and Fulfilled' has an activity period of four years 2016-2020 with a total cost of SEK 44 million; of this amount, the expected Swedish contribution is expected to be SEK 40 million, with Sweden as the only main donor. UNFPA intends to allocate SEK 4million from its own Resources. The project has a medium term goal to increase access and utilization of sexual reproductive health and family planning services by young people between the ages of 10-19 years, with a long term goal to contribute to the reduction of the high rate of teenage pregnancies in Liberia. The main development problem the intervention seeks to address is the limited access to the full realization of the sexual and reproductive Health and rights particularly of adolescent girls and boys.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.

10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

description.narrative: The project is in its third year of the implementation and remained focus on its goal to contribute to the reduction in the high rate of teenage pregnancy in four counties of the south east of Liberia: Grand Gedeh, Maryland, Grand Kru and River Gee. The project provided targeted clients access to sexual and reproductive health and rights information and services (family planning, ANC 4th visit, Delivery in health facility and STIs). Thanks to the programme, a cumulative total of number of 180,789 clients have accessed SRHR services from 30 Ministry of Health facilities, and through 20 community delivery sites in the four counties. Through the project, the Public Health Law is in the process of being revised to include access to safe abortion care services up to 24 weeks and access to family planning service for adolescents without parental consent. The ongoing revision of the Public Health Law constitutes an important step in making access to safe abortion care services and family planning available for adolescents. These services are crucial when it comes to vital life decisions. The services can give adolescents power to make decisions over their own lives by providing them with the necessary tools for safe and enjoyable sexual experience without coercion, risk of contracting diseases or unwanted pregnancies. Access to these services could have a strengthening mechanism for women in particular by empowering them and making them more independent; in domestic as well as in working life. Liberia Ministry of Health is leading the revision of the Public Health Law with strong commitment from the Chief Medical Officer of Liberia. When revised, the Public Health Law has to meet the approval of the Legislature and the President of Liberia for it to take effect. The relaxation on the restriction to right to safe abortion and family planning for adolescent without parental consent are important changes that will bring Liberia in line with its international commitment under the Maputo Protocol which in Article 14 establishes for women right to control their fertility, the right whether to have children, the number of children and the spacing of children as well as the right to chose any form of contraception. The programme has further contributed to National School Health Policy being validated and endorsed by the government. The school health program has trained a total of 41 teachers from 20 schools in SRHR information dissemination, mentorship and coaching as pilot for the program. In addition, school-based Sexuality Education has been operationalised in accordance with international standards and integrated into the National Education Curriculum for primary and secondary schools and out-of-school youth (OSY). One result of this is that a total number of 24,840 young people have benefited from sexuality education (SCE), delivered by 397 persons trained in comprehensive sexuality education from 50 schools. A gender-responsive sexuality education manual has been developed with the aim to deliver out of-school sexuality education that conform with international standards. The project also targets out of school young people (10-19 years) and has provided 4.951 adolescents with quality comprehensive sexuality education through Women Susu clubs in out-of-school settings. These sample results were presented at development cooperation meeting for quality review of the conclusion on performance and a main observation was to encourage UNFPA within its final annual reporting to also specify qualitative results especially in terms attitude change in the behaviours of adolescents and the providers of SRHR services for adolescents. Here is a video to give some insights about UNFPA work on the field: https://liberia.unfpa.org/en/video/family-planning-saving-lives-liberia
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Component 1 - Community-based social therapy seeks to create outcomes at four levels: The first outcome focuses on the individual level: improved individual psychosocial health and well-being. The second outcome focuses on the family level: improved family dynamics, including more gender equal relations. The third outcome has to do with community level: renewed social fabric from the grass-roots, in and between target communities, identified by improved social interaction and reduction of tension between different groups. The fourth outcome looks at citizen participation and civil trust: improved citizen participation and positive engagement with local government. ZOA’s pilot community based social-therapy intervention in Margibi County in 2015 provides evidence that these four outcomes contribute to conflict resolution and reconciliation at local and national levels. Component 2 - Support to Early Warning and Early Response, County Peace Committees and District Level Political Reconciliation Dialogues and Civic Engagement Project, has five outcomes: Outcome 1: Reduced conflict incidents in 15 counties due to increased technical and institutional capacity of existing conflict prevention and management mechanisms (specifically the Early Warning and Early Response (EWER) mechanism and County Peace Committees (CPC). Outcome 2: Enhanced political reconciliation and peaceful coexistence, and reduced pre- and post-election conflicts in six counties Lofa, Grand Cape Mount, Sinoe, Bong, Nimba and Montserrado. Outcome 3: Enhanced intergroup harmony and coexistence through improved relations in Margibi, Grand Cape Mount and Gbarpolu Counties. Outcome 4: Increased public participation and civic trust in Sinoe, Bomi, River Gee and Maryland Counties Outcome 5: Advanced youth leadership in peacebuilding at the national and county level.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Sveriges ambassad i Monrovia har mottagit en förfrågan från ZOA angående stöd till projektet "Peacebuilding and Reconciliation through Community Dialogues: Strengthening Social Cohesion and Civic Trust in Five Counties, Liberia" för perioden 2017 - 2020. Insatsen innebär att utföra den evidensbaserade metoden "Community-based social therapy", en form av social gruppterapi för byar. Målet med sessionerna är att bygga förtroende mellan deltagarna och att lära ut verktyg för hur att hantera svåra minnen och traumatiska upplevelser från kriget samt verktyg för konfliktlösning och kommunikation. Det finns positiva resultat från bland annat Rwanda där modellen först introducerades. ZOA arbetar även med att utbilda och träna lokala myndighetsanställda och ledare från civilsamhället i CBS-metoden och faciliterar dialogforum för byinvånare och lokala ledare (statliga och traditionella). En del av programmet inkluderar även att engagera lärare och skolungdomar i så kallade "fredsklubbar".
Insatsen har som övergripande mål att bidra till försoning och fredsbyggande genom samhällsdialoger. För att åstadkomma detta arbetar ZOA med målsättningar på fyra nivåer: i) individnivå: förbättrad individuell psykosocial hälsa och välbefinnande; ii) familjenivå: förbättrad familjedynamik, inklusive ökad jämställdhet; iii) samhällsnivå: stärkt och förbättrad social dynamik från gräsrotsnivå, inom och mellan målgrupper; iv) medborgerligt deltagande och förtroende: ökat engagemang hos medborgare samt förbättrade relationer mellan medborgare och lokala myndigheter. Projektet har genomgått en pilotfas som utvärderats och visar att dessa fyra nivåer bidrar till konfliktlösning och försoning på lokal och nationell nivå.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Sweden's Embassy in Monrovia has received a request from ZOA for support for the project "Peacebuilding and Reconciliation through Community Dialogues: Strengthening Social Cohesion and Civic Trust in Five Counties, Liberia" for the period 2017-2020. The contribution includes carrying out the evidence-based method "Community- based social therapy " which is a form of social group therapy for communities. The aim of these social group therapy sessions is to build trust among the participants and to communicate tools for dealing with difficult memories and traumatic experiences from the war, as well as proving tools for conflict resolution and communication. There are positive results from, for example Rwanda, where this apporach was first introduced. ZOA also trains local civil servants and civil society leaders in the CBS method and facilitates platforms for dialogue for community residents and local leaders, both formal and traditional. A part of the project also includes engaging teachers and schoolchildren in so-called "peace clubs".
The overall goal of the contribution is to contribute to reconciliation and peace building through community dialogues. To achieve this, ZOA works at four different levels: i) individual level: improved individual psychosocial health and well-being; ii) family level: improved family dynamics, including increased gender equality; iii) social level: strengthened and improved social dynamics from grassroots level, within and between target groups; iv) civic participation and trust: increased involvement of citizens as well as improved relationships between citizens and local authorities. The project has undergone a pilot phase that has been evaluated and shows that these four levels contribute to conflict resolutionand reconciliation at local and national level.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

description.narrative: The Mid Term Review (MTR) needs to be awaited to follow-up on the results, as the MTR will report against the baseline. Below is a summary of indicative and observed results reported in the progress report for year 1. Component 1, Community-based Socio-therapy, has overall created outcomes on both the individual, family and community level: On the individual level, many members of the CBS reported that their former low tolerance for disagreements and responding to issues in an aggressive and emotional manner has changed, resulting in more constructive ways to solve conflicts in the communities. On the family level, the reported results within and between families are improved relationships among community members and that the role of each family member now is better recognized by each member in the family. In and between target communities, the project has contributed to more interaction, and discussion of development issues of common concern, between community leaders and community members. This has resulted in built and strengthened relationships amongst and between the youth and women groups and the local authorities. The project has resulted in a demonstrated will by the Liberia National Police, women groups, elders, religious and community leaders to participate in the Community Leaders Forum and the Civil Trust Workshops. The participants have demonstrated a commitment by their active participation in the meetings and their engagement in follow up actions. The project has enabled for citizens in some of the project locations (particularly in Yekepa, Sinje and West Point) to have direct access to their lawmakers and hence resulted in citizens using this opportunity actively to raise issues and concerns with them to find common solutions. Furthermore, the project has made the local government officials that are participating in the forums more receptive to the concerns and proactive in the solving of the problems brought to them.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 I FN:s Säkerhetsrådsresolution 2239 från 2015, bekräftades att FN:s fredsbevarande mission i Liberia (UNMIL) som funnits på plats i landet sedan 2003, ska dras tillbaka den 30 september i år. Neddragningen har skett gradvis under de senaste åren och innebär en successiv överlämning av ansvar till den liberianska regeringen (GoL) för säkerheten i landet och skydd av civilbefolkningen. Liberias regering återtog, som resolutionen påbjöd, fullt ansvar för säkerheten i landet den 30 juni i år, men allvarliga resurs- och kapacitetsbrister föreligger. I resolutionen skriver Säkerhetsrådet att Liberias regering bör arbeta fram en plan med tidslinjer och indikatorer för säkerhetssektorreform innehållande planer för ledarskap, koordinering, uppföljning och resurser, översynsmekanismer etcetera. Resolutionen understryker vikten av att GoL genomför reform av säkerhets- respektive rättssektorn.
GoL tog fram Government of Liberia Plan for UNMIL Transition med en narrativ text kring utmaningar och prioriteringar samt en matris med mål och aktiviteter. Transitionsplanen är gravt underfinansierad och understryker behovet av stöd från internationella givare till transitionsplanen och säkerhetssektorn i stort.
Svag kapacitet hos implementerande parter och korruption i säkerhets- och rättsinstitutionerna medför en relativt hög risknivå som fordrar noggrann uppföljning. På grund av neddragningen av UNMIL och det svaga givarstödet till Liberia generallt och till dessa processer specifikt, är behoven stora och absorptionskapaciteten hög.Sverige är en av få givare som dessutom har en välbemannad ambassad i Liberia och har därför möjlighet att följa upp stödet bättre. Sverige är därför en av de viktigaste givarna i denna sektor och har tillsammans med USA ingått i flera arbetsgrupper med GoL för att planera den kommande fredsbyggandestrukturen i landet.
UNDPs/UNMILs Rule of Law Joint Programme har utformats för att stödja GoL i arbetet med att genomföra transitionsplanen samt bygger vidare på målen i planen. Programmet syftar till att säkerställa en sammanhållen strategi för säkerhetssektorreform och ökad rättssäkerhet samt till att stödja implementeringen av dessa reformprocesser. UNDP och UNMIL (under Department for Peacekeeping Operations, DPKO) har utvecklat ett gemensamt program för detta. Programmet fokuserar på kapacitetsuppbyggnad av statliga säkerhets- och rättsinstitutioner samt av civilsamhället; etablering av översynsmekanismer och standardiserade rutiner; förbättrat samarbete bland aktörer i hela rättskedjan; stärkt och adekvat nationellt juridiskt ramverk samt; stärka jämställdhetsperspektiv i hela rättskedjan och öka kvinnors och flickors rättssäkerhet. Detta är tänkt att förbättra tillhandahållandet av säkerhets- och rättsliga tjänster och därmed även bygga förtroende hos befolkningen och förbättra relationen mellan stat och befolkning.
Konceptet med ett gemensamt program (joint programme) innebär en rad aktiviteter som ingår i en gemensam arbetsplan och budgetram, som per definition omfattar två eller fler FN-organisationer och syftar till att uppnå resultat i linje med nationella prioriteringar som återspeglas i United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) / One Program. Arbetsordningen och budgetram mellan UNDP och UNMIL utgör en del av programdokumentet, som specificerar roller och ansvar. Programmets koordineras av UNDP och UNMIL i samarbete med GoL, men anlitar även det civila samhällets organisationer som genomförandepartner. Sverige, representerat av Sida, ingår ett avtal med UNDP. Av Sida fastställd avtalsmall "Third Party Cost Sharing Agreement" används (senaste version av mallen fastställd genom Sida beslut 2016-002132).
Samförståndsavtal kommer att ingås mellan UNDP och UNMIL som anger att UNDP ska bära det fulla ansvaret för att genomföra programmet och anta ekonomisk ansvarsskyldighet för de medel som ställs till förfogande. Avtalsmallen har delats med ambassaden men kommer formellt att ingås senare på året. Dock har UNDP, UNMIL och GoL formellt signerat programdokumentet. Programmet kommer att ha full tillgång till de tjänster som tillhandahålls av UNDPs operativa enheter samt följa UNDPs regelverk, men dra nytta av UNMILs operativa fördelar. Enligt UNDPs finansiella regler och förordningar, kommer UNDP förvalta mottagen finansiering; framställa konsoliderade narrativa och ekonomiska rapporter, inklusive certifierade bokslut. UNDP kommer att ta ut en 8% avgift för administrationskostnader, så kallad General Management Services (GMS). UNMIL bidrar med kompetens i enlighet med sitt uppdrag i Liberia och specifikt för sin kompetens som en fredsbyggande mission. UNMILs pågående neddragning och kommande totala tillbakadragande, vars tidpunkt beslutas av säkerhetsrådet i december 2016, innebär att det är möjligt (troligt) att programmet kommer att pågå efter tillbakadragandet av UNMIL. Ambassaden bedömer att UNMILs bidrag i programmet i form av kompetens, resurser och nätverk är en fördel för programmet men som ändå kan övertas av UNDP vid ett totalt tillbakadragande av UNMIL. Detta baseras på tidigare erfarenhet av UNDP i säkerhets- och rättsuppbyggnad i Liberia.
Programmet bygger på UNDPs program Justice and Security Joint Programme (avslutat) och pågående Justice and Security Trust Fund II (JSTF II) som Ambassaden har finansierat, varav den senare med SEK 30 498 948 (insatsnummer 52090042). Aktivitetsperioden för JSTF II har nyligen förlängts utan medelstillägg till 2017-04-31. JSTF II har fokuserat på kapacitetsuppbyggnad av Liberias säkerhet –och rättssektor vilket är en huvudprioritet i Liberias transitionsplan. Implementering av JSTF II fördröjdes kraftigt på grund av ebolautbrottet men måluppfyllelse och resultatrapportering för insatsen har uppfyllt ambassadens krav. Programmet har uppnått flera viktiga resultat gällande att stärka kapaciteten för Liberias övertagande av säkerheten i landet samt att öka rättssäkerheten.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The UNDP/UNMIL Joint Rule of Law Programme aims at ensuring a more joined-up approach to rule of law, UNDP and UNMIL intend to develop a joint rule of law, justice and security (ROLJS) programme aimed at successfully implementing UNMIL's mandated tasks and facilitating a seamless transition to more appropriate forms of assistance in the longer term by the UNCT.

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

description.narrative: Reported results in 2018 and 2019 include: Outcome 1: Capacity of justice and security institutions strengthened and linkages forged • Result 1.1: In-depth capacity assessment of the Liberian legislature completed• Result 1.2: Development of new five-year strategic plan (2019-2023) for the judiciary initiated• Result 1.3: Deployment of 60 additional Magisterial Court level judges supported • Result 1.4: Coordination and oversight role of the Ministry of Justice enhanced through continued support to the Planning and Programme Management Unit• Result 1.5: Implementation of the National Human Rights Action Plan of Liberia supported• Result 1.6: Compliance with human rights treaty reporting obligations improved• Result 1.7: Grassroots approaches to safety and security supported, notably by reinforcing the role of the security councils at county and district level• Result 1.8: Regulatory framework put in place for both the Liberia National Police and the Liberia Immigration Service• Result 1.9: Capacity of the LNP Finance Division enhanced by embedding a finance expert • Result 1.10: Implementation of the LNP’s community policing policy supported• Result 1.11: Establishment of a proper plea bargaining system supported• Result 1.12: Deployment of six additional prosecutors, two additional case liaison officers and two additional victim support officers supported • Result 1.13: Investigation and prosecution capacity of the specialised Women and Children Protection Section and the SGBV Crimes Prosecution Unit enhanced• Result 1.14: 153 duty uniforms for LNP personnel purchased and distributed across five counties• Result 1.15: Renovation and refurbishment of border crossings in Garley Town (Grand Gedeh) and Nyeken (River Gee) completed• Result 1.16: 45 motorbikes purchased and handed over to LIS• Result 1.17: Recruitment, training and deployment of 25 additional probation officers supported • Result 1.18: Investigative capacity of the Bureau of Corrections and Rehabilitation enhanced• Result 1.19: Construction of new correctional facility in Robertsport (Grand Cape Mount) completed• Result 1.20: Deployment of nine additional human rights monitors supported • Result 1.21: Capacity assessment of the Independent National Commission on Human Rights undertaken in conjunction with NANHRI• Result 1.22: Confidence- and trust-building between the different justice and security institutions promoted Outcome 2: Civil society contribution to rule of law and community access to justice enhanced• Result 2.1: Partnership agreements put in place with 16 CSOs/CBOs • Result 2.2: Civil society capacity to provide tailored legal aid and assistance enhanced• Result 2.3: Tailored legal aid services provided to 1,243 people, including 744 women and girls• Result 2.4: Legal awareness-raising activities undertaken across 14 counties, reaching a total of 46,776 people• Result 2.5: 684 monitoring visits to local courts and police stations undertaken• Result 2.6: 347 informal justice actors trained on national and international human rights norms and standards• Result 2.7: 599 conflicts and disputes mediated outside the formal justice system, including through a number of community mediation teams• Result 2.8: Linkages between selected CSOs/CBOs and the Independent National Commission on Human Rights strengthened Outcome 3: Gender responsiveness of justice, security and legislative actors strengthened and women and girls’ access to justice and security improved• Result 3.1: Investigation and prosecution capacity of the Women and Children Protection Section and the SGBV Crimes Prosecution Unit enhanced• Result 3.2: Establishment of additional divisions of Court E in Bong and and Nimba supported• Result 3.3: Tailored legal aid services provided to 320 victims/survivors of SGBV• Result 3.4: 299 women and girls assisted to realise their rights under Liberia’s personal status lawsOutcome 4: Capacity of key actors and stakeholders to monitor progress and results in rule of law development supported• Result 4.1: Public expenditure review of the Liberian justice and security sectors undertaken• Result 4.2: Public perception survey to establish the extent to which Liberians engage with and trust the different justice and security institutions completed In 2019, many of the above activities continued. Examples of achieved results in 2019 relating to continued activities include: Support to Criminal Court E, a specialised court for SGBV crimes. enabled the court to function more efficiently. During the period under review, 252 cases were assigned to Criminal Court E, in Monrovia and 172 convictions were secured. Through the programme, Court E was also established in Bong and Nimba and judges were assigned. The Programme procured and delivered two vehicles and six motorbikes to the Judiciary to enhance mobility and transportation needs of the judges and public defenders. This intervention has critically increased access to justice and legal representation with 84 cases being defended by public defenders benefiting 116 persons during the period under review. The Programme provided legal aid services to 670 pre-trial detainees, including 84 women at the police and prisons, resulting in a 3% reduction in arbitrary pre-trial detention. In addition, 1,723 persons benefitted from legal aid services provided by CSOs. Further, 838 monitoring visits were conducted to assess the performance of justice and security institutions.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen är ett stöd för implementering av Forums Syds projekt: ”Sustainable ownership: empowering communities and civil society Liberia”. Projektet har som mål att bygga upp det liberianska civilsamhällets kapacitet genom att stärka och öka närvaron av lokala civilsamhällesorganisationer på den liberianska landsbygden. Civilsamhället avser att öka kapaciteten för rättighetsbärare, som lever under marginaliserade förhållanden, att ha anspråk på sina rättigheter och specifikt rättigheterna att delta i lokala initiativ och utvecklingsprocesser. Projektet kommer nå ut till 26 lokala organisationer (14 som mottagare av bidrag och 12 som motagare av igångsättningsstöd ”seed grants”) i 7 av Liberias 15 counties (län). Projektet har en treårig implementeringscykel från mitten av 2018 till mitten av 2021.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution is a support to Forum Syd for the implementation of the project Sustainable ownership: empwering communities and civil society in Liberia. The project has an objective to build capacity of civil society organizations in Liberia to strengthen local CSOs presence in rural counties in Liberia through increased capacity of rights-holders living under marginalised conditions to claim their rights and participate in locally owned initiatives and local development processes. The project will reach 26 local organizations (14 as receipients of sub-grants and 12 as receipients of seed grants) in seven of Liberia's 15 counties. The project has three years implementation cycle mid 2018-2021. A simplified environment assessment was done by Forum Syd, in additional an environment and climate review by Sida Helpdesk on environment and climate made recommendations that will informed continuous environment improvement in the project. Resources in budget and project work plan for environment and climate has been made. For gender, resources in the budget and plan has been allocated to integrate the gender perspective and Forum Syd has described in their theory of change an attention to mainstream gender. For this reason both environment and climate and gender marker are significant for the project.

The main objective of the proposed intervention is 'Civil society organizations have developed and strengthened their presence in rural counties in Liberia through increased capacity of rights-holders living under marginalized conditions to claim their rights and participate in locally owned initiatives and local development processes.' Three main outcomes are expected to be achieved by the project: 1. Partner organizations and communities have developed their capacities to participate in decision-making processes; 2. Partner organizations have developed their advocacy and monitoring skills of government institutions, public service providers and/or private sector actors' performance in relations to the three thematic areas of the programme; 3. Partner organizations and existing CSO networks have the capacity and resources to develop, fund-raise and implement projects of their own choice that are clearly linked to the needs and priorities identified by involved rights-holder groups and communities. The proposed intervention will reach a total of 26 local CSOs in rural Liberia in two categories - 14 local CSOs as sub-grants and 12 grassroots organizations will receive seed grants. The overall focus of the project is civil society strengthening within three areas: governance and accountability, gender equality and environment and climate change resilience and sustainable use of natural resources. All partners are expected to actively promote gender equality, and some of the organizations will focus on improving environment through sustainable agriculture methods, sustainable energy alternatives, awareness raising on environment and climate change. All partner organizations are expected to mainstream their work through an environment lens, using environmentally sustainable working methods and increase their awareness and knowledge on environment and climate change, natural resource management and rights. The overall goal of the project is to respond to the limited rights and opportunities in rural communities, and the limited presence of participatory and locally based development initiatives. In addition to support to already existing CSOs in the rural areas, the proposed intervention will support non-registered right-holders strengthen their organizations. This is important and relevant for small scale local initiatives that face disadvantage due to high registration cost and lengthy bureaucratic processes that deny them formal registration. Where formal registration is used as criteria to receive donor assistance, rural based organizations representing people living in poverty are often left out. Forum Syd's expressed commitment to reach non-registered right-holders to strengthen their organizations is addressing this important gap. Forum Syd in its proposed intervention intends to achieve its goal to strengthen the capacity of CSOs in rural Liberia through four key methods: a) Build capacities of local CSOs to develop their own sustainability plans and project ideas, as well as to deepen their discussions on their mission and vision, and engage in long-term strategic planning; implement and monitor participatory and inclusive local sustainable development initiatives; be better equipped to raise awareness and mobilize rights-holders through a human rights-based approach and support rights-holders to organize themselves and engage in collective action. b) Strengthen a rights-based and gender aware development of local CSO, supporting increased internal accountability, transparency and member-based decision-making processes; c) Build capacity of local authorities/duty bearers, service providers, community structures and traditional authorities, in their understanding of their duties and obligations, the role of civil society, and how to engage in transparent, accountable, participatory, inclusive, gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable processes with rights-holders and communities d) Promote dialogue and inclusive democratic decision-making processes involving rights-holders, local CSOs and government institutions at the county and national level. The partner organizations to be supported by Forum Syd at the end of the project will demonstrate a number of positive change in attitudes, behaviors and relations: they will be better organized for collective actions on issues relating to gender, environment and and climate change and sustainable use of natural resources; they will have better understanding of the role, obligations and responsibilities of the key duty bearers of the State and will possess better skills to advocate, negotiate and undertake joint activities with duty bearers at the local and national levels. Communities in the seven counties of the project (Bomi, Bong, Grand Gedeh, Nimba, Montserrado, Grand Bassa and Grand Cape Mount) are expected to experience increase activities of Forum Syd supported partners in the areas of gender equality, environment and climate change and sustainable use of natural resources.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

title.narrative: Forum Syd civil society strengthening agreement
Forum Syd civil society strengthening decision on contribution

description.narrative: Specific progress on the three outcomes/result areas are documented below:Outcome 1 (organizations’ capacity to participate in decision-making processes): Forum Syd approved 11 grants to CSOs in 2019 with the aim to strengthen their capacity as organizations and increase their knowledge in thematic areas and the roles of duty bearers and rights holders. Forum Syd also prepared nine new grants for approval by the grant making committee and supported two community events that contributed to Outcome 1: a celebration of activism and an awareness raising event focused on the rights of girls. Outcome 2 (monitoring and advocacy skills): took the form of, for example, women’s leadership empowerment and engaging duty-bearers in dialog on farming and climate change. Under the Land Rights Component, Forum Syd analyzed a mapping Report; devised the grant application focusing on Land Rights; and trained staff and local CSOs in the Forum Syd Right(s) Way Forward (RWF) methodology. Outcome 3 (builds on Outcomes 1 and 2): This is expected to show specific results at a later date but the ground work continues: grant making to CSOs; the land rights component is defined and partners identified and systems, procedures, trained staff and partners are in place.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
