title.narrative: COVID-19 DIAKONIA - Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018 - 2021
COVID-19 DIAKONIA - Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018 - 2021

description.narrative:
Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Diakonia har sökt biståndsmedel från Sida om 42 877 799 SEK för programmet "Ett starkare civilt samhälle för ett värdigt liv" för perioden juni 2018 - maj 2021.
Insatsens övergripande mål är demokratisk en samhällsbyggnad där alla kvinnor, män, flickor och pojkar ska kunna leva i frihet, kräva sina rättigheter och åtnjuta ett liv i fred och värdighet.
Insatsen syftar till att: a. stärka civilsamhället och demokratin samt förespråka ansvarighet, jämställdhet och större respekt för mänskliga rättigheter; b. stärka rösten för kongolesiska medborgare, särskilt kvinnor, när det kommer till utkrävandet av mänskliga rättigheter; c. fler kvinnor ska vara delaktiga i offentliga beslutsfattanden samt att främja lagar och policys som inte är diskriminerande mot kvinnor; d. kongolesiska medborgare använder demokratin, väljer sina lokala, regionala och nationella ledare samt utkräver ansvar ifrån dessa ledare.
Diakonia kommer att genomföra programmet tillsammans med åtta organisationer för det lokala civilsamhället i DR Kongo. Diakonia avser även att ingå avtal med ytterligare partners vad avser kulturella aktiviteter inom programmet. Innan beslut fattas om dessa ska Diakonia först konsultera Sida.
Totalt kommer Diakonia vidareförmedla 56% av budgeten till åtta lokala organisationer. Insatsen kommer huvudsakligen att genomföras i Kongo Central, Kwilu, Maindombe, Kasai Central, Lualaba och Kinshasa.

The programme describes how Diakonia intends to strengthen Congolese civil society organization and administrative as well self-management capacity in the DRC. It also describes objectives and proposed results, mainly focused on the better understanding of the democratic process, motoring of human rights violation, capacity of women and youth leaders to engage with public institutions for life indignity as well youth pro-democracy to engage in democratic debate and to improve DRC transparency and accountability, especially during the State management.

tag.narrative: 3.4 - By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.
3.4 - Till 2030 genom förebyggande insatser och behandling minska det antal människor som dör i förtid av icke smittsamma sjukdomar med en tredjedel samt främja psykisk hälsa och välbefinnande.

title.narrative: Diakonia-Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018-2021

description.narrative: Between 15th June 2019 - May 14th 2020, Diakonia continued to implement “Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018 – 2021” as planned in year 2. But, when the Covid19 pandemic broke out, the DRC Government applied measures that obliged partners to adjust programmes after consultation with the Embassy. The main achievements were in capacity building of all 8 partner organizations: Administrative and Financial Management; Two curricula for Women, Youth, PLWD Human Resources and Civic Education were designed; sensitization campaigns and monitoring of Human Rights was documented; Establishment of Multi-Actor Dialogue Framework and Women & Girls training in Feminine held in all selected provinces; Transformational Leadership and Gender Justice capacity building and production of Training Module on Gender, Women’s Rights; Advocacy by the Demo/HR consortium upon local Electoral training of youth electoral Observation and meaningful vote and participative democracy. Result areas and outcomes during the period include: Outcome 1: Civil society strengthened in order to advocate for democracy, accountability, gender equality and greater respect for Human Rights, in dialogue with duty bearers 33 Dialogue frames established in the 6 provinces (members are now doing joint advocacy activities; The Framework is now considered as the official voice of the CS towards the authorities. They are now asking the frame to provide their input for authorities’ planning) 3 Consortia established (2 are functional: Human Rights defenders and Democracy) by ACAJ, VSV, CEHAJ1325 for HR chaired by ACAJ; by NSCC, LYREC and CEJP for Democracy chaired by NSCC. Staffs from all 8 partner organisations have had their financial management capacity reinforced, resulting in their financial management practices, as shown by the audit report which showed drastic improvements. Outcome 2: The Congolese citizens, in particular women and youth, demand respect for Human Rights Human Rights Module (being prepared by CEHAJ1325 Specialists): To be integrated into the Basic Education Curriculum. A Civic Education Module on Human Rights (under preparation, by ACAJ Specialists) Human Rights sensitisation campaigns in the 6 provinces (by ACAJ, VSV, LYREC & CEHAJ1325) Workshop on Human Rights Violation Monitoring (Kongo Central, by ACAJ) Monitoring of Human Rights Violation (VSV) Study on Human Rights practices within security services (Ongoing, by CEHAJ1325) Protection of HRD in danger (by HR Protection Mechanism set by Diakonia within the HR Consortium) Outcome 3: Increased number of women present in public decision-making processes promoting non-discriminatory laws and public policies towards women Electoral reforms Advocacy (by Diakonia partners and non partners, led by NSCC; result: preparation of & dissemination of CS-wide Vade-Mecum); initiatives to reinforce DRC Women’s political participation (led by FMJC; resulting in an Advocacy Strategy) Girls’ participation in decision-making organs at the local level: This to be revealed by the evaluation report. Preparation of a training module on gender and Women’s Rights (by CONAFED, distributed to Gender & Development Local Committees). Outcome 4: Congolese citizens embrace democracy, elect their provincial and national leaders, and hold them to account Deployment of community mobilisers and dissemination of sensitization materials/cards on decentralization and local elections: Diakonia noticed an improvement in the understanding of their role by the population as rights-holders in terms of democracy and elections (consciousness). Compilation and validation of Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue Frameworks’ priority list (these have been sent to Provincial Governments for consideration in their planning cycles). Awareness-raising Campaign on ‘Meaningful’ Voting and Participatory Democracy. (Impact: The Catholic Church confirmed that the population voted according to manifesto, not personalities). Training of Election Observers (Impact: EU, Carter Centre, AU Observation missions all uploaded the vital and important role played by Congolese Electoral Observers. This is expected to continue for local elections, still to be held).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF - Stöd till landprogram i DRK 2018-2021
COVID-19 UNICEF - Support to Unicef country program in DRC 2018-2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 UNICEF has submitted an application for support to its country program. This contribution is a consolidated support to the implementation of UNICEF country program in DRC, focusing on three thematic areas: health, protection of children who previously were involved with in armed groups and strengthening vulnerable societies’ capacity to withstand recurrent crises (resilience).
The contribution is in line with the priorities of Sweden's Development Cooperation Strategy with DRC 2021-2025- specifically areas 2: Equitable health and nutrition, result area 3: Inclusive and sustainable communities as well as our cross-cutting focus resilience/nexus by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable groups and societies.
This support will specifically contribute to improved access to high-quality care for children and pregnant women. Explicitly, the contribution’s results concern improved vaccination coverage, access to basic drugs to treat diarrhea, pneumonia and malaria at community levels, water and sanitation, and the strengthening of health systems for sustainability of the results. Attention to young women and adolescents' SRHR needs (including menstrual hygiene) is emphasized more than ever, in line with UNICEF Gender Action Plan (GAP) 2018-2021.
Children released from armed groups will have access to psychosocial assistance and be given support to reintegrate their communities, resume their education or engage in economic activities. The contribution will also help strengthen resilience or reduce vulnerability (health / nutrition, education, conflict transformation / reconciliation, water and sanitation, etc.) among internally displaced persons and local populations so that they can better prevent or cope with further crises in the future.
UNICEF's country program in DRC covered initially the period 2013-2017, it was then extended until 2019. The current program covers the period 2020-2024, and is based on UNICEF's global Strategic Plan 2018-2021 adopted by UNICEF's Board in 2017. The priority areas of the UNICEF country program are health, protection of vulnerable children (protection), education and humanitarian assistance and resilience.
Sida previously supported UNICEF DRC through three different contributions: one thematic support for health, one project's support for child protection and another for resilience. This contribution is a consolidated model and has gradually gathered all Swedish support to UNICEF DRC country program. This modality aims to increase both ??flexibility (easier planning and reinforcing synergies between interventions in the focus areas on the partner's side), but also cost-effectiveness by enabling better utilization of resources (including reduced administrative staff time and cost, joint follow-up and dialogue meetings, etc.) for both UNICEF and the Embassy. In 2018, this support was directed to health, whereas in 2019 both health and protection of children associated with armed conflict will be supported. From 2020 the Embassy had only one comprehensive contribution to UNICEF country programme in DRC through all three focus areas (health, child protection and resilience).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 United Nations Childrens Fund (Unicef) har vänt sig till Sida och ansökt om stöd till implementering av landprogrammet. Stödet är tematiskt och omfattar hälsa, skydd för barn som kommit i kontakt med väpnade grupper samt förstärkning av utsatta samhällens kapacitet att stå emot återkommande kriser.
Insatsen motsvarar Sveriges prioriteringar i den nuvarande strategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med DRK 2021-2025, särskilt avseende områdena förbättrad grundläggande hälsa och värnad mänsklig säkerhet och frihet från våld.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till en förbättrad lokal tillgång till en högkvalitativ vård för barn och gravida kvinnor, särskilt avseende tillgång till vaccination och basläkemedel för diarréer, lunginflammation och malaria. Dessutom åsyftas en förbättrad tillgång till lokala vatten- och sanitetssystem samt även till ett allmänt förstärkt hälsosystem. I linje med Unicefs aktionsplan för genderfrågor (Gender Action Plan, 2018-2021) betonas särskilt unga kvinnors och ungdomars behov av stöd avseende sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR).
Vidare avser insatsen att ge de barn som deltagit i beväpnade grupper tillgång till psykosocialt stöd. Dessutom omfattas stöd till barnens integrering i deras ursprungliga samhällen samt återupptagande av skolgång eller egen försörjning genom ekonomiska aktiviteter. Insatsen avser även bidra till att förstärka och minska sårbarheten hos internflyktingar och lokalbefolkning genom bl.a. förbättrad hälsa, nutrition, utbildning samt vatten- och sanitet så att de lättare klarar av framtida kriser.
Unicefs landprogram i DRK nuvarande landprogram gäller för perioden 2020-2024. Programmet bygger vidare på Unicefs globala verksamhetsplan (2018-2021) som antogs av Unicefs styrelse år 2017.
Sida har tidigare lämnat stöd till Unicef i DRK genom tre olika insatser: ett tematiskt stöd till hälsa, ett projektsstöd till barnsskydd och ett projektsstöd till resiliens. Denna instats lägger ihop dessa tidigare projektstöd. Det samlade stödet innebär ökad flexibilitet och effektivitet i planering och implentering, bl.a. på grund av tydligare synergier mellan de berörda fokusområdena. Stödet bedöms även leda till en effektivare resursanvändning av personal samt ett effektivare samarbete mellan Unicef och ambassaden.

This contribution is aimed at supporting the implementation of UNICEF Country Programme in DRC 2020-2024 that focuses on the achievement of the following goal areas: 1) every child survives and thrives, 2) every child is protected from violence and 3) every child lives in a safe and clean environment. The theory of change is that this goal will be achieved if: (a) quality basic social services are delivered at scale; (b) region-specific approaches address child deprivations and gender-based inequalities that characterize each region; and (c) district-level models involving multi-sector convergence are replicated across the country. The underlying assumptions are that the Government will increase investments in basic social services and decentralisation, and there will be a reduction in violence and conflict. The programme will address system-wide bottlenecks to social services through (a) generating data and evidence for planning and monitoring; (b) policy reforms, strategic advocacy and use of evidence to deliver at scale; (c) strengthening of institutional capacities and community systems for quality service delivery; (d) influencing public investment and (e) leveraging resources and partners, including the private sector. In health, the objective of the intervention is specifically to increase the coverage of high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health in the countries' health zones and to encourage the adoption of responsible behaviours by adolescents and young people to prevent unwanted pregnancies, HIV/AIDS and human papilloma virus (HPV) as well as to support positive health policy development centrally and at intermediate levels in the country. It is expected that in four years time, three quarters of the 516 Health Zones in DRC will be able to provide the high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health, and at least 80% of targeted villages are certified as child-friendly communities. Among key indicators is the percentage of children <11 months receiving a third dose of DTP-containing vaccine from 81% in 2017 to 95% in 2024. With regard to protection, this intervention will contribute to promote governance for child protection and strengthening protective environment from all forms of violence in the country. In terms of results, the support will contribute to identification, interim care and psychosocial support, reunification and reintegration measures and quality services for at least 50% of the affected children; as well as to operationalization of surveillance mechanisms. Another indicator is the number of territories implementing the child protection network (from 62% in 2018 to 85% in 2024). In addition for the reintegration of child ex-combatants, Unicef ??will have to focus more on the work of the MONUSCO of SSU via ISSSS (international security and stabilization support strategy) on the present demobilization agreement of FRPI in Ituri. In terms of protection, Unicef ??will have to strengthen the mechanism for child birth registration and find out how to lead the lobbying and advocacy to catch up with cases of children who have not been registered within 90 days of birth in the fragile zones. The interventions in transitional zones is aimed at improving coverage of basic social services and in strengthening communities' capacity to manage key risks and vulnerabilities. Results in terms of increased access to basic social services concern access to primary education, to health services including prevention and treatment of severe malnutrition, to safe water and sanitation. Strengthening community-level social protection networks, including using cash transfer mechanisms. Unicef ??will have to make intersectorality effective through CAC (cellule d'animation communautaire : multisectoral structure responsible for coordinating all development initiatives at the local level) after the integration of PEAR + 3 into this support to the country program but also to make analysis of the actions to be carried out after the response to Ebola outbreak.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: In 2018, UNICEF piloted the Child-Friendly Community (CFC) approach, with the aim of reducing the multiple deprivations of children, adolescents, and young people through community platforms. This approach focused on the zones of convergence - service delivery at both the community and facility level to complete an integrated package of health, nutrition, HIV, WASH, child protection, education, and communication for development (C4D) across the life cycle of a child. 406 villages are currently been covered in three health zones: Nsele health zone in Kinshasa province, Mbanzangungu in Kongo Central, and Kenge in Kwango. In 2018, 60 per cent of the villages received health services through facilities or through outreach, and 210 had functional community structures that track and analyse the Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child and Adolescent Health (RMNCAH) of the population with corrective actions. All 406 villages have restructured their community-based organisations and started community monitoring on five key interventions: immunization, home treatment of diarrhoea, vitamin A supplementation, deworming, and birth registration; with 604 community health workers closely following-up on the five interventions and key family practices for 28,535 children under-five and 1,121 pregnant women.In 43 health zones, three million family kits with basic drugs and a clean delivery kit were distributed to over 1,500,000 children under-five and 176,854 pregnant women, contributing to a remarkable reduction of the child mortality rate due to severe diarrhoea from five per cent in 2017 to 1.2 per cent in 2018 in the targeted health zones, and to the national reduction from 3.1 per cent in 2017 to 1.1 per cent in 2018. In 2018, twenty-four measures to implement the revised family code were developed, thereby improving the child protection legal framework. Improved collaboration and cooperation between social service providers and community-based actors led to the identification and referral to basic protection services of 608,890 vulnerable children. In non-conflict areas, survivors of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) received holistic and appropriate support, with 1,702 benefitting from medical consultations, 2,101 from psychosocial support (MHPSS), 413 from socioeconomic reintegration assistance, and 143 from legal aid. In 2018, PEAR+III specifically sought to empower communities in three health zones to strengthen social protection and cohesion mechanisms as a means to contribute to durable peace and development. More than 3,000 children were reintegrated in school by using school improvement plan grants to cover their school fees in North Kivu and Ituri provinces. In addition, 1,450 children participated in 34 peace clubs and 50 teachers received training on peacebuilding. Almost 200 parent teacher associations (COGES) and parent committees (COPA) members received training on children’s rights and good governance. Treatment for severely malnourished children benefitted to 3,147 children in transitional communities in the 120 villages were covered with nutrition support in North Kivu and Ituri provinces.To improve access to water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH), 21 water points were rehabilitated, and 169 villages and 94 schools received post-certification for Village Ecoles Assainis (Health Villages and Schools).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF - Stöd till landprogram i DRK 2018-2021
COVID-19 UNICEF - Support to Unicef country program in DRC 2018-2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 UNICEF has submitted an application for support to its country program. This contribution is a consolidated support to the implementation of UNICEF country program in DRC, focusing on three thematic areas: health, protection of children who previously were involved with in armed groups and strengthening vulnerable societies’ capacity to withstand recurrent crises (resilience).
The contribution is in line with the priorities of Sweden's Development Cooperation Strategy with DRC 2021-2025- specifically areas 2: Equitable health and nutrition, result area 3: Inclusive and sustainable communities as well as our cross-cutting focus resilience/nexus by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable groups and societies.
This support will specifically contribute to improved access to high-quality care for children and pregnant women. Explicitly, the contribution’s results concern improved vaccination coverage, access to basic drugs to treat diarrhea, pneumonia and malaria at community levels, water and sanitation, and the strengthening of health systems for sustainability of the results. Attention to young women and adolescents' SRHR needs (including menstrual hygiene) is emphasized more than ever, in line with UNICEF Gender Action Plan (GAP) 2018-2021.
Children released from armed groups will have access to psychosocial assistance and be given support to reintegrate their communities, resume their education or engage in economic activities. The contribution will also help strengthen resilience or reduce vulnerability (health / nutrition, education, conflict transformation / reconciliation, water and sanitation, etc.) among internally displaced persons and local populations so that they can better prevent or cope with further crises in the future.
UNICEF's country program in DRC covered initially the period 2013-2017, it was then extended until 2019. The current program covers the period 2020-2024, and is based on UNICEF's global Strategic Plan 2018-2021 adopted by UNICEF's Board in 2017. The priority areas of the UNICEF country program are health, protection of vulnerable children (protection), education and humanitarian assistance and resilience.
Sida previously supported UNICEF DRC through three different contributions: one thematic support for health, one project's support for child protection and another for resilience. This contribution is a consolidated model and has gradually gathered all Swedish support to UNICEF DRC country program. This modality aims to increase both ??flexibility (easier planning and reinforcing synergies between interventions in the focus areas on the partner's side), but also cost-effectiveness by enabling better utilization of resources (including reduced administrative staff time and cost, joint follow-up and dialogue meetings, etc.) for both UNICEF and the Embassy. In 2018, this support was directed to health, whereas in 2019 both health and protection of children associated with armed conflict will be supported. From 2020 the Embassy had only one comprehensive contribution to UNICEF country programme in DRC through all three focus areas (health, child protection and resilience).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 United Nations Childrens Fund (Unicef) har vänt sig till Sida och ansökt om stöd till implementering av landprogrammet. Stödet är tematiskt och omfattar hälsa, skydd för barn som kommit i kontakt med väpnade grupper samt förstärkning av utsatta samhällens kapacitet att stå emot återkommande kriser.
Insatsen motsvarar Sveriges prioriteringar i den nuvarande strategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med DRK 2021-2025, särskilt avseende områdena förbättrad grundläggande hälsa och värnad mänsklig säkerhet och frihet från våld.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till en förbättrad lokal tillgång till en högkvalitativ vård för barn och gravida kvinnor, särskilt avseende tillgång till vaccination och basläkemedel för diarréer, lunginflammation och malaria. Dessutom åsyftas en förbättrad tillgång till lokala vatten- och sanitetssystem samt även till ett allmänt förstärkt hälsosystem. I linje med Unicefs aktionsplan för genderfrågor (Gender Action Plan, 2018-2021) betonas särskilt unga kvinnors och ungdomars behov av stöd avseende sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR).
Vidare avser insatsen att ge de barn som deltagit i beväpnade grupper tillgång till psykosocialt stöd. Dessutom omfattas stöd till barnens integrering i deras ursprungliga samhällen samt återupptagande av skolgång eller egen försörjning genom ekonomiska aktiviteter. Insatsen avser även bidra till att förstärka och minska sårbarheten hos internflyktingar och lokalbefolkning genom bl.a. förbättrad hälsa, nutrition, utbildning samt vatten- och sanitet så att de lättare klarar av framtida kriser.
Unicefs landprogram i DRK nuvarande landprogram gäller för perioden 2020-2024. Programmet bygger vidare på Unicefs globala verksamhetsplan (2018-2021) som antogs av Unicefs styrelse år 2017.
Sida har tidigare lämnat stöd till Unicef i DRK genom tre olika insatser: ett tematiskt stöd till hälsa, ett projektsstöd till barnsskydd och ett projektsstöd till resiliens. Denna instats lägger ihop dessa tidigare projektstöd. Det samlade stödet innebär ökad flexibilitet och effektivitet i planering och implentering, bl.a. på grund av tydligare synergier mellan de berörda fokusområdena. Stödet bedöms även leda till en effektivare resursanvändning av personal samt ett effektivare samarbete mellan Unicef och ambassaden.

This contribution is aimed at supporting the implementation of UNICEF Country Programme in DRC 2020-2024 that focuses on the achievement of the following goal areas: 1) every child survives and thrives, 2) every child is protected from violence and 3) every child lives in a safe and clean environment. The theory of change is that this goal will be achieved if: (a) quality basic social services are delivered at scale; (b) region-specific approaches address child deprivations and gender-based inequalities that characterize each region; and (c) district-level models involving multi-sector convergence are replicated across the country. The underlying assumptions are that the Government will increase investments in basic social services and decentralisation, and there will be a reduction in violence and conflict. The programme will address system-wide bottlenecks to social services through (a) generating data and evidence for planning and monitoring; (b) policy reforms, strategic advocacy and use of evidence to deliver at scale; (c) strengthening of institutional capacities and community systems for quality service delivery; (d) influencing public investment and (e) leveraging resources and partners, including the private sector. In health, the objective of the intervention is specifically to increase the coverage of high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health in the countries' health zones and to encourage the adoption of responsible behaviours by adolescents and young people to prevent unwanted pregnancies, HIV/AIDS and human papilloma virus (HPV) as well as to support positive health policy development centrally and at intermediate levels in the country. It is expected that in four years time, three quarters of the 516 Health Zones in DRC will be able to provide the high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health, and at least 80% of targeted villages are certified as child-friendly communities. Among key indicators is the percentage of children <11 months receiving a third dose of DTP-containing vaccine from 81% in 2017 to 95% in 2024. With regard to protection, this intervention will contribute to promote governance for child protection and strengthening protective environment from all forms of violence in the country. In terms of results, the support will contribute to identification, interim care and psychosocial support, reunification and reintegration measures and quality services for at least 50% of the affected children; as well as to operationalization of surveillance mechanisms. Another indicator is the number of territories implementing the child protection network (from 62% in 2018 to 85% in 2024). In addition for the reintegration of child ex-combatants, Unicef ??will have to focus more on the work of the MONUSCO of SSU via ISSSS (international security and stabilization support strategy) on the present demobilization agreement of FRPI in Ituri. In terms of protection, Unicef ??will have to strengthen the mechanism for child birth registration and find out how to lead the lobbying and advocacy to catch up with cases of children who have not been registered within 90 days of birth in the fragile zones. The interventions in transitional zones is aimed at improving coverage of basic social services and in strengthening communities' capacity to manage key risks and vulnerabilities. Results in terms of increased access to basic social services concern access to primary education, to health services including prevention and treatment of severe malnutrition, to safe water and sanitation. Strengthening community-level social protection networks, including using cash transfer mechanisms. Unicef ??will have to make intersectorality effective through CAC (cellule d'animation communautaire : multisectoral structure responsible for coordinating all development initiatives at the local level) after the integration of PEAR + 3 into this support to the country program but also to make analysis of the actions to be carried out after the response to Ebola outbreak.

Community Health and Social Accountability Programme (CHASP) aims at increasing the utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, New-born, Child Health (RMNCH) services that are accessible, acceptable, affordable and equitable through provision of essential package for health services. The programme is implemented in three different regions and a total of 10 districts of Somalia and has dual objectives: 1) to increase the utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, New-born, Child Health (RMNCH) services; and 2) to develop a strong community, district and regional level referral health system. The programme primarily targets women of reproductive age and children under five years of age for health services. Besides contributing to strengthened health systems, the intervention will increase the health seeking behaviour for women and make reproductive health services accessible and affordable for the target beneficiaries. The programme will further contribute to bridging the gap between health facilities and communities.

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Save the Children has submitted an application for program support for the years 2017-2019, with a total of 90,000,000 kronor. The contribution aims to help strengthen the Somali health sector by supporting primary health care at local level. By strengthening the capacity of local authorities in governance and decision making regarding health issues, increasing access and quality of services, and strengthening the empowerment and resilience of the population, this effort is considered to contribute to improving community health. In addition, the main focus of this contribution lies on maternity, neonatal and child health in order to help strengthen the health of women and children and their potential for survival.
Since 2012, Sida has supported the Somali health sector through a comprehensive UN Joint Program (WHO, UNICEF and UNFPA), entitled Joint Health and Nutrition Program (JHNP). UN organizations in Somalia are mainly non-implementing partners and therefore subcontract local organizations, such as Save the Children to perform and deliver services. Save the Children was the largest implementing partner organization within JHNP, which laid the foundation for the design of this new program after the JHNP ended. Sida, together with the Swiss Development Cooperation in Somalia (SDC), chose to proceed with Save the Children as an individual and direct partner, given the work previously implemented by the organization were successful. Save the Children also has access to many regions around Somalia, including hard-to-reach areas, which this contribution aims to focus on.
The choice to prepare a new support to Save the Children to strengthen the local health sector with particular attention to three regions - Galmudug, Jubbaland and Bari. The selection of regions for project implementation was guided by Save the Children, who concludes that these regions lag behind other regions in terms of access to essential health services. It is worth to remember that these regions are all previous JHNP regions and so continuation of services remains essential.
Decision on contribution will be taken by the Head of Afica Department at Sida Stockholm.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Rädda Barnen har inkommit med en ansökan för programstöd för perioden 2017-2019, med en totalt budget på 144 322 317 kronor. Sidas andel uppgår till totalt 90 000 000 kronor. Schweiz står för resterande andelen. Insatsen syftar till att dels bidra till fortsatt tillgång av basal hälso-och-sjukvårdstjänster för gravida kvinnor och barn under fem år i tre regioner i Somalia, dels fortsätta stödja uppbyggnaden av den Somaliska hälsosektorn med fokus på hälsosystem på lokal och regionalnivå. Insatsen bygger vidare på det stöd som Sverige tidigare har gett till hälsosektorn (bland annat genom Joint Health and Nutrition Program, JHNP), samtidigt som den utforskar nya aspekter inklusive implementeringsforskning för ett förbättrad resultat och kvalité. Vidare, avser instatsen att stärka kapaciteten hos de lokala auktoriteter med styrning och beslutsfattande för hälsofrågor, öka tillgången och kvalitén av hälso-och-sjukvårdstjänster samt stärka egenmakten och resiliensen hos befolkningen.
Sida har sedan 2012 stött den Somaliska hälsosektorn främst genom tre olika program inklusive ett givargemensamt FN-program (WHO, UNICEF och UNFPA), så kallad Joint Health and Nutrition Program (JHNP). Två av de enskilda program som Sida tidigare gav stöd till (Dalarna Högskola barnmorskeprogram och UNFPA pilot program för våld mot kvinnor) samt de JHNP komponenter (reproduktiv, mödra och neonatal hälsa) som UNFPA ansvarade för ingår sedan juli 2017 inom ramen för det stöd som Sida ger till UNFPA:s landprogram för år 2017. Stödet till UNFPA för perioden 2018-2020 kommer att fr.o.m. januari 2018 ingå i Sidas stöd till FN fonden (UN MPTF) för strategiska skäl (för mer information, se gärna beslut om insats med beslutsnummer 28/17). Innehållet i det program förslag som Rädda Barnen har presenterat för Sida bygger vidare på den komponent av JHNP som framför allt UNICEF ansvarade för. UNICEF implementerar inga program utan anlitar internationella och lokala organisationer, såsom Rädda Barnen för att utföra och leverera hälsotjänster. Rädda Barnen var den största implementerande partnerorganisationen inom JHNP och för UNICEF, vilket la grunden till utformandet av detta nya program, efter att JHNP avslutades. Sida, tillsammans med den Schweiziska biståndsmyndigheten (SDC), valde att gå vidare med Rädda Barnen som enskild partnersorganisation då insatserna som tidigare implementerats av organisationen var framgångsrika. Rädda Barnen har dessutom åtkomst till många regioner runtom Somalia, även svåråtkomliga områden, som denna insats avser inrikta sig på.
Sida gör därför bedömningen att planerad insats är a) i linje med resultaten för Sveriges strategi för utvecklingssamarbete, b) i linje med resultaten i Somalias nationella utvecklingsplan, samt c) bygger vidare på det stöd som Sida tidigare har gett i hälsosektorn. Denna insats bygger på principen flexibilitet och "doing development differently" och kommer att ge Sida möjligheten att bättre förstå vad som fungerar och inte i en fragil och konfliktpåverkad kontext som Somalia.
Beslut om insats tas av chef för Afrikaavdelningen på Sida Stockholm.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: 51270022 - Decision on amendment of contribution - CHASP

description.narrative: During the third year of program implementation, CHASP continued the delivery of quality healthcare servicers combined with diverse capacity building interventions in 10 districts across Jubaland, Galmudug and Puntland. This has contributed significantly to increased access and availability of healthcare in targeted regions especially hard-to-reach areas. In the reporting period, the intervention reached 429,124 beneficiaries (178,565 males and 250,559 females), accounting for more than half of the overall health facility utilisation rate of 782,087 with quality health interventions, establishing resilient health systems and robust community structures thus laying a strong foundation for sustainability. Antenatal care results carried out during a client satisfaction interviews shows that, majority of pregnant women attended the health facilities were provided folic acid, iron tablets, tetanus toxoid injection and counseled on the importance of antenatal care and recommended diertary intake. In order to maintain adaptive programming, the intervention continued to conduct a series of research studies and client satisfaction surveys in some of the supported facilities In addition, a study to understand progress in knowledge of care givers on infant and young breast-feeding, children dietary diversity and community health status was also conducted in two districts with findings helping to modify the breast-feeding practices and nutrition programming approach. Following the dissemination of above mentioned research findings conducted, the Ministry of Health and other key health actors in the proogramme-supported regions have adapted these key findings and recommendations with the aim of improving quality health service delivery. Other results achieved in year three include: - Cost per beneficiary ratio for year 3 was maintained at 114 SEK as compared to 250 SEK in year 2;- Flexibility of the programme design maintained to adapt to changing context and learning experiences, COVID 19 and emergency funding utilized;- 77% increase in health facility utilization as compared to year 2 and more effective and efficient health leadership and coordination both at district and state level; - Rehabilitated three health facilities in Bari region. In Horseed health centre, the programme renovated the perimeter fence while in Dharjaale, the community constructed three extension rooms for delivery services; - An elevated water tank constructed for Kobdhexaad health centre improving general sanitation of the health facility, and an underground water reservoir constructed for Baargaal Referral Health centre, ensuring consistent supply of clean water at the health facility; - Stronger community involvement and ownership laying foundation for sustainability. In Galmudug, there is a slight decrease in children under five utilization for year 3 as compared to year 2. This is due to accessibility issues and migration of the population.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Community Health and Social Accountability Programme (CHASP) aims at increasing the utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, New-born, Child Health (RMNCH) services that are accessible, acceptable, affordable and equitable through provision of essential package for health services. The programme is implemented in three different regions and a total of 10 districts of Somalia and has dual objectives: 1) to increase the utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, New-born, Child Health (RMNCH) services; and 2) to develop a strong community, district and regional level referral health system. The programme primarily targets women of reproductive age and children under five years of age for health services. Besides contributing to strengthened health systems, the intervention will increase the health seeking behaviour for women and make reproductive health services accessible and affordable for the target beneficiaries. The programme will further contribute to bridging the gap between health facilities and communities.

title.narrative: FPU - Ethical Journalism for Syrian media phase 2
Free Press Unlimited - Etisk journalistik för syrisk media, fas 2

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Free Press Unlimited har ansökt om 92 500 000 SEK för att genomföra sitt Syrien-program 2016-2020.
Syrien är ett av världens farligaste länder för journalister att arbeta i och yttrandefrihet samt tillgång till information är extremt begränsad. Som en följd av den svåra säkerhetssituationen har många journalister i dag lämnat Syrien och för såväl syrier som en internationell publik är därför tillgången till information om vad som händer inne i landet ytterst begränsad. Därutöver är förekomsten av censur, anklagelser mot journalister för att vara subjektiva, propaganda och politisk/agendadriven information väldigt vanlig. I kombination med att den syriska mediasektorn är/har varit väldigt kontrollerad under Assadregimen finns det ett stort underskott på kompetenta mediaorganisationer som verkar i Syrien/bevakar Syrien från grannländerna. Därmed är även bristen på information om övergrepp som begås i landet omfattande.
Genom den föreslagna insatsen kommer FPU stärka och professionalisera ett antal syriska mediaorganisationer att driva ekonomiskt hållbara verksamheter, arbeta enligt journalistiskt etiska riktlinjer samt producera journalistiskt material av god kvalitet. Detta görs via ett samarbete med Synergy-Takemol som ansvarar för mycket av kapacitetsutvecklingen. En professionell mediasektor kan spela en viktig roll för att informera och skapa medvetenhet hos den syriska befolkningen om olika problem och övergrepp som sker i landet. Press- och informationsfrihet är nödvändiga komponenter för att samla, producera och sprida pålitlig och objektiv information. Trots den pågående konflikten i Syrien har syrisk media utvecklats och diversifierats markant under de senaste åren - bland annat med hjälp av FPU. FPU har tidigare, med stöd av Sida och EU, utvecklat ett syriskt journalistförbund och etablerat en etisk stadga som syriska mediaorganisationer frivilligt kan ansluta sig till. Journalistförbundet ska främja fri och professionell journalistik i Syrien och medverkar till att skapa månatliga rapporter om övergrepp mot journalister i Syrien. Den etiska stadgan ska skydda sina medlemmar och hålla dem ansvariga för att respektera mediaetiska riktlinjer. FPU:s arbete med journalistförbundet och den etiska stadgan kommer fortsätta och fördjupas som en del av denna insats.
Programmet ska även bidra till att framställa tillförlitlig data om det syriska medialandskapet och dess användare och göra denna information allmänt tillgänglig. För att förbättra effektiviteten och organisationen hos syrisk media kommer FPU att engagera det syriskt ledda mediacentret Mawared i Gaziantep. Mawared ska utföra forskning, bidra till nätverkande och koordination samt anordna utbildningsmöjligheter för syriska mediaorganisationer.
Sida bedömer att FPU:s insats är kontextanpassad och högst relevant. FPU har identifierat relevanta problem inom den syriska mediasektorn och har utformat sitt program på ett effektivt sätt. Programmets förväntade resultat är i linje med Sveriges strategi för Syrienkrisen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Syrian uprising in 2011 quickly developed into a full scale war. The conflict has created the biggest humanitarian crisis since World War II and a very large number of Syrians are internally and externally displaced. As one of many disastrous results of the conflict, Syria is today one of the most dangerous countries in the world for journalists to work in and freedom of expression and information is extremely limited. The most important source of information for both Syrian citizens and the international audience is local citizen journalists that are risking their lives to provide media outlets with reports and recordings of protests and atrocities inside Syria. Journalists are often direct targets for warring factions (including the regime, oppositional groups, rebels, Daesh/Islamic State, other Islamist extremist groups, etc.) that seek to prevent information about atrocities and other violent events from being dispersed locally, nationally and internationally. As a consequence, many journalists have been forced to now work from abroad, mainly in neighboring countries, which have complicated their work significantly.
Moreover, propaganda and politicized news/information is very common since different actors in the conflict have different interests and a lot to gain through limitations of reporting about the actual situation on the ground. The regime continuously labels reports about human rights abuses and war crimes as fake, and many journalists are accused of being biased in their reporting. The regime exercise thorough surveillance of all kinds of information channels and Internet censorship is very common. This has effectively limited the spread of information and documentation about committed atrocities even further.
Furthermore, since the Syrian media sector has been heavily controlled by the national authorities, the capacity among media organisations to present objective reporting and run economically sustainable businesses is very limited.
This proposed intervention aims to strengthen and professionalise Syrian media organisations towards sustainability, increased ethically sound and qualitatively high reporting. A specific focus is on helping people to build trust and work together. Naturally, a professional media sector can play an important role to inform and create awareness about societal issues among the Syrian population. It can also create debate and increase transparency. Freedom of the press and freedom of information are crucial elements for gathering, producing and disseminating reliable and unbiased information. Despite all the difficulties in the country in recent years, Syrian media has developed significantly and the sector has become more diversified. However, it still needs to improve further with regards to aspects as professionalism, quality, and content. FPU has already successfully managed to establish an ethical charter for Syrian media organisations (funded by Sida and the EU). The charter aims to protect the members and holding them accountable to respecting media ethics and today includes more than 30 organisations. The members have committed themselves to adhere to the rules established in the charter, which will contribute to improving their level of reporting. Moreover, FPU has also supported Syrian Journalists Association (SJA), an institution that aims to promote free and professional journalism in Syria through, for instance, promote ethical journalism, challenge impunity over attacks on journalists, and repeal laws that restrict journalism. SJA has established a Freedom Centre that publishes a monthly report on violations against Syrian journalists. SJA has also been Active on assisting members in their work and with networking. The charter's and SJA's work will be continued and deepened as part of this intervention.
The proposed programme also aims to support and contribute to reliable data on the Syrian media environment and audiences through independent and publicly accessible research and improving the effectiveness and organization of Syrian media. FPU has engaged in the development of the media centre Mawared, which will be crucial in this work. Mawared is expected to facilitate networking, conduct research, coordination activities and training sessions for Syrian media organisations. An added value with the centre is that it, as being Syrian-led, will increase the level of local ownership of the development of the Syrian media sector. Additional capacity building activities for Syrian media organisations will be arranged by the implementing partner Synergy-Takamol.
Sida's assessment is that FPU’s programme is highly relevant and context-specific. It targets problems relating to media in Syria in an efficient and sustainable way. The expected result of the programme is also in line with Sweden’s strategy for the Syria crisis.

sector.narrative: Media and free flow of information

tag.narrative: 16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Assessing any results in the media sector requires taking into account that the programme's starting point for dialogue and coordination was low. At the start of the Arab spring Syria had never had a functioning independent media. Many media producers were new to the sector and there had not been any functioning media institutions for decades. Since then, Syrian media has gone in exile and prospects of returning to Syria are improbable. Syrian media is in need for capacity building both in respect of institutional strengthening as well as supporting the development of media contents as well as security training. In this context, the Syrian media sector is still emerging and only starting to take on the role of holding media and professionals accountable for their actions. Free Press Unlimited has managed to carry out the support with a holistic programmatic approach and the strategic planning has managed to start a process of building the framework the Syrian media needs to become sustainable. This is shown in reports as well as the mid-term review carried out spring 2019. Results of the support are demonstrated in all various reporting from the supported media organisations. Organisational capacity building including financial management and audit, has resulted in the partners becoming "audit proof", a term used in the reports. This is verified also in the unqualified audit reports of the FPU project. FPU has facilitated audience surveys in Syria, in both opposition controlled areas and government held territory. New audience research is planned to contribute to the strategic planning. Focus on media content in the capacity building has also contributed to development of the partners, never the least in discussing the role of independent media, despite the background of most exile media having grown from the revolution. It is a challenge in this regard to reach an independent and neutral media reporting not linked to any political action or movement. In this perspective the support to the Ethical Charter has played an important role. The Charter is a growing forum for Syrian Journalists where the the member media partners discuss and agree on ethical rules for media production. Objectivity and neutrality has along with accountability, including media's own accountability, has become playing a more and more important role. The Charter has also included a complaints mechanism. In this particular component of the support, FPU has taken the project one step further beyond basic coordination. More than to contribute to enhanced effectiveness of the media sector, FPU has facilitated a dialogue between different Syrian media with different background in order to raise the quality of the media production and inject ethics as well as gender or media's own accountability in to the discussions. The mid-term review of the project presented spring 2019 also points out the Ethical Charter as a success with impact. In line with this the review recommends FPU to create several Spaces for debate on independent Syrian media. Other recommendations are to continue tailored supports in strategic audience development and funding. The review also recommends FPU to look more into the audience research benefits. One conclusion from the first year of the programme is still valid; media institutions are the most vulnerable. Yet, it is exactly this type of partner that should be leading in starting dialogue and coordination for the work with human rights and towards democracy. FPU came to realise that beside strengthening the partners’ capacity, to be able to obtain results, is fostering dialogue and consequently cooperation. In all, it is Sida's assessment that the results of the FPU project Ethical Journalism for Syrian Media 2016 - 2020 correspond well to the set up objectives and remains relevant in the context of the Syrian conflict and it's consequences.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Distribuera "vatten hållbarhet" i MENA& genomförandet av 2030 agenda
FAO- Deploying 'water sustainability' in MENA & implementing the 2030 Agenda

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 FAO har ansökt om medel hos Sida för att genomföra projektet "Implementering av ett hållbart hanterande av vatten med fokus på vatteneffektivitet och vattenproduktivitet i MENA regionen" under perioden 2016-2020.
Projektet syftar till att förbättra vatteneffektivitet och vattenproduktivitet i syfte att stärka både matsäkerhet och vattensäkerhet i Mellanöstern och Nordafrika inom ramen för Agenda 2030. Projektet är i också inriktat mot Hållbarhetsmål 6.4 som handlar om vatteneffektivitet och vattenproduktivitet.
Projektets totala kostnad är ungefär 98 MSEK varav FAO bidrar med 4 MSEK och Sida med 94 MSEK.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Nedan följer en sammanfattning på engelska.
FAO has applied to Sida for funding of 94 MSEK to carry out the project "Implementing the 2030 Agenda for Water efficiency/productivity and Water Sustainability in NENA countries" during the period 2016-2020.
This intervention aims to empower MENA countries to: (i) develop scenario analysis of development trajectories, adopting a Water-Food-Energy-Climate Nexus analytical framework, to serve for policies and strategies revisions towards 'water sustainability', higher food security and more climate-resilient systems; ii) implement measures to achieve the 2030 water-related sustainable development agenda.
The intervention's total budget is 98 MSEK out of which FAOs own funding is approximately 4 MSEK and the remaining 94 MSEK is applied for from Sida.

The expected outcome of the project is that countries of the NENA Region would be empowered at technical, institutional and policy levels to implement their water sustainability, food security, renewable energy and climate resilient agenda and to achieve the water-related SDG to 2030 within safe operational boundaries of water use. Overall, the expected impact is that food security in the NENA region will be strengthened through increased incomes and production, water resources will be used efficiently and sustainably, and climate change effects will be mitigated by a reduction in the carbon footprint of agriculture. An ‘incentive framework and investment’ working group, including parliamentarians, will provide a mechanism for policy and strategy changes, internalization and scaling-up of results.

tag.narrative: 2.3 - By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and non-farm employment.

2.3 - Till 2030 fördubbla jordbrukets produktivitet och inkomster för småskaliga livsmedelsproducenter, i synnerhet kvinnor, ursprungsfolk, familjejordbrukare, boskapsskötande nomader samt fiskare, inklusive genom säker och lika tillgång till mark, andra produktionsresurser och insatsvaror, kunskap, finansiella tjänster och marknader samt möjligheter till värdeskapande och sysselsättning utanför jordbruket.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The main achievements in the year can be summerized as below: -Full engagement of countries facilitated by the National multidisciplinary Teams of the regional water Scarcity initiative and engagement of both ministries in charge of water and agriculture. An estimated 1000 people engaged in the project so far. The number will be higher if we also account for the international gathering where the project has organised events, presentation, and contributed to fair/market place event. -Growing number of partners coming on board through the regional collaborative platforms under the water scarcity initiative and start developing synergies between countries. 15 collaboration/synergies established with international, regional or country level projects. These collaboration result in joint activities or events. -Five international partners involved in the project through contracts and about 16 country partners engaged in addition to the ministries. -1regional training on Water productivity organized for 40 participants coming from 8 countries. The training was organized by the University of Cordobain 2 sub-regional training for 4 countries with two days overlap between the 2 groups. 8 initial national review of crop water productivity reveal major knowledge gaps and importance to carry out detailed assessment for strategic crops. Further investigation being done at country level. -1 review of project implementation plan through the Human Right Based Approach (HRBA) and Gender lens. Report highlights options for monitoring HRBA. -14 pilot sites have been selected for field activities. In those sites, preparatory activities have been initiated to carry out water accounting, water productivity assessment, socio-economic and gender analysis. -6 rapid water accounting exercise well advanced and 2 countries trained on water accounting using remote sensing. These exercise highlight capacity development needs. -In 3 countries (Morocco, Tunisia, Jordan), farmer field schools (FFS) ongoing in 3 sites with a lot of interest from farmers and local organization; a demand from other 2 countries for FFS activities (Lebanon, Palestine); In average 2 FFS groups are organised per site. About 250 farmers will be engaged in those activities. (FFS are based on experimental learning processes). In 1 site (Morroco, Berrechid), one assessment of local governance reveal the need for institutional strengthening for water user groups and cooperatives. - In 1 site (Jendouba in Tunisia), a crop map using remote sensing have been produced by a multidisciplinary team from the ministry of agriculture of Tunisia as part of a long training on crop mapping using remote sensing. The training benefitted 15 young people from different departments of the Ministry of Agriculture. This pilot will guide the design of a regional training in 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: Humanitarian support to UNHCR in UN Consolidated and Emergency Appeals
Humanitärt stöd till UNHCRs aktiviteter i FNs samlade appeller

description.narrative: Each year, Sida makes loosely earmarked contributions to UNHCR's crisis-specific Refugee Response Plans, based on Sida's model for allocation of humanitarian aid and in response to prioritized humanitarian needs through Sida's own Humanitarian Crisis Analyses. The specific objectives of the individual response plans supported may vary from one crisis to another. Nevertheless, they always align with UNHCR's overall mandate and objective to provide protection and assistance to refugees and other persons of concern to the UNHCR. According to the Mission Statement "The High Commissioner for refugees is mandated by the UN to lead and coordinate international action for the worldwide protection of refugees and the resolution of refugee problems. UNHCR’s primary purpose is to safeguard the rights and well-being of refugees." The operations are sorted under four main pillars: 1) Refugee Programme 2) Stateless Programme 3) Reintegration Projects 4) IDP Projects The individual response plans also contribute to UNHCR's Global Strategic Priorities, as set out in the UNHCR Global Appeal. These take into account the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, as well as the commitments made at the World Humanitarian Summit and under the Grand Bargain.

Denna insats rör avtal med "The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)" från 2014, om bidrag till humanitära insatser.
Med sitt mandat att skydda flyktingar, tvångsfördrivna och statslösa, se till dessas möjlighet att återvända, vidarebosättas eller integreras i sina värdsamhällen, så är UNHCR, tillsammans med ICRC, Sidas viktigaste partner inom skyddsområdet. Utöver sin operativa roll i skyddet av flyktingar (juridisk hjälp, utfärda identitetshandlingar, asylrätt, etc) har UNHCR en normativ roll i övervakning och tolkning av flyktingkonventionen. UNHCR är inom humanitära systemet huvudaktören i alla flyktingkriser, med övergripande koordineringsansvar av FN- och civilsamhällsorganisationers humanitära arbete samt ansvarar för samarbete med nationella och lokala myndigheter. I dagsläget omfattar detta koordinering av flera regionala flyktingappeller så som Syrien, Afrikas horn, Nigeria, Sydsudan, Jemen, Centralafrikanska republiken, Burundi och i Europa.
I humanitära kriser inom ett lands gränser ansvarar "United Nations Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)" för koordineringen av den humanitära responsen, detta gäller även internflyktingkriser (Internally displaced People crisis). UNHCR ansvarar i dessa kriser för att leda och samordna arbetet i tre kluster (sektoriella koordineringsgrupper); skyddsklustret, klustret för ”Camp Coordination and Camp Management”, samt ”Emergency Shelter” klustret. UNHCR bidrar därmed till det humanitära systemet globalt, regionalt och nationellt. Utöver detta, och när situationen tillåter, arbetar UNHCR också för hållbara lösningar för flyktingar.
Genom sitt stöd till UNHCR 2020 bidrar Sida till att bistå flyktingar och internflyktingar så att dessa får skydd mot förföljelse och våld, tak över huvudet och basförnödenheter (mat, vatten, hygien, primärsjukvård, etc.) Vidare bidrar Sida till strategisk samordning inom det humanitära systemet.
Sidas finansiella bidrag till UNHCR 2020 omfattar totalt 250 MSEK, varav 30 MSEK specifikt har gått till den globala covid-19-responsplanen. Sida beslutar om detta stöd, som komplement till regeringens årliga kärnbidrag. Sidas stöd går till FNs konsoliderade humanitära appeller (Humanitarian Response Plans), UNHCRs Globala appell och UNHCRs tilläggsbudgetar (Supplementary Appeals) samt Regionala flyktingappeller (Regional Refugee Response Plans). Sida öronmärker genom avtal bidraget till UNHCR på land/region nivå men stödet är oöronmärkt inom denna nivå. Sida har under året även möjlighet att ta ställning till ytterligare stöd genom tilläggsbeslut.
Den största delen av stödet utbetalas i början av året för att UNHCR ska ges förutsättningar att planera och genomföra humanitära insatser utan fördröjning. UNHCR omsätter regelmässigt utbetalda medel i nära anslutning till utbetalning och förbrukar gåvomedel inom verksamhetsåret. Den föreslagna betalningsplanen överensstämmer således med Sidas insatshanteringsregel, avsnitt 2.8.4, där det föreskrivs att betalningen kommer att ske i nära anslutning till den tidpunkt då pengarna kommer att användas och som finansieringsbehoven uppstår. Ett avsteg från Sidas allmänna rutiner om uppdelade betalningar bedöms motiverat.
Bedömningspromemorian har skrivits på engelska med anledning av att engelskspråkig personal i fält är delaktig i beredning och uppföljning av insatsen, i enlighet med Generaldirektörens beslut om Sidas språkvalsmatris med tillämpningsanvisningar från den 1 mars 2013.

Sida has assessed the UN High Commissioner for Refugees as a relevant and strategic humanitarian partner with good implementation capacity. Sida’s Central Organisational Assessment of UNHCR (2015) concludes that the organisation’s systems for internal control are adequate according and in line with Sida contribution regulations.
Sida provides support, in addition to the MFA's annual core contribution, based on the UN Consolidated Appeals (HRP) and UNHCRs Global Appeal, Supplementary Budget Appeals and UNHCR Regional Response Plans (RRRP). Sida allocates funding to UNHCR on a country / regional level and support is unearmarked at this level. During the year Sida assesses UNHCR's Supplementary Appeals for possible additional funding through supplementary decisions.
With its mandate, to protect refugees, forcibly displaced communities and stateless people, and assist in their voluntary repatriation, local integration or resettlement to a third country, UNHCR is alongside ICRC Sida’s key protection partner. In addition to its operational role in the protection of refugees, UNHCR has a normative role in monitoring and interpreting the Refugee Convention. UNHCR is the lead Agency in Refugee operations within the humanitarian system with responsibility to coordinate UN agencies and NGOs response in refugee crisis. This includes coordination of several regional refugee appeals such as Syria, Horn of Africa, Nigeria, South Sudan, Yemen, CAR, Burundi and Europe.
UNHCR coordinates its response under OCHA in emergency within countries (internally displaced people). UNHCR is responsible for leading and coordinating the Protection Cluster, the clusters of Camp Coordination and Camp Management, as well as the Emergency Shelter cluster. UNHCR is thereby contributing strategically to the humanitarian system, at global, regional and country level.
Through this support Sida contributes humanitarian funding to UNHCR in order to assist refugees and internally displaced people in armed conflict, providing legal protection from persecution and violence, emergency shelter (tents, semi-permanent structures, rent for temporary accommodation) and basic necessities (such as food, water, hygiene and primary health care, etc), as well as opportunities for durable solutions, when the situation so allows.
The country allocations for 2019 includes a total of 250 MSEK, including 30 MSEK to the global COVID-19 response plan.
To facilitate rapid humanitarian planning and response, disbursement the main part of the amount is made at the beginning of the year after signing of the Agreement and upon disbursement request from UNHCR. Funds are utilized within a short timeframe after disbursement and UNHCR has a general utilization rate of 98% of the annual contributions. It is Sida's experience that funds available for activities at the country level rarely reaches or exceeds UNHCR's total funding needs. The funding level for UNHCR is generally about 50% of the annual budget. In the exceptional case that UNHCR has not utilized the entire Sida contribution by the end of the year, Sida has been duly informed and the balance have been regulated in accordance with the agreement. The proposed payment plan is thus in line with Sida's rule for contribution management § 2.8.4, which stipulates that payment will be made in close connection with the time when the funds will be used, and as the funding needs arise.

participating-org.narrative: UNHCR/United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
United Nations Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Insatsen har löpt under många år, med stöd till ett stort antal kontexter. Det är närmast omöjligt att enkelt sammanfatta de resultat som UNHCR har åstadkommit under dessa år, givet att de har årliga appeller som identifierar behov för flyktingar, internt tvångsfördrivna, statslösa och återvändande. Rapporterna visar på mycket bred verksamhet som har lyckats säkerställa skydd, bidra med förnödenheter och nödbostäder, utbildning, hälsovård, sysselsättning och mycket mer. UNHCR har också i allt högre utsträckning försökt hitta hållbara lösningar och nya sätt att arbeta för sina målgrupper så effektivt som möjligt (t ex genom att kraftigt öka andelen kontantstöd). UNHCR har även arbetat intensivt med värdregeringar och givarländer för att till exempel förbättra lagstiftning, möta växande behov och stärka samverkan med utvecklingsaktörer (inklusive nationella myndigheter). UNHCR är huvudaktören i alla flyktingkriser inom det humanitära systemet, med övergripande koordineringsansvar av FN- och civilsamhällsorganisationers humanitära arbete samt ansvarar för samarbete med nationella och lokala myndigheter. I många flyktingsituationer har UNHCR därför varit en helt central organisation för att rädda liv och lindra nöd för miljoner människor, i sin roll som garant och uttolkare av Flyktingkonventionen. Exempel på konkreta resultat finns i UNHCR:s Global Report för varje år (tillgänglig på portalsajten Global Focus - reporting.unhcr.org). Där finns också länkar till varje kris där UNHCR är närvarande, inkluvise de som finansierats av Sida specifikt.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
